14. **GOVERNMENT ISSUE**

(a) All items comprised in any Government issue supplied to the Contractor for the purposes of the contract shall always be and remain the property of His Majesty and shall be used by the Contractor solely for the purposes of the contract and the Contractor shall account fully to the Minister for such Government issue in such manner as the Minister may require.

(b) The Contractor shall be responsible for and shall indemnify His Majesty for all loss or damage of or to any and all such Government issue while on the premises of or in the care or subject to the control of the Contractor and shall at its own expense replace, repair or restore to the complete satisfaction of the Minister any and all such Government issue which may be so lost or damaged; provided that the Contractor shall not be obligated to make good damage caused by reasonable wear and tear or due to causes beyond his control.

15. **PRECAUTIONS AGAINST FIRE**

The Contractor shall take special precautions to prevent fire occurring in or about the work, and shall observe and comply with all laws and regulations in force respecting fires, and with all regulations and instructions made and given from time to time during construction, by the Indian Agent with respect to fires and the prevention and extinguishing of fires.

16. **ASSIGNMENTS**

The Contractor shall not assign or sublet the contract without the written consent of the Minister first obtained; provided however that (unless, in any case, the Minister objects thereto and subject also as herein provided) the Contractor may sublet such portions of the work herein contracted for as is customary and usual in the construction of such work, but His Majesty shall not in any way be held liable for the payment of any moneys due to any subcontractor, and the Contractor shall be held responsible for the proper performance of every portion of the work herein contracted for.

17. **SUB-CONTRACTORS**

The Contractor shall, before entering into any sub-contractors for work or materials, notify the Indian Agent in writing of the names of all such proposed sub-contractors and the terms and conditions of such sub-contracts and shall not enter into any such sub-contracts without obtaining the approval of the Indian Agent thereto.

The Indian Agent may, on request, furnish to any sub-contractor wherever practicable, evidence of the amounts certified to on his account.

The Contractor agrees to bind every sub-contractor by the terms of the General Conditions, Drawings and Specifications, as far as applicable to his work.

18. **MEMBER OF H. OF C. NOT TO BENEFIT.**

No member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of the contract, or to any benefit to arise therefrom.
ACCOUNTS

The Contractor shall keep proper accounts and records in such form and detail as shall be satisfactory to the Minister of the cost to the Contractor of the work and the invoices, receipts and vouchers relating thereto, and such accounts, records, invoices receipts and vouchers shall at all times be open to audit and inspection by the Minister or his authorized representatives (who may make copies thereof and take extracts therefrom) and the Contractor shall afford all proper facilities for such audits and inspections and shall furnish the Minister and his authorized representative with all such information as he or they may from time to time require with reference to such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers. If any part of the work is performed by an allied firm (as defined herein) the Contractor shall also cause such allied firm to keep similar accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers with respect to the cost of the work performed by such allied firm, and to permit the same to be inspected and audited by the authorized representatives of the Minister. The Contractor shall cause all such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers as aforesaid to be preserved and kept available for audit and inspection at any time and from time to time until the expiration of five (5) years from the date of the termination of the work.

WORK TO BE FREE FROM ALL ENCUMBRANCE

Before making any payment on any progress or final estimate the Minister may require the Contractor to furnish evidence that all work performed, and material supplied and all structures built for which payment is being made are free and clear from all lawful claims or liens under any law for labour, workmanship, materials or otherwise; the Contractor shall indemnify and hold harmless His Majesty from and against any and all kinds of claims or liens accruing from labour and services performed and material furnished or otherwise, and any of the same in or about the works.

PATENT CLAIMS AND ROYALTIES

(a) His Majesty shall indemnify the Contractor against all actions, claims or proceedings for infringement of any patent or industrial design rights or of any alleged patent or industrial design rights (hereinafter referred to as "patent rights") in carrying out his contract, and for royalties or other payments which may be payable in connection with any such patent rights (including any amounts properly payable by the Contractor to any of its subcontractors pursuant to any similar covenant of indemnity given by the Contractor to any sub-contractor), in respect of anything the model, plan or design of which shall have been provided by or on behalf of His Majesty, but this indemnity shall apply to this contract only.

(b) Save and except as set forth in sub-section (a) of this section, the Contractor shall indemnify His Majesty against all actions, claims or proceedings for infringement of any patent rights and for royalties or other payments which may be payable in connection with any such patent rights in carrying out this contract.

(c) Before making any payments with respect to any patent rights, the Contractor shall supply to the Minister a statement showing all payments and claims for payment by way of royalties or otherwise which the Contractor or any of its subcontractors will or may be obligated to make or proposes to make to the owner or holder of any patent rights in connection with this contract, and the basis thereof and the parties to whom the same are payable, and shall from time to time promptly advise the Minister of any and all claims or arrangements made or proposed, which would or might result in further or different payments being made by the Contractor or any of its subcontractors by way of royalties or otherwise as aforesaid.
(d) If and when the Minister shall so direct, the Contractor shall make no payment by way of royalties or otherwise with respect to any patent rights referred to in any statement furnished by the Contractor as provided in sub-section (c) of this section, except with the consent of the Minister and subject to such conditions as the Minister may impose and from and after the giving of any such direction by the Minister His Majesty shall indemnify the Contractor against any action, claim or proceeding for infringement of the patent rights covered by such direction or for non-payment of royalties or other payments in respect thereof.

22. SANITATION

The Contractor shall comply with, and the work shall be carried on subject to all regulations made by any lawful authority and applicable to said work, and all orders given by the Indian Agent with respect to sanitation or preservation of health on the work. The Contractor shall make adequate arrangements, to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent, for the medical and sanitary supervision of all his employees.

23. INDIAN AGENT'S MARKS

The Contractor shall protect, and shall not remove or destroy, or permit to be removed or destroyed, the stakes, buoys and other marks placed on or about the said work by the Indian Agent or his assistants, and shall furnish the necessary assistance to correct or replace any stake, buoy or mark which through any cause may have been removed or destroyed.

24. NOTICES

Any notice, order, direction or other communication given to the Contractor under any of the provisions of this contract shall be sufficiently given if delivered to the Contractor personally, or to his foreman, or left at the Contractor's office, or mailed at any post office to the Contractor or foreman addressed to the address mentioned in the contract, or to the Contractor's last known place of business or residence.

25. PROGRESS MEASUREMENTS AND CERTIFICATES NOT BINDING

The progress measurements and progress certificates shall not in any respect be taken as binding upon the Indian Agent or as final measurements or as fixing final amounts; they are to be subject to the revision of the Indian Agent in making up his final certificate, and they shall not in any respect be taken as an acceptance of the work or as a release of the Contractor from responsibility in respect thereof.

26. PROTECTION OF WORK

The contract and all information issued in connection therewith are confidential and their use must be strictly confined to the work and to the purpose of the contract; the particulars contained therein; and other matter issued in connection therewith, must not be disclosed to unauthorized persons.

The Contractor shall at all times take and cause to be taken all reasonable measures, for the protection of the work against espionage and sabotage, and on the order of the Minister shall dispense with the services of any person employed in, about or upon the work or cause the same to be dispensed with. The Minister shall at all times through such agency as he may see fit be entitled to maintain on or about the premises where the work or any part thereof is being carried on such police or other protective force as in the opinion of the Minister may be advisable.
27. CANADIAN WORK AND MATERIALS

To the full extent that the same are procurable, only Canadian labour, parts and materials (unless otherwise agreed by the Minister) shall be used in connection with the work.

27a. EMPLOYMENT OF EX-SERVICE MEN

In engaging labour for the work contemplated by this contract, either from the National Employment Service or from Trade Unions with which the contractor has collective agreements, the contractor shall specify that preference shall be given to competent and available ex-service men.

The contractor shall maintain and keep available for inspection by the Minister a record of the names and addresses of ex-service men employed, together with a record of the steps taken to implement this requirement.

28. SALARIES:

The salaries payable to engineers, superintendents, draftsmen and foremen shall only be such as shall be approved by the Minister.

29. TERMINATION

(a) Notwithstanding anything in this contract contained the Minister may, by giving notice to the Contractor, terminate the contract (save and except the provisions of this section and of section 19 of these general conditions) as regards all or any part or parts of the work or works not theretofore completed. Upon such notice being given, the Contractor shall cease work (including the procuring of materials for the fulfilment of the contract) in accordance with and to the extent specified in such notice but shall proceed with all reasonable speed to complete such part or parts (if any) of the work or works as are by the terms of such notice to be completed and shall also proceed with all reasonable speed to complete up to such time and/or stage as may be specified in the notice any part or parts of the work or works as required by such notice. The Minister may, at any time, or from time to time give one or more additional notices with respect to any or all parts of the work which remain to be completed after the giving of any previous notice or notices.

(b) All work completed by the Contractor under or pursuant to the provisions of the contract before or after the giving of any notice, subject to acceptance by His Majesty in accordance with the provisions of the contract, shall be paid for on the basis provided in the agreement (the Contractor being allowed such fraction of his stipulated fee as shall be proportionate to the amount of the work theretofore completed) and the Contractor shall be entitled to be reimbursed the actual cost to the contractor of work not completed under or pursuant to the provisions of this contract and/or any notice given pursuant thereto plus a fair and reasonable profit in respect of work done thereon, provided that no reimbursement shall be made for materials which have been or may be rejected after inspection as not complying with the terms and conditions of this contract and the specifications.
(c) In the event that the Contractor and the Minister are unable to agree upon the amount in respect of which the Contractor is entitled to be reimbursed as aforesaid, the matter shall be referred to the Exchequer Court.

(d) Whenever practicable the Contractor shall procure materials required for the performance of the contract on terms that will enable it to terminate any contracts entered into by the Contractor upon conditions and terms similar in effect to those herein provided for in respect to termination by the Minister and the giving of a notice or notices as aforesaid; and generally the Contractor shall co-operate with His Majesty and the Minister and do everything reasonably within its power at all times to minimize and reduce the amount of His Majesty's obligations under the provisions of this section.

(e) Upon reimbursement being made to the Contractor as herein provided, title to the materials and/or work in progress in respect of which such reimbursement is made shall pass to and vest in His Majesty (the Contractor hereby agreeing to execute and deliver all requisite instruments by way of further assurance) and such materials and/or work in progress shall be delivered to the order of the Minister, but the materials thus taken over will in no case be in excess of what would have been required for performing the contract in full if no notice had been given under the provisions hereof.

(f) If it is established to the satisfaction of the Minister by the Contractor that by reason of any action taken by the Minister under the provisions of this section exceptional hardship has resulted to the Contractor then the Minister may, notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, in his absolute discretion grant such allowance (not to include in any case, however, any allowance or compensation for loss of profit) to the Contractor as, in the opinion of the Minister is warranted by the circumstances.

(g) Any action, decision or determination by the Minister under the provisions of this section shall be final and binding upon the Contractor.

(h) The Contractor shall have no claim for damages, compensation, loss of profit, allowance or otherwise by reason of or directly or indirectly arising out of any action taken or notice given by the Minister under or pursuant to the provisions of this section except as and to the extent in this section expressly provided.

(i) The right of termination and of giving notice hereinafter provided shall be in addition to and not in substitution for any other right possessed by His Majesty and/or the Minister.

30. LABOUR CONDITIONS

The Contractor shall comply with and be subject to all the terms and conditions of the Labour Conditions (if any) referred to in the agreement and to all variations and modifications thereof that may at any time be enacted or brought into force during the continuance of the contract.

THIS AGREEMENT made in triplicate as of this day of

BETWEEN:

HIS MAJESTY THE KING in right of Canada (hereinafter called "His Majesty") herein represented by the Honourable the Minister of Mines and Resources (hereinafter called "the Minister")

OF THE FIRST PART

- and -

THE POOLE CONSTRUCTION COMPANY OF EDMONTON (hereinafter called "the Contractor")

OF THE SECOND PART

WITNESSETH that it is agreed by and between the parties hereto as follows:

SECTION 1. CONTRACT AND INTERPRETATION

(a) The contract consists of the following:

(i) this agreement

(ii) the general conditions attached hereto, and referred to as Schedule "B" (cost Plus Percentage Construction)

(iii) the labour conditions attached hereto

(iv) the definition of cost attached hereto and marked Schedule "A".

(v) all plans, drawings, specifications or other documents or exhibits (if any) attached hereto and initialled or otherwise identified by the parties hereto, or referred to herein as being a part hereof

all of which shall be applicable to and shall form part of this Contract and be binding upon the parties hereto as fully and to the same extent as if set out or incorporated herein;

(b) In this contract unless the context otherwise requires:

"Engineer" shall mean the Indian Agent of the Edmonton Agency, Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources, having control over the work and shall extend to and include any of the officers or employees of the Department of Mines and Resources acting under the instructions of the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch, and all instructions and directions, or certificates, orders or decisions made by any one acting for the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch, shall be subject to the approval of the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch, and may be cancelled, altered, modified and changed as the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch may see fit; Provided always, and
it is hereby understood and agreed that any act on the part of
the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch in connection with and
in virtue of the present contract, and any instructions or
directions or certificates given, or decisions made by the said
Director of the Indian Affairs Branch, or by anyone acting for
such Director or the Indian Affairs Branch, shall be subject to
approval or modification or cancellation by the Minister.

"Minister" shall mean the Minister of Mines and Resources
of Canada, and his successor for the time being in office and
includes the Deputy Minister or any acting Deputy Minister and
any duly authorized representative of the Department of Mines and
Resources.

SECTION 2. SUBJECT MATTER

The Contractor covenants and agrees:

(a) To erect a school on the Stony Plain Indian Reserve
in the Edmonton Agency, in the Province of Alberta,
subject to the conditions mentioned in this con-
tract,

all of which is hereinafter referred to as "the work"

(b) To provide all labour, materials, plant and
equipment (except such materials as are included
in the Government issue, if any) required for the proper com-
pletion of the work, and to perform all the work of and
incidental thereto;

(c) To provide an efficient administration for and to
superintend efficiently the work at all times;

(d) To perform and observe all covenants, terms,
provisos and conditions contained in the contract on the part
of the Contractor to be performed and observed;

(e) To carry out and perform the work with all possible
despatch and to complete the work to the satisfaction of the
Minister.

SECTION 3. PRICE - COST PLUS PERCENTAGE

His Majesty covenants and agrees:

(a) To pay to the Contractor the cost of the work,
as defined in Schedule "A" hereto attached which cost as so
defined is hereinafter referred to as "the cost of the work".

(b) To pay to the Contractor a fee equal to ten
per cent (10%) of the cost of the work payable in monthly pay-
ments bearing the same proportion to the total that the cost of
the work done (as certified by the Indian Agent) during the month
for which payment is claimed bears to the estimated cost of the work.
(c) The said fee referred to in subsection (b) shall be deemed to cover the entire profit of the Contractor and the necessary services of all executive officers of the Contractor and also all overhead expenses of the Contractor at its general offices and at any regularly established branch office, including but without limiting the generality of the foregoing the services of the purchasing, accounting, estimating and contract departments at such general offices or regularly established branch office.

SECTION 4. REFUNDS AND TRADE DISCOUNTS

The Contractor covenants and agrees to take advantage of any and all refunds and trade discounts and such refunds and trade discounts and any profits (save and except the fee payable to the Contractor as provided in Section 3 hereof) which may be received by the Contractor in any way in connection with the work shall be credited by the Contractor to His Majesty. It is understood and agreed, however, that the Contractor shall notify His Majesty immediately upon placing each order for material to be used in connection with the work upon which a cash discount will accrue, for the purpose of enabling His Majesty to take advantage of such cash discount, if His Majesty deems it advisable, by advancing funds to the Contractor to cover such above-mentioned orders or by paying for such orders out of funds set aside by His Majesty for that purpose, and upon His Majesty advancing such funds to the Contractor to cover such above-mentioned orders, the Contractor shall apply them so that the cash discounts thereon will be obtained. Provided always, however, that if His Majesty fails to provide funds to the Contractor to cover such orders or fails to pay for same as provided for above, the Contractor shall be entitled to the benefit of all cash discounts in respect of purchases made by it with its own funds or materials required for the carrying out of this contract. It is understood that His Majesty may supply the Contractor with materials or may make available to the Contractor funds with which to purchase materials required for the purposes of this contract and any and all materials or funds so supplied or made available shall be used by the Contractor solely for the purposes of this contract.

SECTION 5. LISTS OF MATERIALS AND EQUIPMENT SUPPLIERS

The Contractor shall, before placing any orders for any equipment or materials required for the performance of this contract submit to the Minister a list of the suppliers from which, and the price at which it proposes to purchase such materials or equipment, and the Contractor shall, if so directed by the Minister, purchase any or all of such materials or equipment from the same or from some other supplier or suppliers designated by the Minister, with which the Department of Mines and Resources may have made special arrangements for the supply thereof or with respect to priorities in the delivery thereof.
SECTION 6.

(a) As promptly as possible after the 1st day of each month during the prosecution of the work, the Contractor shall furnish to the Minister a certified statement or progress claim of the cost of the work (determined in accordance with Schedule "A") for the preceding period, such statement to be accompanied by two copies of all payrolls, vouchers and invoices and such other information as the Minister may require and thereupon, if such statement is satisfactory to the Minister, the Contractor will be paid the amount which may be due within fifteen (15) days after such statement or progress claim has been received by the Minister;

(b) Payments shall be made only on the production and delivery by the Contractor to the Minister of a certificate in writing signed by the Indian Agent and, if required by the Minister, by a cost accountant appointed or approved by the Minister, certifying the amount to which the contractor is entitled as aforesaid;

(c) The Contractor shall, when making his final requisition for payment furnish to the Indian Agent satisfactory evidence, supported by a statutory declaration in form approved by the Minister establishing payment by the Contractor of the items listed in all preceding requisitions and such other information as the Minister may require;

(d) The final payment shall not become due until the Indian Agent and, if required by the Minister, a cost accountant appointed or approved by the Minister shall have issued a certificate that such payment is due and the Contractor shall have produced proof satisfactory to the Minister that no lien does or can exist against the work; in respect to materials, equipment or payment of wages;

(e) Five copies of all progress claims and summaries of invoices in connection with the work shall be rendered by the Contractor to the Indian Agent.

SECTION 7.

CONTRACTOR'S ADDRESS

The address of the Contractor for all purposes of and incidental to this contract is hereby declared to be Edmonton, Alberta.

Re Day Schools, Michel and Stony Plain Reserves.

Referring to your letter of Aug. 23rd, in regard to plans for the above schools.

The further sets of plans received have not been received and of those sent Aug. 23rd, the first two copies are very hard to read. Could you let me have about three copies of the first two plans of the set.

In regard to electric lighting for the Stony Plain School, will you please advise if this is to be installed as per your letter of June 23rd, to Mr. Gooderham, copy of which he has forwarded to me. There would not appear to be any provision in the plans or specifications for wiring of this school.

E. A. Robertson,
Indian Agent.
October 15, 1947.

Mr. E. A. Robertson, Indian Agent,
Wainwright, Alberta.

New Schools - Highwood and Stony Plain.

These new sets of plans were forwarded to you, as requested in your letter of October 15, 1947.

We are not in a position yet to advise if funds will be available to the extent of the $3,500.00 required to install electricity and running water at the Stony Plain Day School.

The specifications and blue-prints for the standard one-room school do not call for electrical wiring. However, we have had this school wired elsewhere during the course of construction. We are quite prepared to leave this matter for decision between the contractor and yourselves. It would be appreciated if we could be informed as to the approximate cost of having this school wired suitably. It may be possible that we could have it wired this year and then arrange for the installation of the poles and lines next year, when funds are available.

Bernard F. Neary,
Dept. of Welfare & Training.
Extract from letter from Indian Agent E.A. Robertson, dated October 8th. Original on file 110-4-5

"We have also been successful in securing water at the Stony Plain Reserve site. This well hit the water bearing quicksand at 45 feet and is three feet into the strata, giving about four feet of water in the three foot hole. We have found that the quicksand wells will eventually fill in with sand but in the meantime it should provide sufficient water for a few years.

"The cement work for the basement of the Stony Plain school has now been completed and the contractors are at present working on the basement for the Michel School in an endeavour to finish all the cement work before the cold weather sets in.

"The road in to the Stony Plain school, approximately 200 yards, has also been put through but will require a little more grading when the bulldozer is finishing up the levelling of the school site."
Ottawa, December 1, 1947.

Re: Day Schools, Michel Reserve and Stony Plain Reserve.

I am enclosing herewith Progress Claims from the Poole Construction Co. Ltd., in connection with the construction of the above mentioned schools, in the amount of $890.94 for Michel School and $4037.57 for Stony Plain school.

I am not just clear as to what documents should accompany this claim. Sec. 6 of the contract states that the claim should be accompanied by two copies of all payrolls, invoices, etc., while instructions received from the Treasury Department, Calgary, states that these claims do not require copies of payrolls, invoices, etc., and that one copy only of these documents is required with the final claim.

If the copies of payrolls, invoices etc., should have been held here for final claim, will you please return them to me.

The invoice from the Thompson Hardware Co., for materials for Stony Plain School is not attached. The Poole Construction are securing this invoice and will it will sent you as soon as received.

E. A. Robertson,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, December 24, 1947.

Progress Payment -
Stony Plain Indian Day School

Payrolls have been examined in detail and compared with the original paysheets. Daily time records were not available for examination as these are destroyed once they have been transferred to and balanced with paysheets.

The rates of pay observed on the job were in accordance with those approved on the agreement and based on a 44 hour week with overtime at time and a half. Travelling time was paid at regular hourly rate, and was not taken into account in the accumulation of overtime.

Superintendent $1.87½ per hour
(based on fixed salary of $75.00 per week, 40 hour week)
Carpenter foreman 1.40 per hour
Carpenters 1.25 - 1.35
Carpenter Apprentice .63
Labour foreman .90
Labour .80
Indian labour, approved by Indian Agent .55 - .75
Instrumentman 1.05

On payroll # 47 for the period end October 16/47, an error of $2.00 has been noted in the computation of L. Gabrielson's wages which are shown as $37.20 instead of $39.20. As this employee terminated his services with the contractor in January, some difficulty may be experienced in adjusting this amount.
HOLIDAY PAY has been computed throughout at the rate of 3% with all employees including Indians being covered. As in the Michel Reserve School contract, some adjustment will be necessary to bring the charges in line with the actual rates applicable to each employee. Holiday Pay should also have been added to the payrolls in calculating workman's compensation and Public Liability and Property Damage charges.

WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION charge has been calculated at 4% of normal payroll throughout the project. Adjustments arising out of assessments on individual earnings over $3000 will be credited on the final claim.

PUBLIC LIABILITY & PROPERTY DAMAGE Insurance is carried by the Contractor and is in good standing. Charges levied against this project were calculated at .31% of the gross payroll from the commencement of the project to Payroll #2 for the period ending January 15th, 1948, and at .230% on the remaining payrolls included to date. The current year's rate has since been established at .22%, and the required adjustment will be included in the final claim.

UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE contributions have been deducted from all employees with the exception of Superintendent H.G. Ellanwood, who receives a fixed salary of $75.00 per week. The employer's portion was calculated on the basis of 75% of employee's contribution.

INCOME TAX - The records were examined for compliance with income tax regulations and evidence of deductions and remittances were produced to the examiner's satisfaction.

INSURANCE covering fire risk on the project is contained in Asta Insurance Co. Policy #7860 for $11,000 in the names of the Department of Indian Affairs and Poole Construction Co. Ltd. The original policy has been lodged with the Department through the Indian Agent. The duplicate copy of the policy has been examined and payment of premium verified.

MATERIALS - $5765.06

Invoices for materials, small tools, either purchased by the contractor or supplied from their own stock, have been checked to purchase orders and requisitions and also certified by the Indian Agent. Evidence of payment by the contractor to the suppliers has been verified in all cases.

Transfers of materials from the Winterburn School to the Michel School or vice versa, and items distributed between the two schools were found to be properly accounted for with the exception of a 50¢ error on Invoice #1439, where the amount of $51.69 was transferred instead of $51.69. This is to be adjusted on the final claim.

SMALL TOOLS

A joint inventory of small tools amounting to $71.82, which were purchased and charged to the Michel and Winterburn Schools, has been set up.
TRAVELLING EXPENSES - $294.00

Travelling expenses have been paid to A.C. Emsen, job foreman, who provided conveyance to his crew in his personally owned car at the rate of $8.00 per round trip, which in this instance represented 26 miles. Evidence of payment has been ascertained and the number of trips checked with the number of days worked during each period.

Hired Equipment - $27.00

Charges recorded under this caption represent services of G. Morin, with team, at the rate of $1.50 per hour, which compares closely with the minimum rate approved.

TRUCKING - $156.00

Trucking charges on the Company's equipment were set at $3.00 per hour, including operator, and approved by the Indian Agent. Daily time cards were examined and found to correspond with the invoices submitted and carried the foreman's signature.

SUB-CONTRACTS

Millwork - W.M. Clark Lumber Co., have agreed to supply all millwork at an estimated price of $1859.00. This was the lower of two submissions received by the Contractor and was found acceptable by the Indian Agent. So far, invoices amounting to $1565.15, have been submitted on this project.

Painting & Decorating - The firm of Jack Mason was the only party interested in this job and has agreed to complete painting and decorating for $1050. To date accounts have been rendered for $840, representing 80% of the work completed.

Electrical - Al's Electric, 12130 - 95A Street, have been authorized to supply and install electrical wiring and outlets at the price of $515 and to supply and install standard fixtures in the classroom and residence for $195. To date accounts have been rendered for $490.40.

Plumbing & Heating - The sub-letting of this work has been carried out on a cost of labour and material basis, as no firm appeared interested in submitting estimates.

The firm of Dow & Scott have to date rendered accounts for $94.15 of which $9.50 represents labour.

The firm of Press & Maxwell have agreed to supply and install furnace and heating system on the same basis, and have submitted accounts for $410.56 to date. Completion of this phase of the work is estimated to cost approximately $450 more. The General Contractor has a sufficient hold-back against these two firms and a detail audit will be performed when all work has been completed.
COMMISSION OR FEE - $1568.64

In accordance with the terms of the agreement, the Poole Construction Company have charged a 10% commission or fee on all costs incurred to date, omitting any commission on any earnings of the Company arising out of rental of Company owned equipment.

I am enclosing herewith requisition to cover window blinds for the Stony Plain and Michel day schools also Penetrem for finishing the floors and dustbane and a push broom for each school.

The rates observed were based on an 8 hour day, 44 hour week with time and a half for overtime. Travelling time was paid at the regular rate and was not taken into account in the accumulation of overtime.

Effective April 1st, 1948, the following rates were paid by the Contractor in compliance with an Agreement reached between the Edmonton Building Exchange and the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America:

- Carpenter foreman - $1.50 per hour
- Carpenters - $1.40 per hour
- Laborers - $.70 per hour
- Superintendents - $2.00 per hour, based on fixed salary of $60.00 per week, with approval of the Indian Superintendent.

Indian labor has been paid at 75¢ per hour, with approval of Indian Superintendent.

An underpayment of $2.00 noted on payroll #47 for Oct. 14, 1947, appearing in Claim #5, in connection with L. Gabrielson has not been possible to adjust as this former employee could not be located. No further action is contemplated by the Contractor.
HOLIDAY PAY - $64.05

Discrepancies in the calculation of Holiday Pay in Claims 1 to 4 inclusive have been adjusted in this claim by a debit voucher for $13.72 which has been added to the charge of $40.34 applicable to the payrolls submitted with the present claim, making a total charge of $54.05.

The Employees' Holiday Pay Books have been examined and proof of payment established.

Holiday Pay charges have also been taken into account in the computation of the other payroll charges.

HOFMANN'S COMPENSATION - $20.79

The Contractor's assessment rate by the Alberta Workmen's Compensation Board has been 4% for the years 1947 and 1948.

The amount presently claimed represents charges of $48.73 applicable to the payrolls submitted with this claim less a rebate of $27.94 received by the Contractor on 1947 payments in connection with employees whose earnings exceeded the maximum assessable amount of $2000 for that year.

A further examination of the Contractor's records will be made on receipt of the returns from the W.C.B. for 1948 in order to secure any further credit that may accrue.

PUBLIC LIABILITY & PROPERTY DAMAGE - $2.70

The Contractor has maintained adequate coverage against the above risks throughout the Contract. The payment of premiums which were based on .15% of the estimated gross payroll for 1947 and on .22% for 1948, has been established.

The calculations have been reviewed in connection with the present and previous claims and the amount charged has been found sufficiently accurate.

UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE - $4.96

This amount represents the Contractor's portion of contributions paid on behalf of insurable employees listed on the payrolls submitted herewith. The Unemployment Insurance Books for the current fiscal year were produced for examination and satisfactory evidence given that the above Act has been complied with throughout the contract.

INCOME TAX

The Contractor has complied with the Income Tax Act and Regulations in retaining the necessary deductions from taxable employees and remitting same to the Receiver General regularly.

MATERIALS - $244.66

Invoices for materials purchased or supplied from the Contractor's stock have been compared with purchase Orders and requisitions as well as checked for calculations and extensions. A discrepancy of 10¢ in listing Invoice # 7745 on Claim # 1 has been adjusted. Also Invoice # 1382 for $5.30 which was charged in error on Claim # 4 has now been deleted.
Although the Contractor did not have delivery slips to establish proof of delivery of materials, the Indian Agent was able to confirm in most instances that the materials charged had actually been used on the project.

Materials divided between the Stony Plain and Michel Schools have been checked closely for possible duplication and found correctly recorded.

**SMALL TOOLS - $24.97 Credit**

A joint inventory of small tools maintained in connection with the Stony Plain and Michel Schools has been reviewed and a credit of $24.97 has been obtained to cover items retained by the Contractor. The entire amount has been credited to this school in view of the relatively small amount involved.

**FIRE INSURANCE**

An Insurance Policy with the Aetna Insurance Co. for $11,000 has been maintained on the school while under construction. On advice from the Agency Superintendent the Policy has not been renewed by the Contractor since it expired in October 1948.

**TRAVELLING EXPENSES - $36.00**

This amount has been paid to employees of the Contractor for providing transportation to the men in their personal car. The round trip covered some 26 miles and the rate of $2.00 per round trip which has been charged appears fair and reasonable.

**SUB-CONTRACTOR**

**MILLWORK - W.H. Clark Lumber Co. - $14.03**

Invoices for millwork supplied by this sub-contractor and submitted in the present and previous claims amount to $1579.19 although they have not all been listed under sub-contracts. This amount is well within the approved tender for $1629.00.

The above charge of $14.03 represents an invoice for $13.73 for finishings and a 30¢ undercharge in Claim #4 where credit invoice #1439 has been listed as $11.89 instead of $11.59. This sub-contractor has supplied and installed the electrical wiring and standard fixtures in the school and living quarters at a total cost of $490.40, which charges have been included in previous claims. An estimated cost of $310 had been approved by the Indian Affairs Branch.

contractor has a sufficient hold-back on other projects to be protected against the liability for any unpaid accounts of the sub-contractor.

Dear Col. Murray,

In February I visited the Sioux Plain Day School and was impressed particularly with the number of boys in attendance. It was a blizzard day and I found 41 pupils in attendance. The young teacher, Mr. Laddie, appeared to be a capable teacher and had his classes well organized.

I learned that the average attendance for June 30 had been 27, and the highest attendance for the term was 58. Superintendent Robertson, who accompanied me, stated that there will be another in the fall of school—a new hall. It is, therefore, necessary to find space for another classroom.

As you may know, it is proposed to move the agency headquarters from Wainwright to the City of Edmonton, and, for your information, I am attaching copy of a letter which I have written to Mr. Pratt in this regard.

The agency office is about a mile to the east of the school and would, in our opinion, make a very suitable school to take 30 or 35 pupils. It is well constructed, well heated by a furnace in good condition and, so far as I can see, it will be necessary only to remove some partitions and change certain windows to make it a very suitable classroom.

As stated in the letter to Mr. Pratt, the cottage across the road could, in turn, be made the home of the teacher and I believe this would be a real inducement for a good, able minded teacher to apply. The total cost of turning the office into a school should not exceed $1,000.00.

For various reasons, therefore, it is hoped that the agency headquarters are moved into the city in the early summer and that this building can be made ready for a class before the fall term.

You will be advised of progress.

Dear Mr. Pratt:

Re: Edmonton Indian Agency Administrative Office

On my return from Ottawa I got in touch with the District Architect, Department of Public Works, and advised him that it was the wish of the Director of Indian Affairs that he obtain office space in Edmonton for the headquarters of the Edmonton Indian Agency, and that this space would be required as soon as possible, preferably early in the new fiscal year.

I also informed the Superintendent of the Agency, Mr. Robertson, and the present Fur Supervisor, Mr. W. B. Skead. It was known that the District Architect would be glad to have any leads or assistance that these men could give in locating office space in that city, as space there is very scarce.

Space is required for the Superintendent and his staff of three clerks, also the Fur Supervisor. I hope you agree that the latter should be established at the Edmonton Agency office. This office should also be the headquarters of the Welfare Officer, Inspector of Schools and Building Supervisor, when these officials are working in or out of Edmonton. In our opinion the space should not be less than 600 sq. ft.

I have to report that D.P.W. officials are finding it very difficult to locate any office space. Oil companies are offering large rentals for any available space in the city, and it is understood that good space is costing as high as $4.00 a sq.ft.

The District Architect has been advised that location is not of first importance to Indian Affairs. He stated this week that he is constantly surveying the whole situation and following any possible leads, and has hopes that suitable space will be located.

In the meantime, a Clerk, Grade 3, with a homes in Edmonton, has been detailed by the Civil Service Commission to fill the vacancy at the Agency. This man is boarding with the Superintendent at Winterburn.
W. J. F. Pratt, Esq.

March 11/49

The Superintendent and members of his office staff, Mr. Mitchell and Mr. Sims, know that they must find their own living quarters when and if the office is moved into Edmonton.

On a recent visit to the present Agency, consideration was given to the disposition of the buildings when vacated. The office proper will make an excellent day school with very few changes. Another day school is badly needed, and I am writing to Col. Neary, sending you a copy, explaining the local situation in this respect.

To house the teacher of this school, the cottage, now occupied by the clerk and immediately across the road from the office, could be used. The warehouse, which is at the rear of the office, must be retained and it will only require a new entrance to definitely separate it from the school.

The Superintendent's house would be turned over to the Assistant Indian Agency, Mr. Callihoo. The house, which he is now occupying, is the property of the Stoney Plain Band of Indians, and it is believed that the Health & Welfare Department might make some arrangements with the Band to use it for a nursing station, if the Band do not wish to make use of it in some other manner.

You will, therefore, understand, Mr. Pratt, in moving from Winterburn to Edmonton there is no wastage, and in fact there would be a distinct saving in capital outlay.

I would be glad to hear from you.

Yours truly,

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Stony Plain Indian Day School.

One of the first new day schools constructed in the Province of Alberta was on the Stony Plain Reserve. So successful is this school that we are now forced to add a second classroom.

Next year there will be fifty-seven children enrolled in the school. We are fortunate in having secured the former agency office and clerk's residence for school purposes in order to accommodate these additional children. We have been endeavouring to secure tenders for the necessary alterations and installation of extra windows.

The only contractor from whom our Indian Superintendent was able to get a firm bid is the Poole Construction Company of Edmonton. Their tender is in the amount of $1,645.00.

This company has done previous work for the Department in erecting day schools on both the Stony Plain and Michel Reserves. Their tender is fair and reasonable, and I would recommend it for your approval.

Acting Director.

Engel.

October 7, 1949.

Subject: New Furnace - Stony Plain Ind. Day School #2

We are enclosing a copy of our wire to Col. B. F. Kearny requesting authority as soon as possible to purchase a new furnace for the Stony Plain Indian Day School #2 at a cost of approximately $200.00.

We have been having considerable trouble with this furnace and before Mr. Robertson left for the North Country he instructed Keeler's Sheet Metal and Vacuum Service to inspect the furnace and make any minor repairs that were necessary. Mr. Keeler inspected the furnace today and immediately phoned this office to say that in his opinion, the furnace was completely worn out and no repair would be involved. Mr. Keeler is considered to be a very reliable furnace expert and it was felt that in this case his advice should be followed.

As it is too cold to operate the school at this time of year without heat the children have been released until the middle of next week when it is hoped that authority will have been received and the new furnace installed.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 31 July 1947.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated 16th July, 1947, from the Acting Minister of Mines and Resources representing:

That it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1947-48 Estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to Construct a combined one room Indian Day School and Teachers residence on the Stony Plain Reserve, Edmonton Indian Agency in the Province of Alberta;

That it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Stony Plain Reserve and living quarters for the Indian day school teacher:

That Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C.1927, provides, in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest...";

That efforts have been made to interest builders and contractors in the City of Edmonton and local towns near the said Reserve but the builders and contractors have advised that they would not be interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

That a competent building contractor, namely the Poole Construction Company, Edmonton, whom our officials state are a very reliable firm, has agreed to undertake the construction of the said building immediately, on the basis of cost plus ten percent;

That it is considered that the construction of this building is a pressing emergency and within the exemption provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Acting Minister of Mines and Resources advise that authority be granted for entry into a contract with The Poole Construction Company as aforesaid.

A.D.P. HENRY,

EXCAVATION, DRAINAGE, BACKFILL AND GRADING

WORK INCLUDED

The work under this heading shall include all excavation for basement, piers, footings, foundations, catch basin, tile drainage lines, and backfilling for same.

It shall also include cutting away existing banks, prominences etc., to produce graded and terraced areas in the vicinity of the building as required, and fill to produce levels called for on the drawings where finished grade levels are to be higher than existing levels.

It shall further include replacement of top soil as specified herein after grading to lines and levels as shown on the working drawings or as may be directed by the engineer, has been carried out.

TOP SOIL

From the area around the building, which is to be graded, remove top soil to a depth of 6" and deposit where and as directed by the engineer.

EXCAVATION

Excavation for all purposes shall conform to the shapes and shall be carried to the levels shown on the working drawings. The sides of all excavations for building shall be sufficiently clear of the outside face of basement or foundation walls to permit erection and stripping of forms and the application of waterproofing, and the laying of weeping tile drains.

Other footing excavations may be cut the next size of the footings where soil conditions permit; otherwise the excavation shall be large enough to accommodate the necessary forms.

All footings and foundations shall rest on solid undisturbed soil beds, which shall be at approximately true level.

Where excavations for walls, piers or footings have been carried, by accident or design, to greater depths than intended, they shall be filled to the required level with concrete, as specified under Concrete Work.

All excavations shall be protected from damage by frost, accident or other cause, and shall be kept dry and free from refuse.

The contractor shall keep all excavations and basements free of water from any source whatsoever, and shall supply all pumps and labour required for the purpose.

All excavated material not required for backfill or for grading shall be moved to another portion of the site, as directed by the Engineer.

ROCK EXCAVATION

Any rock encountered in excavating shall be removed by drilling and wedging if possible. If blasting must be resorted to, it shall be done by experienced men, and all precautions shall be taken to ensure the safety of all persons, and to prevent damage to property.

All rough, slopping, loose or soft rock in the bottom of excavations shall be cut away leaving solid beds, and all rock projections on sides of any excavation shall be cut away so that clear space equal to other excavating previously specified is available.
Loose large boulders, which are visible or which may be encountered in excavating, are to be removed by the most convenient method either from the site or to other positions therein, as directed by the Engineer.

**SHORING**

Supply and place all shoring that may be required to shore up and securely hold all banks or sides of excavations. Maintain and finally dismantle and remove it when work is completed.

**BACKFILLING AT BUILDINGS**

After waterproofing has been completed in accordance with the waterproofing specification and when so directed by the Engineer, fill in against the outside face of the basement walls of the building with at least 6" of broken stone carefully placed and compacted so that weepers will not be disturbed or damaged. Over the broken stone, but to within 6" of finished grade, fill with well compacted soil. This fill to be well tamped, moistened and consolidated in layers to prevent settlement.

Backfill where necessary in basement around piers, footings and underfloor drainage lines, with excavated material as required to form level bed. Fill to be thoroughly tamped and consolidated to prevent settlement. To the top of footings over this bed spread broken stone as shown on working drawings to form base for concrete floor slab. Stone to be carefully placed and compacted to avoid injury to under-floor drainage lines.

**DRAINAGE**

Trenches

Trenches for drainage lines from building as specified for the accommodation of vitrified tile piping shall provide gradients as indicated on drainage details or specified under Plumbing and Drainage. Trenches shall be wide enough to permit workmen to operate.

**LAYING TILE**

Lay a drain of 4" agricultural weeping tile cemented around basement foundation walls at proper gradients from bottom of footings as shown on drawings. If the site requires it, upon instructions of the Engineer, run branch lines 6' 0" long running through footing or walls and under basement floor slab where indicated. Where each of these branches passes through footings or walls it shall consist of a section of 4" cast iron pipe of the same length as the width of footing or wall. Care shall be taken that concrete is thoroughly tamped around this cast iron pipe.

Weeping tile shall be laid with 1/8" open joints protected with tar paper strips 6" wide and then covered with not less than 12" of broken stone and gravel, before backfill is placed.

**CONNECT DRAINS TO CATCH BASIN**

Carry all tile drains from foundation footings and basement floor drains and connect to catch basin (see Concrete Specification) in position shown or where directed by the Engineer.
VITRIFIED TILES

Lay an efficient drain of 6" vitrified salt glazed earthenware pipe from each basin to discharge by gravity flow above grade. If the extent of this drain is not indicated, the contractor shall include in his tender price an amount for installing same to any point selected by the Engineer, within 100' O" of the building.

Lay 4" similar tile drain, or drains if shown, from each basin to the proper positions at basement footings and connect same to cast iron basement floor drains.

During laying, each section of vitrified tile shall be solidly supported above bottom of trench and socket-jointed with cement mortar. After jointing, solid beds of soil shall be well packed under pipes.

CAST IRON DRAINS

Run a 4" cast iron pipe drain, or drains if shown, under basement floor from floor drains and any plumbing fixtures to outside of foundation walls under footings and connect to the vitrified tile drains, specified above, running to catch basin.

Provide and install all required N.C., bands, etc., and a G.I. trap and floor strainer to each basement floor outlet.

BACK FILLING

Back filling over all tile and iron drains shall be carefully executed with approved material in a manner to avoid disturbing pipes.

GRADING

Upon completion of the building, carefully clean up all debris, material, rubbish, etc., from the areas disturbed by building operations and grade up for a distance of 12 feet around the building to levels and lines shown on the various working drawings to the satisfaction of the Engineer.

Where terracing is required, the fill is to be thoroughly rammed and consolidated to prevent settlement.

When all grading has been completed, all graded surfaces and areas used to be covered with topsoil previously removed.

(b) The supply and placing of all bolts, dowels, anchors, pipes, sleeves and miscellaneous ironwork wherever required in concrete work.

(c) The furnishing and placing of reinforcing rods in basement walls and of wire mesh in basement floor slab.

(d) The finish of all cement floors.

(e) The forming, making and installation of precast lintels and thresholds.

(f) The patching of air holes and rubbing down all irregularities in exposed concrete.

For labour and material in foundation formwork see Carpentry Specification.

EXTRA WORK

WATER SUPPLY

The contractor shall arrange for an adequate supply of fresh water to his concrete mixer and for any other building purpose.

Water shall be clean and free from injurious amounts of oil, acid, alkali, organic matter or other deleterious substances.

CEMENT

Cement shall conform to the "Standard Specification for Portland Cement", A.S. - 1940 of the Canadian Engineering Standards Association and subsequent revisions thereof. Aggregates shall conform to the "Standard Specification for Concrete and Reinforced Concrete", A.S. - 1940 of the Canadian Engineering Standards Association and subsequent revisions thereof.

AGGREGATES

Aggregate shall consist of natural sand and gravel, crushed rock or other clean, inert minerals, free from alkali, organic matter or other deleterious substances.
Fine aggregate shall be sand, preferably water-washed, and shall range in size from fine to coarse within the percentages by weight as specified hereafter for ordinary watertight concretes.

ORDINARY CONCRETE

Concrete used in the basement walls of the building, the basement floor slabs and in piers, steps and all footings shall be ordinary concrete as hereunder described.

AGGREGATES

Fine aggregates shall range in size fine to coarse within the following percentages by weight:

Passing 3/8" sieve 100 per cent.
- No. 4 " 94-100 "
- 0.10 " 45-70 "
- 0.50 " 5-30 "
- 0.100 " 0-5 "

Volume removed by sedimentation not more than 3 per cent.

Coarse aggregate shall consist of crushed stone or gravel, graded within the following percentages by weight:

Passing a 1-inch sieve 90-100 per cent.
- 3/4 " 37-70 "
- 2/3 " 10-30 "
- No. 4 " 0-5 "

PROPORTIONS

The proportions of cement, fine and coarse aggregate measured dry and water for all ordinary concrete shall be as follows:

One (1) part cement.
One and one-half (1½) parts fine aggregate.
Three (3) parts coarse aggregate (1" nominal size) and not more than five and one-tenth (5-1/10) gallons of water per sack of cement.

Note: This mixture shall have a strength in compression at 28 days of at least 2,500 lbs. per square inch.

WATERTIGHT CONCRETE

In Basement Walls of Building

All concrete in basement walls of the building above the footings shall be of watertight density using the following approximate quantities:

The sum of separate volumes of fine and coarse aggregates shall be 3-3/4 cubic feet, measured dry, per sack of cement, using not more than 4.1 gals. of water, including surplus water contained in the aggregates. The volume of coarse aggregate shall not be less than the volume of fine aggregate and not more than twice the volume of fine aggregate.

Fine aggregate should have from 10 to 20 per cent of particles passing a 50 mesh sieve and coarse aggregate made
up of particles graded from 1/4 inch up to not more than 1 inch. Coarse aggregate should be of a non-porous character.

The concrete should be of plastic consistency which can be placed without segregation of materials. In consolidating the concrete no excess water should rise to the surface.

In proportioning the aggregates, the contractor should make trial batches with the materials to be used, measuring the materials accurately and making due allowance for moisture, adjusting the proportions until suitable workability is secured. Special care shall be exercised to ensure that the concrete does not dry out during the curing period.

This concrete is designed to have a compressive strength of 3,000 lbs after 28 days.

**STORAGE OF MATERIALS**

Cement shall be stored in a weather tight building, the floor of which shall be raised above the ground to ensure dryness. When required by the Engineer, the cement shall be stored in such a manner as to permit ready identification of the various lots for test purposes.

Aggregates shall be delivered and stored separately. Storage shall be such as will avoid the inclusion of foreign materials.

**UNITS OF MEASUREMENT**

Units of measurement for all concrete shall be:

Water shall be the Imperial gallon, and for purposes of this specification 10 lbs. of water shall be taken as the equivalent of one Imperial gallon.

Cement shall be the cubic foot and for purposes of this specification, the Canadian sack of cement, weighing 97 lbs. gross, shall be regarded as the equivalent of 0.9 cubic foot.

**MEASUREMENT OF AGGREGATES**

The aggregate shall be measured by volume or by weight, as may be directed by the Engineer. The method of measurement used shall be such as to secure the specified proportions in each batch, due allowance being made for free moisture and bulkage effect.

**MEASUREMENT OF WATER**

The water shall be measured by a device such that the quantity of water in each batch can be regulated to give concrete of uniform consistency in successive batches, due allowance being made for free moisture in the aggregate.

**AGGREGATE MOISTURE**

When tests for moisture in the aggregate cannot be made, approximate values may be based upon the following:

- Very wet sand: 0/4 gal. per cu. ft.
- Moderately wet sand: 1/2 gal. per cu. ft.
- Moist sand about 1/4 gal. per cu. ft.
- Moist gravel or crushed rock about 1/8 to 1/4 gal. per cu. ft.
