MIXING

Concrete shall be mixed in an approved type batch mixer of capacity commensurate with the volume of work to be carried out. It shall be mixed to such a consistency that it will flow when diluted, but will not be so wet that the materials will separate in handling.

The ingredients shall be accurately measured for each batch and mixed as follows:

1. Mix cement and fine aggregate.
2. Add coarse aggregate.
3. Add water.

The mixing of each batch shall continue not less than two (2) minutes after all ingredients are in the mixer, during which time the mixer shall rotate at a speed of from 14 to 20 revolutions per minute, unless otherwise rated by the manufacturer and approved by the Engineer.

NO RE-TEMPERING

The re-temping of concrete or mortar which has partially hardened, that is, remaining with or without additional cement, aggregate or water, will not be permitted.

DEPOSITING CONCRETE

Concrete shall be deposited in forms as rapidly as possible to avoid rehandling. It shall be thoroughly compacted with suitable tools and by approved means to eliminate all air bubbles and to prevent honeycombing. Pouring shall be continuous until the unit of operation, as approved by the Engineer, is complete.

Concrete in footings of basement walls shall be completed in one operation and brought to a smooth, level surface to receive membrane waterproofing in damp-proof course hereafter specified.

Under no circumstances shall concrete be removed from forms and deposited elsewhere in the work, nor shall any concrete which has partially hardened, be deposited in the forms.

JOINING

On recommencing the pouring of concrete after previous work has partially set, the surface of the hardened concrete shall be saturated with water and sprinkled with dry cement and the superimposed concrete shall be deposited in such a manner as will ensure an excess of mortar over the entire surface of the joint and a complete and satisfactory bond.

CONCRETE WALLS

Concrete foundation walls and footings shall be of full thickness and depths shown on working drawings of the building. Footings shall be laid on a solid foundation of undisturbed soil. Wherever soil has been removed below the required depth, the excavation shall be filled with concrete as before specified resting upon a solid bottom, without extra expense to the Department.
GREEN CONCRETE

Green concrete shall not be subjected to any heavy blows or strains during the progress of the work. No wheeling or handling of concrete on partly set concrete will be permitted.

ANCHOR BOLTS

Set 2" x 13" bolts as shown on typical wall section details, with nuts and washers, to anchor the main sills of external frame walls to the concrete foundation walls. Bolts to be spaced not more than 4 feet apart. The top of the concrete walls shall be floated to a true and level finish to receive the sills of the frame walls.

SET SLEEVES ETC., IN PLACE

The contractor shall set in place as required, before the concrete is poured, all pipe sleeves, anchors and miscellaneous ironwork.

BASEMENT FLOOR FOUNDATIONS

On a solid bottom lay a bed of broken stone and gravel 6" thick to form a foundation for the basement floor slab of each building. This bed shall be well tamped and consolidated, and brought to such levels as will conform to the gradients required to drain the finished cement floors to the floor drains where indicated on the basement plans.

FLOOR SLABS

Over the broken stone floor foundations above specified, lay a slab of ordinary concrete of the thickness shown on the working drawings. The slab shall be graded to the requisite levels to drain the finished floors and shall be floated to an even surface ready to receive cement finish. Reinforce the basement floor slab with 6" x 6" - 8' x 5' wire mesh, placed 2" above bottom of slab.

CEMENT FLOOR FINISH

When the floor slab has hardened, but before it has thoroughly dried out, the frame partitions should be set in place as described under Carpentry work, and there shall be applied a floor finish of cement, one inch thick, consisting of 1 part cement, 1 part well graded sand and from 1/2 to 2 parts of pea gravel, or crushed stone, graded from 1/8 to 3/8 inches. It shall be of the driest possible consistency, possible to work with a sawing motion of the straight edge. The addition of fine aggregate, or water, to give workability will not be permitted.

After placing the concrete, it shall be spread to the correct slope and compacted with a wooden float, as soon as possible after spreading. Floating shall not be continued more than is necessary to bring the minimum amount of mortar to the surfaces for finishing. When concrete has hardened sufficiently to withstand the moderate pressure of the thumb without leaving a depression, it shall be trowelled to a smooth and even surface. Over trowelling shall be avoided and no drip shall be used.
CONCRETE FINISH

After removal of the forms, any air holes or voids remaining in exposed concrete walls, piers, etc., shall be filled with cement mortar mixed in the proportions of 1 cement to 2 sand, and all rough surfaces rubbed down so that the concrete presents a smooth and even surface to the satisfaction of the Engineer. An excessive number of air holes and voids shall be sufficient reason for rejection of the concrete by the Engineer. All exposed concrete surfaces within the basement are to be finished to receive paint as specified hereafter.

THRESHOLDS

Form the thresholds of the grade entrances in precast concrete, with lugs and wash, in accordance with detail drawing. Concrete to be mixed in the proportion specified for watertight concrete. The exposed surfaces of the thresholds shall be rubbed with carbondium stone or wire brush until all irregularities are removed; the finished surfaces then to be thoroughly moistened and a coat of cement grout, brushed on.

GRADE ENTRANCE STEPS

Form a step to the grade entrances of the building of the dimensions shown, or ordinary concrete reinforced with 6" x 6" wire mesh and resting on a bed of broken stone, at least 12 inches thick, well consolidated down to a solid bottom.

DAMP-PROOF COURSE

Between the top of concrete footings and concrete basement walls, a damp proof course shall be formed consisting of layers of 12 lb. asphalt saturated felt mopped in place and on top with hot coal tar pitch the width of the footings to form a capillary stop.

MATAPOICILIC

The entire exterior surface of all concrete foundation walls below the finished grade line and the exterior top of footings of the building shall be given a coat of hot coal tar pitch well brushed in and of sufficient weight to render the walls thoroughly water-proof. In the angle formed by the foundation walls and footings on exterior side, mop on a strip of tarred 10 pound building felt 12" wide.

MASTIC JOINTS

At the junctions of basement floor slabs and vertical concrete surfaces form joints with an approved mastic compound.

REINFORCEMENT

All steel used as concrete reinforcement shall comply with the requirements of the C.E.S.A. Standard Specifications for intermediate grade steel, having an ultimate strength of 40,000 lbs per sq.in.

Reinforcing steel shall be clean and free from rust and coatings. It shall be accurately placed and secured against displacement by annealed wire ties or suitable clips at intersections.

FOUNDATION WALLS

The foundation walls of the building shall be reinforced with two 2-5/8" diameter rods placed at the top and at the
bottom and looped 2 feet at corners.

**INTERIOR CONCRETE WALLS**

The 3 inch interior concrete walls shall be reinforced with 1-1/8" diameter rod placed at the top and at the bottom and bent 2 feet into adjoining concrete walls.

**BASEMENT WINDOWS**

Reinforce the walls around the basement window openings and all doors with two 4/8" diameter rods set vertically and horizontally 2" from the faces of the jambs and of the walls, as shown on detail drawings.

All reinforcing steel when in position shall be approved by the engineer in charge before proceeding with concrete work.

**CONCRETE CATCH BASIN**

Construct catch basin of ordinary concrete as previously specified to size shown on plan. Location and depth of catch basin to be determined by Engineer in charge of the work.
BRICKWORK

WORK INCLUDED

The work under this heading shall include the erection of flues and chimneys in the building in the position and of dimensions shown on the working drawings; and the setting and building in cleanout doors and frames, smoke pipe, thimbles, etc., as may be required.

CHIMNEYS

From the level of the concrete chimney foundations, 2'-6" above the basement floor of the building, carry up the chimneys to a height of not less than 3'-0" above the ridge line of the building, as shown on elevations.

The chimneys where passing through the building shall be carried up in good quality well-burned common brick, laid 4 courses, including 4 joints, to measure 12". The flues from furnaces shall be provided with rectangular vitrified flue linings of the sizes shown on plans, carried up from the smoke pipe inlet to the cap of the chimney stack. Both flues of single classroom school to be so lined.

MORTAR

Mortar for all brickwork shall be composed of one part of Portland cement and three parts clean sharp sand to which may be added hydrated lime to the extent of 10 per cent by volume of the quantity of cement used.

JOINTS

All brickwork, whether exposed or concealed, shall be well bedded and with joints flushed full of mortar.

FACE BRICK

The exterior brickwork in chimney stack shall be carried up in a good grade of hard burned red face brick with weathered joints, coursed as described for common brick. Form caps to the chimney stacks as shown on elevations with precast concrete cap.

MISCELLANEOUS IRONWORK

Set and build into place all miscellaneous ironware, hereafter specified and as required, in the positions in brickwork as shown on the working drawings.

FLASHINGS

Prepare brickwork to receive metal flashings as indicated on working drawings and as specified under roofing and Flashings.

All joints in brickwork to receive metal flashings are to be raked out to a depth of 1/2" and left clear for the insertion of flashing.

COMPLETION

Upon completion of the work the face brickwork shall be thoroughly cleaned down with stiff brushes and clean water.
CARPENTRY AND MILLWORK

WORK INCLUDED

The work under this heading shall cover the furnishing of material and labor for all rough and finishing carpentry in the buildings and outside privies specified herein, indicated on the drawings, or as may be necessary for the proper completion of the work. The general extent of the work is as follows:

(a) Setting out the work and providing all necessary shores, scaffolding, templates, backs, blocks, nailing strips, turving, grounds, etcetera.

(b) The erection and removal of temporary privy, mixing platforms and concrete formwork, etcetera; also offices and storage buildings as necessary for construction work.

(c) Framing all walls, floors, roofs, inside partitions, landings, beams, sub-floors, boarding and sheathing, including cutting for and making good after the work of all other trades as necessary.

(d) Application of asphalt felt to exterior walls and sloping roofs, bavelled siding to exterior walls and wood shingles to roofs or alternatively. The application of asbestos siding shingles to exterior walls and of asphalt shingles to roofs.

(e) Insulating frame walls and ceilings.

(f) Installing and caulking door and window frames. Installing sash, storm sash, storm doors, louvres, etcetera.

(g) Constructing and applying exterior finish for entrances, platforms, steps, and fitting and applying exterior casing for door, window and louver openings; also corner boards, water tables, skirting boards, etc.,

(h) Installing all gypsum wall board and insulation board, strapping and interior finish to walls, ceilings and partitions.

(i) Installing all interior finish and millwork, fitting and hanging doors; installing kitchen dresser, shelving, door and window trim, baseboards, shoe strips, jamb linings, clothes closet fittings, etc.

(j) Installing all finished floors and staircases.

(k) Supplying, fitting and installing all rough and finishing hardware.

MATERIALS

All lumber and timber used in the buildings shall be square edged to size, well seasoned and dry. It shall be free from sap, shakes, warp edges, cracks, loose or dead knots and any defect that would impair its strength or durability.

Framing timbers generally shall be of merchantable spruce of S.C. Douglas fir, in Eastern areas, of equivalent grading.
All exterior woodwork where exposed to view or to the weather shall be of pine or Douglas fir, dressed for painters' finish.

**FORMWORK**

All foundation formwork shall be of merchantable grade spruce or hemlock; shipped to be cut of 1" x 3" and framing timbers 2" x 4" S. 15, 1E.

All formwork shall be set plumb and level and strongly wired to prevent bulging. Set in place cast iron sleeves of suitable size for all pipes passing through the concrete walls.

All shiplap boarding shall be closely jointed and the inside faces coated with non-staining mineral oil or other approved liquid before concrete is deposited, to give a smooth even finish to the concrete surface.

**FRAMING TIMBERS**

Framing material shall be piled in such a manner that drainage and ventilation is assured, while awaiting use.

All framing and structural timbers shall be erected in the strongest manner in accordance with the working drawings and following the best practice. All studding and joists to be set plumb and level, braced or bridged as necessary, and strongly nailed or spiked together.

Framing members shall be dressed at sawmill. The sizes named are nominal.

**MAIN WALL SILLS**

Provide and set in place main wall sills to carry first floor joists and exterior frame walls as shown on typical wall section. Sills to be anchored to corner walls with anchor bolts at intervals of sills and spaced not more than 6 feet apart.

**STUDDING**

The studding of all exterior walls shall be framed up with 2" x 4" studs from the main sills, excepting over basement windows where it shall be supported by lintels of the depth of the joints. Studs to be spaced 16 inches on centers and doubled round door and window openings. Over the school classroom windows frame the studding with diagonal bracing from the mullion studs to the wallplates. Check in a 1" x 6" ribbon board where required and set two rows of 2" x 4" stringers to classroom walls and one row to the walls of teachers quarters. Wall plates to be 2" x 4" doubled. Partitions, unless otherwise described, to be framed with 2" x 4" sills, 2" x 4" studs 16 inches on centers, and 2" x 4" headers, doubled for bearing partitions and with stringing as described for exterior walls. Frame partitions in basements shall be carried up from the cement floors to the underside of the first floor joists with 2" x 4" sills, studs and caps. Partitions to be set in place before finishing coat of cement floor is towelled under the sill, and are to be anchored in position with 8" spikes and well nailed to joists overhead.

**FLOOR JOISTS**

Joists are to be doubled where they carry partitions running in the same direction, and trimming joists for staircase,
chimney, etcetera, will also be doubled as necessary.

Generally all joints will be set not more than 16 inches on centres. Where a variation is necessary, the spacing is to be reduced. Set joists of the dimensions shown on drawings 16 inches on centres for all floors and landings throughout the building.

CROSS BRIDGING

Set rows of 1" x 1" cross bridging not more than 2 feet apart between the joists of all floors uniformly spaced and in line.

CEILING JOISTS

Ceiling joists of the sizes shown to be set 16 inches on centres spiked to the sides of rafters. Trim ceiling joints as required for vent over Classroom and for chimney, etcetera.

BASEMENT POSTS

Set in place where shown in the basement 8" x 8" wood posts 3.4.S. with 2" chamfered corners. Posts to be anchored at bottom to concrete footings with iron dovels and to be well spiked to beams at top.

RAFTERS

All rafters to be accurately cut, set true in line and securely spiked or nailed to wall plates, ridge boards and other supports.

Rafters of the main roof shall be 2" x 6" 16 inches on centres. Those over the Classroom to be trussed as shown, with braces and vertical pieces well spiked to support ceiling joists.

Rafters at overhang of eaves shall be 3.4.S., spaced at feet and notched over wall plate, securely nailed to side of each main roof rafter. Roof boarding at overhanging eaves to be T. & G. V-joint, as shown on typical wall section detail.

Set in place at intersection of main roofs of two Classroom School buildings, valley rafters of dimensions shown, built up of 2" material well spiked together.

SHIPLAP SHEATHING

Line both sides of the exterior frame walls throughout the building and the inner side of the dwarf walls to the second storey of the Teacher's quarters in the one Classroom building with shiplap sheathing cut of 1" x 6" material.

The exterior sheathing to the building is to be laid diagonally.

Line both sides of the stud partitions in the basement fuel and furnace rooms and of first floor stud partitions which enclose Classroom and Coat rooms, also one side of stud partitions enclosing public stairways with similar shiplap sheathing.

Cover the whole of the sloping rafters of the building, with similar shiplap sheathing.
SUB-FLOORS

Lay a sub-floor of 1" x 8" ship-lap sheathing upon the first and second floor joists and the staircase landings of building as required to receive finished floors. Ship-lap for sub-floors to be laid diagonally.

WAXED KRAFT PAPER

Over the sub-floors of the building, before laying finished floors, apply one thickness of medium weight waxed kraft waterproof paper well lapped at joints and edges.

SADDLES

Form saddles behind chimneys as required to receive flashing.

BUILDING FELT

All exterior boarding to roof slopes and walls shall be covered with one layer of asphalt impregnated building felt. Felt used on roofs to weigh 15 lbs. per square, and on walls 12 lbs. per square. All felt to be well lapped at joints and edges and where used on walls to be carried behind all door and window casings, corner boards, etcetera.

ASBESTOS SIDING SHINGLES

Cover the whole of the exterior wall surfaces of the building where shown on the drawings, over the asphalt felt previously specified, with ground asbestos siding shingles, oyster grey in colour, size 12" x 24" laid with 3" exposure. Shingles are to be laid to butt tightly against the corner boards and exterior casings of doors and windows and to be cut to fit the edges of verges and elsewhere and nailed in accordance with the manufacturers' directions.

ALTERNATIVE WOOD SIDING

The contractor shall submit an alternative price for covering the exterior wall surfaces where shown on drawings with 1" x 8" bevelled or drop siding of B.C. Douglas fir or pine, accurately cut and closely jointed. Place the wood siding but 1" x 10" skirting, weathered and treated as shown on typical wall section.

MINERAL WOOL INSULATION

Furnish and install mineral wool insulation in waterproof paper backed batts, not loose, as required, to completely insulate the outside walls and upper cellars of the building as noted on the drawings or hereafter specified, and placed in accordance with the manufacturer's printed instructions.

The insulation shall be installed against the back of ship-lap in all exterior frame walls from top of foundation walls to roof in order to provide a continuous blanket of insulation surrounding the occupied portions of the building.

Install mineral wool insulation between horizontal ceiling joists above occupied areas and between rafters where sloping ceilings occur, with the waterproof backing on the lower side, between studs, up to ceiling insulation in gable ends.
and in dwarf walls of Teacher's Quarters in One Classroom building.

Use batts in stud walls the full thickness of the studs (3-3/4") and between rafters and ceiling joints where so required use batts of similar thickness. Also have use the granulated form to fill completely all voids in the spaces to be insulated.

**SOUNDPROOF INSULATION AND STRAPPING**

Line the underside of the first floor joists over the workshop, manual training and sewing rooms in the basement of the building with 1" thick sound insulating wallboard, "Ten-tact" or equal, in sheets size 3 ft. by 4 ft., where electric wiring is installed set in place 1" x 2" strapping at 16 inch centres below the first floor joists to conform to the requirements of such installation and to receive the ceiling board.

**FIREPROOF INSULATING BOARD**

Line the underside of the first floor joists over the furnace (or boiler) and fuel rooms in the basement of the building with similar 1" thick, sound insulating wallboard laid at right angles to same, line the ceilings with asbestos fire proof insulating board 1/4" thick in sheets size 6 ft. by 4 ft. laid with close joints. No strapping is to be applied to these ceilings.

**CAULKING**

Carefully caulk around all window and door frames, and wherever else necessary to fill voids and cracks in exterior insulated walls, with oakum tightly packed in from the inner side.

**GYPSUM WALLBOARD**

Cover the interior surfaces of ship lap on exterior frame walls, both sides of all stud partitions from the finished floors to the ceiling joists, and the undersides of floor and ceiling joists throughout the building, except as otherwise specified, with gypsum wallboard 3/8" thick in sheets 48 inches wide with all edges bevelled. Joists to be taped and filled with plaster joint filler to form smooth unbroken wall and ceiling surfaces for painters' finish. Internal and external angles shall be neatly taped and filled with plaster joint filler. Taping and jointing shall be carried out in strict accordance with manufacturers' directions.

Similarly line the strapping previously specified to the ceilings of the Workshop, Manual Training and Sewing Rooms in the basement, with gypsum wallboard.

Omit gypsum wallboard within the fuel boiler and store room of the building.

**WALLWORK**

All mouldings and trim used throughout the building to be of stock sizes and pattern, following as closely as possible dimensions and profiles shown on detail drawings, and to the approval of the Engineer.

**EXTERIOR FINISHED WOODWORK AND TRIM**

All doors and windows and their trim, and all exterior moulded woodwork in entrances, cornices, etcetera, shall be of selected factory grade pine or B.C. Douglas Fir S.A.S. sanded for...
painters' finish. All other exterior woodwork where exposed to view is to be of 'S. I Common Pine or Fir of equivalent grading S-4S.

CASINGS AND ARCHITRAVES

Set 1-1/8" x 3-3/4" casings around all windows and louvre openings and casings of similar thickness to suit width of millions; also 1-1/8" x 3-3/4" casings around the entrance doors in frame walls of the single classroom building. Architraves around entrance doors of two classroom building to be moulded 5-3/4" wide, including back bands, as shown on detail drawing.

CORNER BOARDS

Set in place corner boards out of 1" x 4" at the external angles of the building to stop the wood siding or asbestos siding shingles.

ENTRANCE DOOR PEDIMENTS

Construct the pediments over the entrance doors of the two classroom building in accordance with detail drawings, using stock mouldings as nearly as possible similar in profile and dimensions to those shown on the drawings.

OPEN EAVES

Under the open eaves of the building set a fascia board out of 1" x 6" rebated at lower edge to receive siding shingles. The fascia shall be accurately cut and fitted between the rafters, and a bed mould set in the angle of roof and wall as shown on detail drawing.

DOOR AND WINDOW FRAMES

All door and window frames and exterior frame walls shall be of a width equal to the thickness of the wall from the face of the finished inner wall surface to the face of the outside shiplap sheathing.

DOOR FRAMES

The door frames of the main entrances shall be of 2" B.C. Douglas Fir or pine, single rebated for 1-3/4" door opening outwards.

The entrance door frames of two classroom building where abutting concrete walls shall be strongly nailed to wood backs set in the walls as shown on detail drawing.

Door frames set in frame walls should have hardwood sills, weathered on upper surface and grooved and throated below.

WINDOW FRAMES

All double-hung and casement window frames shall be as shown on detail drawings. The frames for double-hung windows in the frame walls shall have 1-1/8" jambs and heads tongued into blind stops, complete with parting strips and stops to receive sash as hereafter described. Millions for double-hung windows shall have jambs tongued into blind stops of the widths shown.
The sills shall be pitched to weather, throated for drip and grooved to receive exterior shiplap.

Frames of double-hung windows in concrete walls shall have sills shaped as shown and with water bar below.

Casing window frames in frame walls shall have double rebated jambs and heads out of 2" material, and where mullions occur they shall be 2" thick. They shall have sills, pitched to weather, fitted with iron water bar, throated for drip and grooved to receive outside shiplap and on inner edge for stool.

The frames of casement windows in concrete walls shall be cut of 2" x 6" material; sills to be weathered and grooved on top and below to receive water bars.

LOUVRES.

Construct louvres in the gable ends of the building with jamb linings, sill, slats, casings and No. 13 mesh galvanized fly screen in accordance with detail drawings.

DOORWAY TO ROOF SPACE

Frame for access to roof space where shown and set in place double rebated door frame. Provide and hang T. & G. batten door on each side fitted with hook and eye latches.

CEILING VENTS

Form ventilators in the ceilings of the classrooms with wire mesh grilles, size about 18" x 24" and hinged bottom shutters above. Vent grilles to be of No. 11 woven galvanized wire, 1" square mesh, all in accordance with detail drawings. Vents to be controlled from classroom walls by small louver pullays and cleats.

WINDOW SASH

All windows, except where otherwise shown on the elevations, shall have double-hung sash, those in the classrooms to be 1-3/4" thick, and those elsewhere 1-5/8" thick.

All muntin bars shall have clean cut mouldings and shall be set straight and true.

All double-hung windows shall be fitted with spiral spring balances of approved type and make, neatly fitted into grooves formed in the sash, and attached to window frames in accordance with the manufacturers' directions.

Casement windows in all frame and concrete walls shall have sash 1-3/8" thick with bottom rails rebated to open inwards, and a suitable moulded drip set at the lower edge of the bottom rail.

STORM SASH

Furnish and fit storm sash 1-3/8" thick to all windows; those to double-hung windows to be rebated as required by blind stops. Storm sash of casement windows in concrete and in frame walls shall be fitted in the outer rabbet of the frame.
Sash shall be divided into lights to match the permanent sash and shall be fitted with ventilator slots and covers.

SCREENS

Furnish and fit in place to all windows throughout the buildings, strongly and neatly constructed fly screens complete in all respects for painters' finish.

Screens shall be factory made of F.C. Fir or pine 1-1/2" thick with stiles and rails dovetail or tenoned together, and with horizontal main bars in line with meeting rails of double-hung windows. Omit bar in casement window screens. Screens to be fitted with 14 x 14 mesh galvanized wire cloth, tightly and evenly stretched and held in place with cover mould on outer edge. Screens to all windows in frame walls to be set between the exterior casings and to finish flush with same; those to windows in the basement walls of the school to be set in place of storm sash. Attach hooks and eyes as necessary to secure all screens in place.

ENTRANCE PLATFORMS AND STEPS TO ONE CLASSROOM BUILDING

PLATFORM

Construct the entrance platforms to the One Classroom building with 2" x 6" framing joists resting on 6" x 6" posts (anchored to 3" x 6" concrete piers) and grading blocks in the concrete wall. Bridging joists to be 2" x 6" set at 12" centres, and notched to ledger at ends. Lay the floor with 1-1/2" x 6-1/4" F.C. Fir or pine flooring to fall 1" away from building, all tightly jointed, blind nailed and smoothed off ready for painters' finish.

STEPS

Form the steps to entrance platforms as shown on elevations, with 2" x 12" cut and mitred carriages and treads cut out of two 2" x 4"s and a 2" x 5" spaced 1/4" apart with spacing pieces between. Set caps mould under tread nosings returned at ends; risers to be 3/4" thick mitred at corners. Steps to have 2" x 12" intermediate carriage resting on 6" x 6" cedar sill at grade level with broken stone and gravel bed beneath 10" deep.

Construct the railings and balustrades as shown with 4" x 4" posts, 2" x 4" rails and 1-1/2" square balusters.

DOORS

All doors shall be of No. 1 quality F.C. Douglas Fir or White pine of the sizes indicated on plans strongly trimmed and glued together and of the patterns hereunder described.

All interior doors throughout the first floor to be 1-3/4" thick two panelled or of standard slab type. Those to basement and to the second floor of teachers quarters to be two panelled struck moulded doors 1-3/8" thick.

Entrance doors to be three panelled 1-3/4" thick with two vertical panels and inner panel sized as shown with double strength glass set in place with moulded wood beads.

METAL CLAD DOORS

Construct doors to furnace or boiler and fuel room in basement of building of 1" x 3" shiplap, with three 1" x 6" horizontal rails on back. Between horizontal rails cut in
vertical 1" x 6" pieces to reinforce edge of shiplap, and fill panels with shiplap applied diagonally. Trim shiplap to remove tongue or groove at edges of door and where it abuts fills. Fasten the shiplap to fills, and the two thicknesses of shiplap to each other with screws. Cover both sides and all edges of this core with 26 gauge galvanized iron fastened to core in a neat manner without bulges or buckles, and with joints in metal soldered.

**STORM DOORS**

Provide and fit 1-3/8" combination screen and storm doors of approved stock pattern, to the entrances of the teachers' residence in the one classroom school.

**INTERIOR WOODWORK, TRIM AND FITTINGS**

**MATERIALS**

All interior finishing woodwork throughout the building including the basement of the building, unless otherwise specified shall be of selected factory grade F.O. Douglas Fir, pine or equivalent grade of spruce, to the approval of the Engineer, and the two kinds shall not be mixed in similar work.

No trim will be required to windows in boiler, furnace or fuel rooms.

Dimensions used in describing trim are nominal only and slight variation in thickness or width of stock materials will be acceptable.

All finishing woodwork in interior trim to be sanded smooth, free from mill marks, with nail heads countersunk and ready for painters' finish.

**CASINGS**

Set 3/4" x 3/4" bull nose casing, unless otherwise specified, around all doors and windows, ceiling vents and elsewhere as required in the finished portions of the building.

Inside casings to the entrance doors of the building and to the door and window openings throughout the first story of the Teachers' Quarters with the exception of the kitchen, are to be 3/4" x 3-1/2" moulded with 1-1/8" x 1-1/4" moulded back bands planted on.

Trim to all door openings to include base blocks of same height as base boards.

**STOOLS**

Set 1-1/16" x 2-3/4" stool with 3/4" x 3-3/4" bull nose apron and 5/8" x 7/8" cove mould under to double-hung windows in frame walls. The stool to double-hung windows in the basement to be 1-1/8" x 5-3/4" ogee moulded with bull nose apron and 5/8" x 7/8" cove mould.

The stool to casement windows in frame walls shall be 1-1/8" thick ogee moulded and tongued into the sills with 3/4" x 3-3/4" bull nose apron and cove mould under.
BASEBOARDS

Baseboards throughout the building shall be 3/4" x 7-3/4" bull nosed.

All baseboards to be accurately fitted and mitred at angles.

Bases to frame partitions in the basement shall be formed with expanded metal lath strips as described under concrete work and shown on detail drawings.

BLACKBOARDS

Provide and install on the school classroom walls where shown, and in accordance with detail drawings, manufactured asbestos whiteboard "Black Abestolite" or equal, held in place with quarter round mould and casings and provided with chalk rail with apron and cove mould under.

HANGING CLOSET FITTINGS

Set two rows of hook rails out of 1" x 4" material bull nosed, in the school corridors, securely screwed to walls, and attach strong cast iron japanned hit and coat hooks set approximately 18" apart in staggered rows.

In the bedroom closets in the quarters, set similar hook rails on the end walls and a 1-1/4" round hanging rod 2' above the floor, where indicated. Set a 1" shelf 12" wide, 3" above the rods, set on single cast iron cupboard hooks, bronze finish, 6" apart, to the hook rails.

OUTBOARDS WITH SHELVING

Set up shelving out of 1" material supported on 1" x 2" wall bearers in the storage cupboards where indicated. Shelving in the linen closet in the two Classroom Teachers' Quarters shall be formed of 1" x 3" boards set 5/3" apart on similar wall bearers. Set up shelving in the closets and storage rooms where shown in the blueprints of the buildings, strongly supported on 2" x 3" framed bearers to the approval of the Engineer in charge.

STAIRCASES

Construct the staircases from the basement to first and second storeys in accordance with the working drawings, these specifications and detail drawings to be supplied later, following the best stair building practice.

Framing shall be of B.C. Douglas Fir or pine and will include outer intermediate and inner carriage, wall and outer strings, wedges, blocking, etcetera, required for rigid work. Carriages shall be 1-3/4" thick, strings 1-3/8" thick, of depths as shown on details.

Except as otherwise shown or specified, strings shall be of closed string construction with carriages cut to conform to the rise and run of the steps. Wall and outer strings to be grooved to receive risers, treads and tapered wedges. Outer strings shall have a finished and polished top. Strings should be ploughed to receive 1-3/8" square balusters and shaped filler pieces between balusters.
Balusters, string cap, fascia and filler pieces will be R.C. fir for natural finish or of pine for paint finish, as directed.

Treads, with rounded nosings and cove mould under, tongued and grooved for risers, will be 1-1/4" thick. Risers, tongued and grooved for treads, will be 3/4" thick. Treads and risers will be of first grade hard maple. Blocks 2" x 2" x 6" shall be screwed and glued into place midway between carriers at the junction of treads with risers. Built up newels 4-1/4" square with moulded caps and loops will be of birch. "Moulded handrails" 2-1/4" x 2-3/4" grooved to receive balusters, and filler pieces will be of birch.

Furnish and set in place to each flight of stairs in the building where stairs are enclosed between partitions one 2" dia. wall handrail supported on metal brackets.

Set up the balustrades to the landings and halls where shown with handrail and balusters to match those of the stairs and half newels set against partitions. Face the staircase well with 3/4" fascia with nosing to match finished floor and cover mould to ceiling joint.

KITCHEN DRESSER

Construct the kitchen dresser in the residence out of 1" material, with cupboards above and below counter, all in accordance with detail drawing. Counter tops to be covered with "Pasonite" or equal with metal or plastic nosing. Cupboard member below drawers to be 1-1/2" thick, drawer fronts 7/8" and bottoms 3/8" thick.

Provide and fit 7/8" plywood slab type doors to finish flush with stiles and rails of cupboards.

FINISHED FLOORING

Hardwood flooring shall be graded in accordance with Canadian hardwood flooring manufacturers' grading rules and shall be well seasoned, kiln dried, tongued, grooved and end matched.

All finished flooring throughout the school area, including hallways, landings and coat rooms shall be No. 1 or Factory Grade (second grade below "Clear") hard maple 13/16" x 2".

All finished flooring throughout the Teachers' Quarters shall be No. 1 or second grade (first grade below "Clear") hard maple 9/16" x 1-3/4".

All hardwood flooring shall be laid with close joints on the waterproof paper and sub-floors previously specified and blind nailed as follows: 13/16" flooring to be nailed with 2-1/2" cut flooring nails and 9/16" flooring with 2" flooring nails. Nails to be spaced more than 10" apart.

Provide and fix nosings to staircase landings of the thickness of the finished flooring.

SIDE MOULD

Set a 3/4" x 3/4" maple side mould in the angle of finished floors and baseboards where hardwood floors are specified.oulds to be mitred at angles.
FINISHED FLOORING - ALTERNATIVE

If hardwood flooring is not procurable, the contractor shall so state in his tender and shall supply and lay instead throughout the building in accordance with the above specification, as it applied, No. 1 B.C. edge grain Douglas Fir flooring.

OUTSIDE TOILETS

Construct outside toilets where directed on the school site for boys and girls in accordance with the working drawings. Each unit to consist of a small frame building resting on cedar sills.

Materials in superstructure shall be as shown on working drawings. Roof shingles and wall siding shall be similar to those used on main building.

No pits to be excavated, but metal receptacles as indicated on the working drawings are to be provided for use under privy seats and in boys' toilet, metal urinal trough.
MISCELLANEOUS, ROUGH AND FINISHING HARDWARE

ROUGH AND MISCELLANEOUS HARDWARE

MATERIAL INCLUDED

The contractor shall supply and install all rough and structural hardware including nails, spikes, bolts, anchors, clean-out doors and frames to all flues, and thimbles for stove pipe connections to flues, etc., which may be required for the complete erection of the building including the following.

COAL CHUTES

Provide and set in basement fuel room wall a coal chute of "Majestic" type or equal, wall opening size about 21" x 27" cast iron and steel with hopper and automatic door opening and locking device, complete with chain control.

CHIMNEY CLEANOUT DOORS

Furnish for setting and building into place, by bricklayer, hinged cleanout doors with frames to all flues in positions and of sizes shown on the working drawings.

CHIMNEY THIMBLES, COLLARS, ETC

Furnish for setting and building into place by bricklayers as required for each flue, thimbles and smoke pipe collars of sizes and in position to suit furnace and smoke pipes.

THRESHOLDS

Provide and set in place to the entrance doorways of the building a grooved bronze threshold size 4-3/4" x 7/8" made by the Chamberlin Metal Feather Strip Co., Ltd., of Kingsville, Ontario, or equal, securely anchored to the cement thresholds.

FINISHING HARDWARE

MATERIAL INCLUDED

Material under this heading shall include all finishing hardware required throughout the building, whether specified or not, which shall be selected to the approval of the Engineer in charge. Finishing hardware does not include spiral scale balances specified under Carpentry and Millwork. They shall be covered by the contract price.

All finishing hardware shall be attached in a neat and careful manner with screws of suitable kind and finish to match hardware.

Upon completion of the contract, a detailed list of finishing hardware supported by receipted invoices for same shall be submitted to the Department. Any portion of the sum named not expended on finishing hardware shall be deducted from the total contract price.

PROVISIONAL AMOUNTS

The contractor shall include in the amount of his tender for Single Classroom School and residence a sum of
One hundred and Seventy-five Dollars ($175.00) and for Two Classroom School and Residence a sum of two hundred and Seventy Five Dollars ($275.00) to cover the cost of all finishing hardware installed in the respective buildings. Such sum shall include the actual trade cost of material, plus freight charges, but no allowance is included in these amounts for contractor's percentage.
ROOFING AND FLASHING

ASPHALT ROOFING SHINGLES

Cover all sloping roof surfaces on the asphalt felt previously specified, with twin- or 3-in-1 asphalt strip shingles, weight 160 lbs per square. Shingles to be of red colour laid 4-1/2" to weather and to include all necessary starters and hip and ridge shingles.

FLASHING

All roofs of the buildings shall be flashed wherever required to render same thoroughly watertight and weatherproof with No. 26 gauge galvanized sheet iron.

The roof valleys shall have 6" metal exposure at the top, extending to 18" at eaves, with 6" extension under the shingles.

Flash with similar metal above all exterior door and window and louvre heads in frame walls, the watertables around the buildings and elsewhere as may be required.

The cover flashing to chimneys shall be stepped and turned into brick course as determined under "brickwork" and shall be secured in place with lead wedges. Base flashings shall extend under shingles and be turned up against vertical surfaces at least 6 inches. Step flashings shall lap base flashings 4" and shall lap over the adjoining step flashing a minimum of 2" at vertical joints.

Flash above the entrance door pediments and brackets shown on detail drawings, turned up against walls to lap behind the asbestos siding shingles at least 4".

CAULKING

Horizontal brick joints, into which flashing has been wedged, shall be caulked full with an approved asphalt caulking compound upon completion of the flashing work.

GUARANTEE

The contractor shall furnish a written guarantee that he will make good at his own expense any leaks or other defects in the roofs or flashings throughout the buildings, and any damage caused thereby, within a period of one year after acceptance of the buildings by the Department, and no final payment will be made before such document is received.
PAINTING & GLAZING

WORK INCLUDED

The work under this heading shall cover the furnishing of all materials and equipment and the execution of all priming, painting, staining, varnishing or other finishing work on all exterior and interior wood and metal surfaces, as well as interior concrete and wallboard surfaces as specified herein or as may be necessary for a satisfactory job throughout the building.

WORKSHIP

All work shall be carried out by skilled workmen in accordance with the best practice, and no paint or other finish shall be applied under unfavorable conditions, or to any surface which is damp, dirty, greasy, rough or otherwise imperfect. Each coat of finish must be thoroughly dry before succeeding coats are applied.

All nail holes and joints in finishing woodwork shall be filled with putty, coloured to match finish and sanded smooth. Before applying priming coat, whether at the factory or on the job, all knots and sapwood shall be given a coat of best grade orange shellac. All surfaces shall be finished smooth and even, and shall be free from runs, sags, brush marks, bubbles and other defects.

The contractor shall examine all finishing woodwork and other surfaces to receive painters' finish and ensure that it is in proper condition.

MATERIALS

All materials used on the work shall be of first quality standard brands of approved manufacture, delivered to the job in the original sealed containers. They shall be well stirred, thinned where necessary and applied strictly in accordance with manufacturers' directions.

COLOUR SCHEDULES

Schedules of colours for finished paintwork throughout the two buildings will be prepared and furnished by the Department before the paintwork is begun.

EXTERIOR WORK

WOODWORK

All exterior trim and any other exterior wood surfaces exposed to view or to the weather shall be painted three coats of exterior white lead and oil paint. All window sash, storm sash, exterior doors and storm doors shall receive three coats of paint on both sides and all edges.

ENTRANCE PLATFORMS AND STEPS

The entrance platforms and steps thereto in the Single Classroom building shall be primed and painted two coats of bent quality gray floor paint.
First wire over with vinegar all galvanized iron in flashings, etc., then prime with one coat of red lead paint, and finish with two coats of lead and oil paint of colour to match adjacent work.

Other exterior metal work shall be similarly painted three coats to match adjacent work in colour.

Galvanized wire mesh in fly screens will not be painted.

OUTSIDE TOILETS

The exterior and interior exposed woodwork of the outside toilet building shall be given two coats of good quality shingle stain. The colour of the stain will be medium dark brown, except for roof shingles which are to match the red roof shingles on main building.

INTERIOR WORK

SOFTWOOD FINISH

All interior fir trim or spruce trim and millwork throughout the building shall be painted three coats of white lead and oil semi-gloss paint of selected colour, except as hereafter specified. Ship lap partitions in the basement will not be painted.

PAINTING ON FIR

When paint is applied to c.e. fir, the wood shall be primed with an oil filler of special manufacture to prevent the raising of the grain.

ALTERNATIVE PRIZE FOR B.C. FIR - NATURAL FINISH

The contractor shall submit in his tender an alternative price for finishing all B.C. fir trim and millwork for natural finish as follows:

(1) well rub in a wood paste filler.
(2) apply a coat of pure white shellac.
(3) apply coat of interior varnish thinned with 10% of turpentine.
(4) apply second full coat of varnish after 24 hours.

BIRCH TRIM

Birch hand rails and newels to staircases to be stain-filled to approved colour and varnished two coats.

The first coat of varnish to be thinned with best quality turpentine and at least twelve hours must elapse before second coat of varnish is applied.

FINISHED FLOORS AND HARDWOOD STAIRS

All finished floors, including stair landings, and all stair treads and risers are to be finished with three coats
of best quality floor varnish. The first coat of varnish to be thinned with turpentine, and succeeding coats applied twelve hours apart in full consistency from the container.

WALLBOARD SURFACES

All gypsum wallboard surfaces throughout the building shall be examined to ensure completely filled joints, and secure fastening before finish is applied.

All such surfaces to be first coated with a sealing primer manufactured for the purpose applied in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions, and finished with two coats of semi-gloss paint of selected colour.

CIMENT SURFACES

Cement wall and floor surfaces throughout the basement excepting only in furnace (or boiler) fuel and store rooms shall be finished as follows:

(a) Walls.

Carefully examine all cement finished wall surfaces, and remove all traces of oil, grease, dirt, or other foreign matter, then apply one coat well brushed on of a concrete hardener as supplied by leading paint manufacturers, as it comes from the container.

When hardener is set and dry, apply a second coat, 50% of which shall be an approved sealer primer and 50% concrete paint of colour selected for finish coat.

Allow 24 hours for drying and apply a final coat of concrete paint of selected colour as it comes from the container.

(b) Floors.

Remove all grease, oil, dirt, efflorescence and other foreign substances from floors and when perfectly dry apply one coat of concrete hardener, well brushed in.

When hardener is set and dry, apply one coat of cement and concrete sealer as it comes from the container and allow 24 hours for drying, after which apply two coats of concrete floor paint in accordance with the manufacturer's directions.
GLAZING

WINDOWS & DOORS

All glass for double hung and casement windows, as well as closed doors, shall be glazed with 34 oz. sheet glass.

STORM WINDOWS AND STORM DOORS

Storm glass and lights in storm doors also shall be glazed with 34 oz. sheet glass.

Glass shall be free of waves, bubbles or other imperfections and shall be cut with straight edges or full size required by the openings.

All glass in windows shall be bedded in putty, sprung and finished with putty, coloured to match paintwork.

All glass in closed doors shall be marbled and held in place with wood bands or moulds. The glass in exterior doors to be back putted.

Painting of sash and frames may be carried out at the mill, and the contractor may arrange to have all or any part of the glazing also completed at the mill.

Previous to priming sash and frames, the engineer in charge shall be notified so that inspection may be arranged.

PROTECTION AND CLEANING

During construction the contractor shall protect all glass from damage, providing at his own expense all breakages from any cause. He shall clean all glass before the buildings are occupied. He shall also prevent the accumulation of painters' material in addition to the buildings and arrange for storage of his materials elsewhere to prevent as far as possible a fire hazard from such causes.

COMPLETION

When painting and glazing work has been completed, the contractor shall clean all spots from finished surfaces, refinish any rubbed or damaged work, whether it be caused by himself or others. He shall touch up where work of other trades require, and leave the buildings in a clean and orderly condition.

1. All clauses set forth in the General and Labour Conditions shall apply to and govern this Trade.

2. SCOPE OF WORK

This specification and the accompanying heating drawing are intended to provide for a complete system of gravity warm air heating in the building. The Contractor shall take all measurements at the building, set out all work and be responsible for the accuracy of same. He shall provide all labour, transportation, material and plant and give his personal and constant attention to the work and be responsible for any damage done.

3. VISIT THE SITE

The Contractor must visit the Site and see the conditions under which the work will be done and govern himself accordingly.

4. MATERIALS AND WORKMANSHIP

All materials shall be new and the best of their respective kinds, sound and free from defects.

Workmanship shall be of the best and all work shall be done in a neat manner with due attention given to the grading of all warm air leaders, and making connections. All connections shall be made to provide free and unobstructed flow and shall be made as tight as possible and in a manner consistent with the best practice.

5. WARM AIR FURNACE

Furnish and set up complete in the basement, where shown on plan, one first grade furnace as described on drawing, having a rated output equivalent to that called for on the plan. The furnaces shall have a double casing; they shall be equipped with manually operated chain, controlled draft and check dampers, water pan and a complete set of firing tools.

6. SMOKE PIPE

Provide and install galvanized iron smoke pipe of a gauge and diameter called for on plan. This smoke pipe shall have a close fitting manually operated key damper in horizontal run.
Provide suitable collar at a point where smoke pipe enters chimney.

7. **LEADERS**

Provide and install circular warm air leaders of sizes noted on plan, made up of bright tin or 26 gauge galvanized iron, with locked seams. Joints shall be lapped not less than 1" and shall be banded and soldered to make tight connections. All leaders shall be carefully connected to furnace con, register boxes and wall stacks, with all necessary elbows, tees, tees, boots, transformer sections, etc., as may be required to provide a complete job. Leaders shall be supported from joints and shall be installed with rise of not less than one inch per lined foot.

All leaders, except as noted on plan, shall be provided with dampers located not more than 3'-0" from furnace con.

Where leaders are run within 1" of any woodwork, the woodwork in the immediate vicinity shall be protected with sheet asbestos wall board.

Where leaders pass through partitions, galvanized iron flanged sleeves shall be provided, the flanges having dimensions sufficient to cover opening in partition. The sleeves shall be made of No. 24 gauge galvanized iron.

8. **STACKS**

All warm air stacks shall be made up of bright tin or No. 26 gauge galvanized iron, and shall be of sizes as noted on drawing.

9. **RETURN AIR DUCTS AND LEADERS**

From the cold air register floors located where shown on plan, provide and connect air return air ducts of sizes and as noted on plan. These return air ducts shall be installed directly to the undersides of the joists and run to the furnace room where round return air leaders shall be connected therefrom to cold air stacks, typically as shown on large scale section. Care shall be taken to make all joints as tight as possible, and all panels shall be cross braced to provide rigidity.

10. **ELBOWS**

All elbows shall be not less than 3 pieces style, and shall be adjustable. Care shall be taken to obtain tight connections between elbows and leaders.

11. **REGISTERS AND FLOORS**

Supply and install baseboard and floor registers where shown of sizes noted on plan. Supply registers shall be provided with movable louvers and suitable for connection to register boxes.

Return air floors shall be cast with bronze finish or hardwood. Wall floors adjacent to stair well or first floor shall be steel with bronze finish of sizes as shown.
14. COMPLETION

Upon completion of the work the Contractor shall remove all rubbish and waste materials resulting from his work and leave the whole system in perfect working order.

15. RECORD PLANS

During progress of the work, the Contractor shall keep a record of all changes to the original plans. Upon completion he shall forward one set of blueprints with changes clearly recorded in red to the Chief Engineer. Blueprints for this purpose shall be furnished by the Department.

16. GUARANTEE

The Contractor will be called upon to guarantee his work for a period of one year after it is accepted by the Department. He shall make good or replace any defect arising in his work during that period, at his own expense as soon as possible after being notified that such defect has appeared.

17. HEATING EQUIPMENT LIST

Equipment listed under condition table "C" on sheet No. H-1 Index No. 337 of the blue prints should be provided for this school.

22. SANITATION

The Contractor shall comply with, and the work shall be carried on subject to all regulations made by any lawful authority applicable to said work, and all orders given by the Indian Agent with respect to sanitation or preservation of health on the work. The Contractor shall make adequate arrangements, to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent, for the medical and sanitary supervision of all his employees.

The Contractor shall protect, and shall not remove or destroy, or permit to be removed or destroyed, the stakes, buoys and other marks placed on or about the said work by the Indian Agent or his assistants, and shall furnish the necessary assistance to correct or replace any stake, buoy or mark which through any cause may have been removed or destroyed.

24. NOTICES

Any notice, order, direction or other communication given to the Contractor under any of the provisions of this contract shall be sufficiently given if delivered to the Contractor personally, or to his foreman, or left at the Contractor's office, or mailed at any post office to the Contractor or foreman addressed to the address mentioned in the contract, or to the Contractor's last known place of business or residence.

25. PROGRESS MEASUREMENTS AND CERTIFICATES NOT BINDING

The progress measurements and progress certificates shall not in any respect be taken as binding upon the Indian Agent or as final measurements or as fixing final amounts; they are to be subject to the revision of the Indian Agent in making up his final certificate, and they shall not in any respect be taken as an acceptance of the work or as a release of the Contractor from responsibility in respect thereof.

26. PROTECTION OF WORK

The contract and all information issued in connection therewith are confidential and their use must be strictly confined to the work and to the purpose of the contract; the particulars contained therein; and other matter issued in connection therewith, must not be disclosed to unauthorized persons.

The Contractor shall at all times take and cause to be taken all reasonable measures, for the protection of the work against espionage and sabotage, and on the order of the Minister shall dispense with the services of any person employed in, about or upon the work or cause the same to be dispensed with. The Minister shall at all times through such agency as he may see fit be entitled to maintain on or about the premises where the work or any part thereof is being carried on such police or other protective force as in the opinion of the Minister may be advisable.
27. CANADIAN LABOUR AND MATERIALS

To the full extent that the same are procurable, only Canadian labour, parts and materials (unless otherwise agreed by the Minister) shall be used in connection with the work.

27a. EMPLOYMENT OF EX-SERVICE MEN

In engaging labour for the work contemplated by this contract, either from the National Employment Service or from Trade Unions with which the contractor has collective agreements, the contractor shall specify that preference shall be given to competent and available ex-service men.

The contractor shall maintain and keep available for inspection by the Minister a record of the names and addresses of ex-service men employed, together with a record of the steps taken to implement this requirement.

28. SALARIES:

The salaries payable to engineers, superintendents, draftsmen and foremen shall only be such as shall be approved by the Minister.

29. TERMINATION

(a) Notwithstanding anything in this contract contained the Minister may, by giving notice to the Contractor, terminate the contract (save and except the provisions of this section and of section 19 of these general conditions) as regards all or any part or parts of the work or works not theretofore completed. Upon such notice being given, the Contractor shall cease work (including the procuring of materials for the fulfilment of the contract) in accordance with and to the extent specified in such notice but shall proceed with all reasonable speed to complete such part or parts (if any) of the work or works as are by the terms of such notice to be completed and shall also proceed with all reasonable speed to complete up to such time and/or stage as may be specified in the notice any part or parts of the work or works as required by such notice. The Minister may, at any time, or from time to time give one or more additional notices with respect to any or all parts of the work which remain to be completed after the giving of any previous notice or notices.

(b) All work completed by the Contractor under or pursuant to the provisions of the contract before or after the giving of any notice, subject to acceptance by His Majesty in accordance with the provisions of the contract, shall be held for on the basis provided in an agreement (the Contractor being allowed such fraction of his stipulated fee as shall be proportionate to the amount of the work theretofore completed) and the Contractor shall be entitled to be reimbursed the actual cost of the contractor of work not completed under or pursuant to the provisions of this contract and/or any notice given pursuant thereto plus a fair and reasonable profit in respect of work done therein, provided that no reimbursement shall be made for materials which have been or may be rejected after inspection as not complying with the terms and conditions of this contract and the specifications.
(c) In the event that the Contractor and the Minister are unable to agree upon the amount in respect of which the Contractor is entitled to be reimbursed as aforesaid, the matter shall be referred to the Exchequer Court.

(d) Whenever practicable the Contractor shall procure materials required for the performance of the contract on terms that will enable it to terminate any contracts entered into by the Contractor upon conditions and terms similar in effect to those herein provided for in respect to termination by the Minister and the giving of a notice or notices as aforesaid; and generally the Contractor shall cooperate with His Majesty and the Minister and do everything reasonably within its power at all times to minimize and reduce the amount of His Majesty's obligations under the provisions of this section.

(e) Upon reimbursement being made to the Contractor as herein provided, title to the materials and/or work in progress in respect of which such reimbursement is made shall pass to and vest in His Majesty (the Contractor hereby agreeing to execute and deliver all requisite instruments by way of further assurance) and such materials and/or work in progress shall be delivered to the order of the Minister, but the materials thus taken over will in no case be in excess of what would have been required for performing the contract in full if no notice had been given under the provisions hereof.

(f) If it is established to the satisfaction of the Minister by the Contractor that by reason of any action taken by the Minister under the provisions of this section exceptional hardship has resulted to the Contractor then the Minister may, notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, in his absolute discretion grant such allowance (not to include in any case, however, any allowance or compensation for loss of profit) to the Contractor as, in the opinion of the Minister is warranted by the circumstances.

(g) Any action, decision or determination by the Minister under the provisions of this section shall be final and binding upon the Contractor.

(h) The Contractor shall have no claim for damages, compensation, loss of profit, allowance or otherwise by reason of or directly or indirectly arising out of any action taken or notice given by the Minister under or pursuant to the provisions of this section except as and to the extent in this section expressly provided.

(i) The right of termination and of giving notice hereinafore provided shall be in addition to and not in substitution for any other right possessed by His Majesty and/or the Minister.

NEW SCHOOLS - Michel and Stoney Plain

Three more sets of plans were forwarded to you, as requested in your letter of October 15, 1947.

Payrolls have been examined in detail and compared with the original paysheets. Daily time records were not available for examination as these are destroyed once they have been transferred to and balanced with paysheets.

The rates of pay observed on the job were in accordance with those approved on the agreement and based on 44 hour week with overtime at time and a half. Travelling time was paid at regular hourly rate, and was not taken into account in the accumulation of overtime.

| Position                        | Rate per hour |
|---------------------------------|---------------|
| Superintendent                  | $1.87½        |
| Carpenter foreman               | 1.40          |
| Carpenters                      | 1.25 - 1.35   |
| Carpenter Apprentice            | .63           |
| Labour foreman                  | .90           |
| Labour                          | .80           |
| Indian labour, approved by      | .55 - .75     |
| Indian Agent                    |               |
| Instrumentman                   | 1.05          |

On payroll # 47 for the period end October 16/47, an error of $2.00 has been noted in the computation of L. Gabrielson's wages which are shown as $37.20 instead of $39.20. As this employee terminated his services with the contractor in January, some difficulty may be experienced in adjusting this amount.
HOLIDAY PAY has been computed throughout at the rate of 3% with all employees including Indians being covered. As in the Michel Reserve School contract, some adjustment will be necessary to bring the charges in line with the actual rates applicable to each employee. Holiday Pay should also have been added to the payrolls in calculating Workmen's Compensation and Public Liability and Property Damage charges.

WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION charge has been calculated at 4% of actual payroll throughout the project. Adjustments arising out of assessments on individual earnings over $2000 will be credited on the final claim.

PUBLIC LIABILITY & PROPERTY DAMAGE Insurance is carried by the Contractor and is in good standing. Charges levied against this project were calculated at .31% of the gross payroll from the commencement of the project to Payroll # 2 for the period ending January 25th, 1948, and at .230% on the remaining payrolls included to date. The current year's rate has since been established at .250%, and the required adjustment will be included in the final claim.

UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE contributions have been deducted from all employees with the exception of Superintendent H.G. Ellenwood, who receives a fixed salary of $75.00 per week. The employer's portion was calculated on the basis of 75% of employee's contribution.

INCOME TAX - The records were examined for compliance with Income Tax regulations and evidence of deductions and remittances were produced to the examiner's satisfaction.

INSURANCE covering fire risk on the project is contained in Aetna Insurance Co. Policy # 7860 for $11,000 in the names of the Department of Indian Affairs and Poole Construction Co. Ltd. The Original Policy has been lodged with the Department through the Indian Agent. The duplicate copy of the Policy has been examined and payment of premium verified.

MATERIALS - $5703.08

Invoices for materials, small tools, either purchased by the contractor or supplied from their own stock, have been checked to purchase orders and requisitions and also certified by the Indian Agent. Evidence of payment by the contractor to the suppliers has been verified in all cases.

Transfers of materials from the Winterburn School to the Michel School or vice versa, and items distributed between the two schools were found to be properly accounted for with the exception of a 30¢ error on invoice # 1459, where the amount of $51.59 was transferred instead of $51.59. This is to be adjusted on the final claim.

SMALL TOOLS

A joint inventory of small tools amounting to $71.89, which were purchased and charged to the Michel and Winterburn Schools, has been set up.
TRAVELLING EXPENSES - $294.00

Travelling expenses have been paid to A.C. Butson, job foreman, who provided conveyance to his crew in his personally owned car at the rate of $2.00 per round trip, which in this instance represented 26 miles. Evidence of payment has been ascertained and the number of trips checked with the number of days worked during each period.

Hired Equipment - $57.00

Charges recorded under this caption represent services of G. Morin, with team, at the rate of $1.50 per hour, which compares closely with the minimum rate approved.

TRUCKING - $156.00

Trucking charges on the Company's equipment were set at $3.00 per hour, including operator, and approved by the Indian Agent. Daily time cards were examined and found to correspond with the invoices submitted and carried the foreman's signature.

SUB-CONTRACTS

Millwork - W.M. Clark Lumber Co., have agreed to supply all millwork at an estimated price of $1829.00. This was the lower of two submissions received by the Contractor and was found acceptable by the Indian Agent. So far, invoices amounting to $1565.16, have been submitted on this project.

Painting & Decorating - The firm of Jack Mason was the only party interested in this job and has agreed to complete painting and decorating for $1050. To date accounts have been rendered for $840, representing 80% of the work completed.

Electrical - Al's Electric, 12130 - 9th Street, have been authorized to supply and install electrical wiring and outlets at the price of $315 and to supply and install standard fixtures in the classroom and residence for $195. To date accounts have been rendered for $400.40.

Plumbing & Heating - The sub-letting of this work has been carried out on a cost of labour and material basis, as no firm appeared interested in submitting estimates.

The firm of Dow & Scott have to date rendered accounts for $94.15 of which $9.50 represents labour.

The firm of Freese & Maxwell have agreed to supply and install furnace and heating system on the same basis, and have submitted accounts for $410.96 to date. Completion of this phase of the work is estimated to cost approximately $450 more. The General Contractor has a sufficient hold-back against these two firms and a detail audit will be performed when all work has been completed.
COMMISSION OR FEE - $1568.64

In accordance with the terms of the agreement, the Poole Construction Company have charged a 10% commission or fee on all costs incurred to date, omitting any commission on any earnings of the Company arising out of rental of Company owned equipment.

Further to my letter of June 4th in connection with desks for the above schools.

The desks taken over from Youville School for use at Michel School have now been refinished and will be taken to the school today.

I am having these brought over to the Agency for storage and shall be glad if you will advise what disposition you wish made of them. I am enclosing herewith requisition to cover window blinds for the Stony Plain and Michel day schools also Penetrem for finishing the floors and dustbane and a push broom for each school.

Ref. your 110-6-30 of November 20

We naturally cannot hope to equip all the Indian schools with the hockey equipment which they request. PROGRESS CLAIM #5 - $8222.63 (Final)

The audit of Progress Claim #5, in connection with the above contract has been completed by the undersigned at the Contractor's office in Edmonton and in conjunction with records and information furnished by the Superintendent of the Edmonton Agency, Mr. R.A. Robertson and the report therein follows:

LABOR AND LABOR CHARGES - $1264.32

This amount represents the balance of wages and related charges to the completion of the contract and brings the total labor cost for the project to $8222.63.

The payrolls submitted have been examined in detail and calculations have been found correct. Transfers from original time cards to the payrolls have been found in order.

The scale of wages paid by the Contractor was in accordance with rates that have been approved and set out in the Agreement. The rates observed were based on an 8 hour day, 44 hour week with time and a half for overtime. Travelling time was paid at the regular rate and was not taken into account in the accumulation of overtime.

Effective April 1st., 1946, the following rates were paid by the Contractor in compliance with an Agreement reached between the Edmonton Builders' Exchange and the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America:

Carpenter foreman - $1.50 per hour
Carpenters - $1.40 per hour
Laborers - $.90 per hour
Superintendent - $2.00 per hour, based on fixed salary of $50.00 per week, with approval of the Indian Superintendent.

Indian labor has been paid at 75¢ per hour, with approval of Indian Superintendent.

An underpayment of $2.00 noted on payroll # AV for Oct. 16, 1947, appearing in Claim #5, in connection with L. Gabrielson has not been possible to adjust as this former employee could not be reached. No further action is contemplated by the Contractor.
HOLIDAY PAY - $24.65

Discrepancies in the calculation of Holiday Pay in Claims 1 to 4 inclusive have been adjusted in this claim by a debit voucher for $13.79 which has been added to the charge of $10.86 applicable to the payrolls submitted with the present claim, making a total charge of $24.65.

The Employees' Holiday Pay Books have been examined and proof of payment established.

Holiday Pay charges have also been taken into account in the computation of the other payroll charges.

WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION - $25.75

The Contractor's assessment rate by the Alberta Workmen's Compensation Board has been 45¢ for the years 1947 and 1948.

The amount presently claimed represents charges of $46.75 applicable to the payrolls submitted with this claim less a rebate of $20.96 received by the Contractor on 1947 payments in connection with employees whose earnings exceeded the maximum assessable amount of $2000 for that year.

A further examination of the Contractor's records will be made on receipt of the returns from the W.C.B. for 1948 in order to secure any further credit that may accrue.

PUBLIC LIABILITY & PROPERTY DAMAGE - $2.75

The Contractor has maintained adequate coverage against the above risks throughout the Contract. The payment of premiums which were based on .25% of the estimated gross payroll for 1947 and on .225% for 1948, has been established.

The calculations have been reviewed in connection with the present and previous claims and the amount charged has been found sufficiently accurate.

UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE - $14.50

This amount represents the Contractor's portion of contributions paid on behalf of insurable employees listed on the payrolls submitted herewith. Dear Mr. Pratt:

Ref: Edmonton Indian Agency Administrative Office

On my return from Ottawa I got in touch with the District Architect, Department of Public Works, and advised him that it was the wish of the Director of Indian Affairs that he obtain office space in Edmonton for the headquarters of the Edmonton Indian Agency, and that this space would be required as soon as possible, preferably early in the new fiscal year.

I also informed the Superintendent of the Agency, Mr. Robertson, and the present Fur Supervisor, Mr. W. B. Skead. It was known that the District Architect would be glad to have any leads or assistance that these men could give in locating office space in that city, as space there is very scarce.

Space is required for the Superintendent and his staff of three clerks, also the Fur Supervisor. I hope you agree that the latter should be established in the Edmonton Agency office. This office should also be the headquarters of the Welfare Officer, Inspector of Schools and Building Supervisor, when these officials are working in or out of Edmonton. In our opinion the space should not be less than 600 sq. ft.

I have to report that D.F.W. officials are finding it very difficult to locate any office space. Oil companies are offering large rentals for any available space in the city, and it is understood that good space is costing as high as $4.00 a sq.ft.

The District Architect has been advised that location is not of first importance to Indian Affairs. He stated this week that he is constantly surveying the whole situation and following any possible leads, and has hopes that suitable space will be located.

In the meantime, a Clerk, Grade 3, with a homes in Edmonton, has been detailed by the Civil Service Commission to fill the vacancy at the Agency. This man is boarding with the Superintendent at Winterburn.
The Superintendent and members of his office staff, Mr. Mitchell and Mr. Sims, know that they must find their own living quarters when and if the office is moved into Edmonton.

On a recent visit to the present Agency, consideration was given to the disposition of the buildings when vacated. The office proper will make an excellent day school with very few changes. Another day school is badly needed, and I am writing to Col. Henry, sending you a copy, explaining the local situation in this respect.

To house the teacher of this school, the cottage, now occupied by the clerk and immediately across the road from the office, could be used. The warehouse, which is at the rear of the office, must be retained and it will only require a new entrance to definitely separate it from the school.

The Superintendent's house would be turned over to the Assistant Indian Agency, Mr. Callihoo. The house, which he is now occupying, is the property of the Stoney Plain Band of Indians, and it is believed that the Health & Welfare Department might make some arrangements with the Band to use it for a nursing station, if the Band do not wish to make use of it in some other manner.

You will, therefore, understand, Mr. Pratt, in moving from Winterburn to Edmonton there is no wastage, and in fact there would be a distinct saving in capital outlay.

I would be glad to hear from you.

Yours truly,

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Dear Col. Neary:

Re: Stony Plain Day School

In February I visited the Stony Plain Day School and was impressed particularly with the number that there in attendance. It was a blizzardy day and I found 41 pupils in attendance. The young teacher, Mr. H. S. Leslie, appeared to me to be a capable teacher and had his classes well organized.

I learned that the average attendance for January had been 37.8 and the highest attendance for the term was 52. Superintendent Robertson, who accompanied me, stated that there will be another 12 to 15 pupils of school age next fall. It is, therefore, necessary to find space for another classroom.

As you may know, it is proposed to move the Agency headquarters from Winterburn to the City of Edmonton, and, for your information, I am attaching copy of a letter which I have written to Mr. Pratt in this regard.

The Agency office is about a mile to the east of the school and would, in our opinion, make a very suitable school to take 30 or 35 pupils. It is well constructed, well heated by a furnace in good condition and, so far as I can see, it would be necessary only to remove some partitions and change certain windows to make it a very suitable classroom.

As stated in the letter to Mr. Pratt, the cottage across the road could, in turn, be made the home of the teacher and I believe this would be a real inducement for a good single married teacher to apply. The total cost of making the office into a school should not exceed $1,000.00.

For various reasons, therefore, it is hoped that the Agency headquarters are moved into the city in the early summer and that this building can be made ready for a class before the fall term.

You will be advised of progress.

Yours sincerely,

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.
