DEPUTY MINISTER

Stony Plain Indian Day School.

One of the first new day schools constructed in the province of Alberta was on the Stony Plain Reserve. So successful is this school that we are now forced to add a second classroom.

Next year there will be fifty-seven children enrolled in the school. We are fortunate in having secured the former agency office and clerk's residence for school purposes in order to accommodate these additional children. We have been endeavouring to secure tenders for the necessary alterations and installation of extra windows.

The only contractor from whom our Indian Superintendent was able to get a firm bid is the Poole Construction Company of Edmonton. Their tender is in the amount of $1,045.00.

This company has done previous work for the Department in erecting day schools on both the Stony Plain and Michel Reserves. Their tender is fair and reasonable, and I would recommend it for your approval.

Acting Director.

We are enclosing a copy of our wire to Col. H. F. Neary requesting authority as soon as possible to purchase a new furnace for the Stony Plain Indian Day School #2 at a cost of approximately $200.00.

We have been having considerable trouble with this furnace and before Mr. Robertson left for the North country he instructed Keeler's Sheet Metal and Vacuum Service to inspect the furnace and make any minor repairs that were necessary. Mr. Keeler inspected the furnace today and immediately phoned this office to say that in his opinion, the furnace was completely worn out due to fire hazard involved. Mr. Keeler is considered to be a very reliable furnace expert and it was felt that in this case his advice should be followed.

As it is too cold to operate the school at this time of year without heat the children have been released until the middle of next week when it is hoped that authority will have been received and the new furnace installed.

Mr. Bernard Neary,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Booth Bldg., Spark St.,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I just met His Excellency Right Rev. H. Routhier, o.m.i. and he advised me the intention of the Indian Department to build a school for the Indians at Whitefish Lake, Atikameg, P.O.

He asked me to give you some informations about the conditions of the country.

To get the lumbers, we have to come to Grouard; the manager of a sawmill offers to us a special price; he will let us have the rough lumbers at Grouard, 43 miles from Whitefish L. for thirty dollars, a thousand feet; it seems they can be obtained there quite cheap. No sawmill has been established on the Metis colony, as it was thought.

The freighting may be done quite easily from Grouard to Whitefish Lake in winter; but the road is so bad in summer that it is very expensive to carry some goods in summer.

So to build the school next spring or summer, it is very important that the freight be done before April at least.

With my thanks and my Best Greetings of the Season,

I am,

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

y. M. Flori, o.m.i.

Ottawa, December 15, 1947.

Atikameg Indian Day School

Dear Father Floch:

I have for answer your letter of December 8. I myself wrote on December 8 to our Indian Agent, Mr. Landry, at High Prairie, concerning this school and made certain suggestions to him. It is possible that by now he has the information contained in your letter. In any event, I have sent him an extract of the part dealing with the lumber and the winter freighting of materials. I hope that we can make satisfactory arrangements in regard to this school.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. A. Landry, Indian Agent,
High Prairie, Alberta.

Atikameg Indian Day School

Further to my letter of December 8 concerning the above Day School, I have now received a communication from the Reverend Father Flock with regard to the lumber required. He states in part as follows:

"To get the lumber, we have to come to Grouard. The manager of a sawmill offers to us a special price; he will let us have the rough lumber at Grouard, 43 miles from Whitefish L. for thirty dollars, a thousand feet; it seems they can be planned there quite cheap. No sawmill has been established on the Metis colony, as it was thought.

"The freighting may be done quite easily from Grouard to Whitefish Lake in winter; but the road is so bad in summer that it is very expensive to carry some goods in summer.

"So to build the school next spring or summer, it is very important that the freight be done before April at least."

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Re: Atikameg Indian Day School.

I acknowledge receipt of your letters of December 8th and 15th, file 131-22-1 (W.T.) having reference to the construction of the above noted school.

I have recently interviewed Right Reverend Bishop Routhier and I am advised that he has found a suitable man to act as foremen for this construction. I know the man personally. He has erected several buildings in this district and has always shown himself most reliable and efficient. I am confident that with him acting as foreman we would have no trouble with the school building at that point.

As I understand a good deal of local lumber such as spruce will be required in this construction. This lumber, as noted by Father Floch's letter to you, is available in the vicinity of Grouard which is approximately 43 miles from Atikameg. The price that he quotes however at $30.00 per thousand is for rough lumber. As you are no doubt aware the biggest part of this lumber will have to be planed and would therefore cost an estimated additional $6.00 per thousand. The transportation of that lumber imposes a problem and as noted by Father Floch it is hardly feasible after March. The roads to that point are now in the better condition than it is expected that they will be in the course of the winter. I would very much appreciate if all freighting to be taken to that point were done by Indians. The standard of living of the Indians of the Whitefish Lake Reserve (Atikameg) is very low. Most of them have horses and sleighs and would very much appreciate whatever freighting we would give them. I am not yet certain of the exact cost of freighting lumber from Grouard to Atikameg but I would estimate that it will be in the neighborhood of $20.00 per thousand.

If it is your intention that I place an order with local lumber mills and take charge of the freighting of lumber it would be appreciated if I were notified at your earliest opportunity. It would also be appreciated if I were furnished with the quantity and type of lumber that will be needed. On receipt of same it will receive my prompt attention.

A. Lancy,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, December 27, 1947.

Mr. A. Landry, Indian Agent,
High Prairie, Alberta.

Atikameg Indian Day School

Reference your 6-6-4 of December 23 -

It is noted that you are prepared to recommend a foreman for the construction of this school. Although it will be some time before construction can actually begin, if you will let us have his name, address and wages per hour requested, we will obtain the necessary authority for his employment from the Minister's office. With regard to the building itself, we have today sent you, under separate file, the following documents:

(a) One blueprint of our standard one-room Indian Day School with attached teacher's residence,

(b) One set of specifications for the above school,

(c) Three copies of the bill of materials required to construct the above school.

We can send you extra copies of any of the above documents as required.

It is suggested that you now take the following action:

(1) Prepare, from the bill of materials, a requisition for the lumber which can be supplied by the Grouard mill.

At the foot of the requisition, state the price for rough lumber and for planed lumber, as quoted by the mill. It would be preferable to separate the requisition into two parts, one for rough lumber and the
other for planed lumber. You should also state the name and address of the mill quoting on this lumber. We can then have our Departmental Purchasing Agent proceed with the placing of this order at once.

(2) Return to us one of the bills of material which we are sending to you and from which you have deleted all lumber items listed on the requisition above and which can be supplied locally. You should also delete the broken and crushed stone which we hope can be obtained locally. It would be very expensive to freight these masonry items in to Atikameg. We can then prepare another requisition to the Departmental Purchasing Agent for items which will have to be purchased in Edmonton, or elsewhere. If you can recommend a source of supply for the bricks, flue lining, tile and tile pipe, this would help to speed up delivery.

We can arrange for the purchase of the cement by carload lot.

We will expect to hear from you further with regard to our recommended action as above.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Re: Atikamek Day School

I wish to refer to your letter of December 27th, file 131-22-1 (W.T.), having reference to the building of the above mentioned school.

Receipt is also acknowledged of the following documents:

(a) One blueprint of our standard one-room Indian Day School with attached teacher's residence,

(c) One set of specifications for the above school,

(c) Three copies of the bill of materials required to construct the above school.

Since receiving these documents I have attached great importance and priority to this matter. I have succeeded in locating an experienced and reliable builder to act as foreman. The party is Alfred Blouin, whose address is Jousard, Alberta. This man is 36 years of age and well reputed as a very good carpenter and builder. So far he has built 4 military barracks at Grande Prairie, 1 church at Jousard, 1 ware-house at Peace River, 1 residence at Fairview and 3 residences at Peace River. He gives as reference Mr. Charles Turner, Contractor, Grande Prairie, Alta., and also Ray Lehey, Contractor, Peace River, Alberta. I know this man personally and I have seen some of the work that he has done. I am of the opinion that he is fully qualified to undertake the building of our school there. In view of the remoteness of the area however, he is demanding $150 per hour. Considering the wages paid for common labour and for skilled labour I do not think that Mr. Blouin is over estimating himself by demanding these wages.

In your letter of December 16th in which you quote part of a letter from Father Floc'h of Atikameg, I wish to report as follows: When Father Floc'h approached the Grouard saw-mill which is operated by the Basarab Brothers, it would appear that the firm really quoted him $30.00 per thousand for rough lumber. They were under the impression however that the lumber was required for the church authorities and in that respect they always make it a point to sell lumber at times ever lower than cost price.
When I interviewed the Bassarab Brothers they would not consider anything less than $42.00 per thousand for rough lumber and an additional $6.00 per thousand for plain lumber. Furthermore they will not undertake to prepare this lumber for me before June. Since it would be impossible to freight that lumber into Whitefish Lake in the spring it is obvious that we cannot consider purchasing our lumber from them.

I have also approached a second small firm, Walker and Sons, who operate a portable saw-mill within 35 miles of Atikameg. They are willing to fill my order at $45.00 per thousand feet for lumber dressed on three sides and the same price for lumber dressed on four sides. The transportation of this lumber from the mill to Atikameg could be done by Indians and I do not think that the cost would be more than $20.00 per thousand feet.

It is to be noted however that your requisition calls for all lumber to be yard seasoned and dry. In that respect I can only say that it is absolutely impossible to obtain such lumber in this district and in fact I am absolutely unaware as to where it could be obtained. There are numerous constructions going on in this district and all native lumber that is used is lumber sawn in winter, allowed to dry for approximately four months and then used in the buildings. Due to the shortage of lumber there is no alternative. While it does not make the best of buildings it would appear to be satisfactory and this system has always been followed in the district.

Studying the matter more fully I find another angle that we possibly could undertake. Last spring a portable saw-mill was purchased from Welfare and sent to me at Driftpile, where I intended to use it mainly for the bands of Driftpile and Sucker Creeks. This mill is now set up in Driftpile and is powered by the band tractor. It works very nicely and does a very nice job. I have just returned from Atikameg after going through the spruce timber available on the reserve there. I find that while this timber is quite scattered there would be enough logs available within four miles of the school site to fill our requirements of native lumber. A good sawyer is available and under his leadership most of the work in this connection could be done by Indians. A small portable planer would have to be rented and moved on the premises. The tractor could be rented from the Driftpile Band and brought there as a means of power.

After consulting experienced saw-mill operators, I am told that in spite of the cost of wages we could safely fulfill our requirements for an estimated maximum of $90.00 per thousand feet right on the premises.

A copy of this report is being forwarded to Supervisor Gooderham for any recommendations that he may wish to make as there is no doubt that Mr. Gooderham as well as myself, would like to see this saw-mill operated. If the saw-mill is brought there I also intend to apply to Welfare for sufficient funds to saw additional lumber to be used for the building and the improvement of Indian homes of the Whitefish Lake Reserve.

A further point has also entered my mind. No provisions seems to have been made for a shed to store the material at Atikameg. There is no storage available
there for the material. It would therefore appear that we have no alternative but to build one. This shed could be built with one ply of lumber with a suitable roof. I would recommend the size to be 20 X 40 feet. This would require an additional 9000 feet of lumber. When the building of the school is completed I would recommend that this shed be taken apart and the lumber used for the building and improvement of Indian homes.

A. Landry,
Indian Agent.

Attention: B.F. Neary.

Re: Atikames Day School

In previous correspondence, in regards to the above noted school, no mention is made as to its exact location at Atikameg. Am I correct therefore in assuming that it is to be built on the property recently purchased from A.R. Morden by Right Reverend Bishop Henri Routhier?

As you are no doubt aware this property is adjoining the Whitefish Lake Indian Reserve and at the spot where the Indians are mostly located. There is a nice elevation on that property approximately 300 yards from the small Whitelish Lake.

I also note that no provision is made for the water supply. In that respect I can only say that there are no wells at Atikameg. The population of that area use the lake for their water supply. While that water appears to be good I have been informed by the Post Manager of the Hudson's Bay Company that the analysis of the water revealed that it should be chlorinated.

A. Landry,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

Atikameg Indian Day School.

The sum of $14,000.00 has been included in our 1948-49 estimates for the construction of a standard one room school and attached teacher's residence at Atikameg, an Indian reserve situated on Whitefish Lake in the Lesser Slave Lake Agency.

This is an isolated reserve and the Departmental Purchasing Agent is now buying building materials which can be shipped in via The Northern Alberta Railway Company and Indian teamsters to the proposed site. It will not be possible to interest a contractor in the construction of this school, therefore, we requested Mr. Indian Agent Landry to try to locate a suitable building foreman. He has done so and has now reported as follows:

"I have succeeded in locating an experienced and reliable builder to act as foreman. The party is Alfred Blouin, whose address is Jeussard, Alberta. This man is 36 years of age and well reputed as a very good carpenter and builder. So far he has built 4 military barracks at Grande Prairie, 1 church at Jeussard, 1 ware-house at Peace River, 1 residence at Fairview and 3 residences at Peace River. He gives as reference Mr. Charles Turner, Contractor, Grande Prairie, Alberta, and also Mr. Ray Lahey, Contractor, Peace River, Alberta. I know this man personally and I have seen some of work that he has done. I am of the opinion that he is fully qualified to undertake the building of our school there. In view of the remoteness of the
area, however, he is demanding $1.50 per hour. Considering the wages paid for common labour and for skilled labour, I do not think that Mr. Blouin is over estimating himself by demanding these wages".

Your approval is requested for the hiring of Mr. Blouin at the rate of $1.50 per hour to supervise the construction of this school by Indian labour.

Director.

BFN/HM.
Ottawa, January 27, 1948.

Mr. A. Landry, Indian Agent, High Prairie, Alberta.

Atikameg Indian Day School.

We are now able to report progress from here with regard to the construction of this school:

(a) The requisitions are now in the hands of the Departmental Purchasing Agent and it is hoped that Purchase Orders can be issued in the near future. I understand that Father Beuglet would do everything possible through his business contacts in Edmonton to obtain scarce items of building materials. We are now buying similar building materials for two schools in the Norway House Agency and have experienced great difficulty in buying millwork and some hardware items. If firms in Edmonton cannot promise delivery of certain scarce items, then we will write you immediately requesting you to contact Father Beuglet in an attempt to have him expedite such delivery.

(b) Your recommendation concerning Mr. Blouin is now at the Minister's office with a request that approval be given for hiring him at the rate of $1.50 per hour.

(c) Approval is given to your recommendation concerning the building of a storage shed near the site of the school. We will try to get authority for you to buy the lumber necessary by local purchase.

(d) The matter of the site of the school was discussed at some length with Father Beuglet. The Indian Act requires that day schools be situated on an Indian reserve. We would be prepared to accept your recommendation with regard to the location of the school but it should be
located on property owned by the Department. If necessary we could consider the purchase of a small plot of land from Bishop Routhier. We will expect to hear further from you with regard to this matter.

(e) We have asked in our estimates for the sum of $14,000.00 for the construction of this school. A lot depends on the cost of materials, freighting, etc., and as to what provision can be made for water and other extras. Therefore, we are not in a position to give you a definite answer insofar as these items are concerned, until we know how great an expenditure has been made for other necessary supplies, etc. In any event, we cannot exceed $14,000.00.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

With reference to your Credit Voucher No. 446, I have
to advise you that you have been credited with $2,450.06 on the
basis of this account. The sum of $10.00 was deducted from
this, since you advanced J. Willier $10.00 on freighting as per
receipt #99313 which was not accounted for by details in the
same way as the other advances.

I have also to advise you that you have had advances
re this school to the extent of $4000.00 - $1500.00 as per
Cheque No. 96664, dated Mar. 13th and Cheque No. 99380 amounting
to $2500.00 so that you still have to account for $1519.94.

It is noted that you have several other balances out-
standing as follows:

| Item       | Amount   |
|------------|----------|
| Trust Funds| $9047.59 |
| Vote 511   | $60.00 (Firewood) |
| Annuities  | $890.00  |
| Vote 515   | $700.00 (500.00=Freighting) |
|            |          |
|            |          |

It is not known in Treasury if these are in process
of being passed for payment by the Department but it is
definitely not understood why these advances have not been
adjusted by Credit Vouchers or refunds before this. The end
of the Government Fiscal Year is March 31st, and since none of
this money can be expended after that date, certainly sufficient
time has elapsed to have these advances completely cleaned up.

An impression seems to have developed that these
accountable advances do not have to be accounted for until the
end of the year. This is definitely not the case. Accountable
Advances should be liquidated by Credit Voucher or refund or
unexpended balances immediately after the money has been spent.

Will you please give this matter your immediate
attention.

N/W

Re: Atikameg Indian Day School.

The foreman and three carpenters have now proceeded to Atikameg with a view of building the above mentioned school. While there it is anticipated that a good number of Indians will also be employed as the foreman, Mr. Blouin, is very eager to see that this building is completed as soon as possible.

It is not known here exactly how much money will be required for the total labour of this construction. Meanwhile however, it would be appreciated that a temporary advance of $4,000.00 could be sent to the Indian Agency Trust Account, where it will be accounted for in the usual manner.

I have reasons to believe that in all likelihood you will require a progress report as the construction goes on. In that respect it would be appreciated if I could be in receipt of the required forms for this report if they exist. It would also be appreciated if I could be instructed as to any procedure.

A. Landry,
Superintendent.
July 9, 1948.

Mr. A. Landry, Superintendent,
High Prairie, Alberta.

With reference to your letter of June 26th, we are arranging to forward you an accountable advance for $1,000.00 for labour in connection with the erection of the Atikameg Indian Day School. As soon as this cheque is expended you should account for it in the proper manner and apply for a further advance.

While the construction of the building is in progress you should visit it weekly, if possible, and let us have a letter stating the progress that is being made.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Attention: Mr. Neary.

Re: Atikameg Indian Day School:

I have just returned from the Atikameg Reserve and have thoroughly inspected the above noted school building.

The building is progressing very satisfactorily. I regret however, that the cost will exceed considerably the $14,000.00 allotted. The freighting to that point by Indian teams constitutes a major item.

The rough part of the building is now completed. That is to say, the walls and floor, ceiling and roofing and all partitions are completed. The chimney is also nearly finished. All excavation is completed. The outside finish of the cement wall is also completed. Work is also progressing nicely on the interior finish of the basement floor and walls. One out-house is completed.

The hauling of rocks, gravel and sand proved costly. These were only available at a considerable distance from the building site and a road had to be built to get there.

The $1000.00 advance already received for labor has now been used up. A remaining $2435.00 in wages is unpaid as of July 31st. It would therefore be appreciated if an accountable advance of $3000.00 were received here to pay such wages.

Due to.........
Due to the difficulty in obtaining skilled labor to work at such a remote point it is somewhat hard to estimate how much longer it will be before the building is completed. Mr. J.A. Blouin, the foreman, expects to have it completed by September 1st.

A. Landry,
Superintendent.

The attached voucher No. 933 (131) was submitted by the former Superintendent, Mr. Landry, to account for advances forwarded to him in connection with the construction of the Atikameg Day School. The Treasury Branch has asked that this voucher be returned for clarification and revision if necessary.

They point out the following:

(1) For the week ending July 10th the Agent wrote one cheque to J.A. Blouin. For the second and third and fourth names there is no evidence that Blouin paid out this money. Please obtain this information.

(2) Deductions have been made for income tax and unemployment insurance but no indication is given as to what disposal was made of the money. The former Agent has not submitted an accounting for either employer's or employees' share of unemployment insurance.

(3) For the week of July 17th it would appear that the net amount required was handed to the foreman but there is no receipt from the persons whom the foreman paid.

The same applies to the rest of the credit vouchers. To be complete, the credit voucher should contain receipts for all payments made.
(4) The income tax deductions should be forwarded to the Income Tax Department by cheque. If this has already been done, we would like to know the cheque number, amount and date.

The same applies to both the employer's and employees' share of the unemployment insurance.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.
There are quite a number of errors in the letter.

On the second page, Agent wrote the date to R.A. Blans... On the second page, he wrote the name here. No evidence was shown to have been made for income tax & tax. In fact, no indication as to what he had done remains. Agent has submitted no accounts for either Employer or Employee shown & tax.

On July 7th, he has handed the account to the foreman, but we have no record of what the agent has done with it.

The same applies to the receipt of the credit.

To complete the letter, please contain receipts for all payments made.

Handing the money to someone is not sufficient. The income tax deductions should be forwarded to the Income Tax Dept by Oct. 31st. We have not heard from the taxes perhaps checked through his cash book. The same applies to both Employer & Employee shown & tax.

The letter is returned herein.
October 25, 1948.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Reverend Father Floc'h of Saint Benoit Mission, Atikameg Alberta, wishes me to call your attention to the present conditions in regard to the new school building which the Department is erecting at Atikameg, as well as the other matters pertaining to the school itself.

He states that:

1: The building is not yet completed.
2: The heating plant, the toilets for the children and the double windows still have to be finished or installed. This is made difficult because the workmen here left and will not return.
3: Some of the desks are still at Grouard.
4: The kitchen stove, which was ordered C.O.D. from Simpson, is at Eilds and the Agent says that he has no money to have it freighted to the Mission.
5: The Agent would like us to open the school on November 22nd, but as stated above, only part of the desks are in the school and moreover there are no chairs and tables or bedding for the sisters who will be in charge of the school.
6: Apparently the school books and other school material have not yet been shipped or are delayed somewhere in transit.
7: The cocoa milk and sugar have arrived, but there are no biscuits.

The above report, as stated, was forwarded to me by the Reverend Father Floc'h who is in charge of this Mission and should in my estimation be inquired into.

Yours very truly,

Re: Atikameg Day School

Receipt is acknowledged of your letter of November 30, 1948,
file 707-5 (E.I.) regarding the Atikameg Day School.

I visited this school on November 22nd, and found that all
work which could be done with the material available had been fin-
ished. The floor registers had not been installed owing to the
fact that registers are not available. We put in a telephone call
to Edmonton in an endeavour to secure registers but none were av-
ailable of the size desired. We also communicated with a plumbing
supply firm in Peace River with similar results. At present we
have an order for registers with a High Prairie welding firm but
there has been a delay owing to lack of material. The only subtit-
ute available is mink wire which Mr. J. A. Bluin, the carpenter,
will put on when he goes to Atikameg on December 6th.

The kitchen sink had not been installed because a pipe thread-
er was not available. Mr. Bluin will endeavour to borrow such a
tool and install the sink.

Some of the hot air pipes that connect the living quarters
with the furnace were not available. We have attempted to get
these pipes in High Prairie but they are not in stock here. Mr.
Bluin will take measurements and we will have them made as soon
as possible.

The windows had not been put in the toilet as they too were
not shipped from Edmonton. The air vents and urinal were not put
in but Mr. Bluin has promised to do this work during the week of
December 6th.

All except three or four of the desks were at the school on
November 22nd. A few of the desks had been damaged in transit.
but I believe that Father Floch will arrange for repairs.

The storm windows had not been put on the building as they had not yet arrived in Atikameg.

On December 1st, we arranged with a truck driver to have the storm windows taken to the school. The remaining desks were to be taken in at that time also.

I believe that all the furnishings for the residential part of the building will have arrived at Atikameg at this date. On Nov. 22nd, the kitchen stove had not yet arrived owing to the fact that it was shipped C.O.D. to Enilda. The station agent at Enilda wrote to Simpson's of Regina and asked to have the stove released but that was not done. We sent a telegram from this office and asked that the stove be released but no answer arrived. Rev. Father Tessier of Grouard secured the stove by giving a personal cheque. It has now gone to Atikameg but is much too small for preparation of a noon meal for school children.

Mr. Bluin estimates that it will cost approximately $200.00 to finish the school. I believe that amount will be sufficient although the cost of floor registers will be high.

In a telephone conversation today Rev. Father Beuglet of Mo-Lennan told me that the Atikameg Day School was to open on Monday, November 29th. I might add that the delay seems to have been mainly the result of shortage of building materials.

G. S. Lapp

Mr. Philip Phelan, Superintendent,

Dear Sir:

Let allow me to wish you a "Very Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year." I ask God to Bless you and to assist you in your work. Will you also offer my Wishes to Mr. Neary, who is doing so much for our school at Whitefish Lake, Atikameg.

Indeed we are grateful to the Department of Indian Affairs for the nice school built at Atikameg for our Indian children.

However I feel it is not true what is the most advisable in a place like ours; most of the people lead a nomadic life and cannot afford to stay around to have their children go to school. It happens that some have sent back the children to Grouard and it may partly be the reason why some Catholic children have been put at the Anglican school. Besides others have come from the district of Ilebocon or Prairie Lake and stay here; the inconvenience is that far away from their families they can hardly maintain their families; in fact they have build some kind of houses to shelter themselves, but they are so poor that they cannot afford to have a floor. I take the liberty to mention it that it can be understood the condition of life in our district. It is very different as it is around Edmonton and Calgary; the Indians have a chance to farm, here it is entirely a wild country, with bush, swamps, etc.

You may be interested to know how the school building stand; it is not completed; the heating system is not finished, lack of material requisitioned; there is no register fixed on the floor. The sink is not fixed; the man who came did not have the tools to fix it. There are some storm windows not brought in yet and none is set up, and some other things, which are finished. It has taken quite a time to have the school built; the carpenters were away twice for about a month every time. They are supposed to come back at any time, but I am afraid that we may have to wait quite a while.

The teacher, Sister Helene will appreciate very much, if the school furnitures, requisitioned to the Department, can be shipped in the nearest future; for till now she has to go on what was begged or borrowed here and there, and she is short of everything useful to make the school go; it is known the attention always by the Department to supply everything needed.

She did not receive any school register nor any form for monthly or quarterly returns.

Will not be advisable too to have the National Flag supplied and some "Fire Extinguishers".
It will be appreciated also, if different things for games can be supplied as footballs, baseball sets, etc.; our children are very fond of sports and it is a way to have them busy at recess time or after school.

Surely you will excuse me to be such a bother; but I do so think it necessary for the welfare of our Indian children.

With my Wishes of the Season and my sincere thanks,

I am Yours very truly.

Y. M. Hock o.m.i

Re: Atikameg Day School.

Receipt is acknowledged of your letter of January 5th, file 707-5 (El).

Contrary to the statement in my letter of December 4th, Mr. Bluin, the carpenter, did not go to Atikameg on December 6th. The weather became very severe at that time so that Mr. Bluin did not make the trip.

On January 5th Mr. Bluin went to Atikameg by truck to continue work on the school. He was accompanied by Brother Bosse, a tinsmith and carpenter from the Grouard Mission. I went to Atikameg at that time also in the Agency car.

The following information was given to me today by Brother Bosse:

Mr. Bluin and Brother Bosse installed the floor registers and fitted the storm windows. They attempted to complete connections to the sink but some of the fittings were missing. The hot air connections to the living quarters are not complete but the living quarters are sufficiently warm even in sub-zero temperatures. One hot air elbow leading to the classroom was of very light material and is damaged beyond repair. A substitute elbow may be found at Grouard and sent to Atikameg. The air vents and urinal have not been installed in the toilets.

The attached letter lists some work which should be done on the school building. All the improvements which are requested by the Reverend Mother Superior are necessary and I recommend that the work be done as soon as possible. At present there is no storage space in the class-
If shelves with sliding doors were built under the large windows the storage problem would be partially solved. The warehouse to which Reverend Mother Superior refers is the building in which the cement and other building materials were stored. The cement was piled on one side with the result that the floor joists are broken. At present snow blows through the broken floor so the building is not suitable for storage.

All the furniture for the school has arrived at Atikameg. Included in the shipment were two couches (chesterfields) and two buffets. One of each is sufficient in the small quarters. Reverend Mother Superior is waiting for instructions as to the disposition of the extra couch and buffet for which there is insufficient storage space. Some parts of the broken desks are in the office here. When a capable workman is found the desks will be repaired and returned to Atikameg. At present there are sufficient desks for the pupils enrolled.

Mr. Bluin left Atikameg on the afternoon of January 8th. He plans not to return before May although he is aware, I believe, that the building should be completed by March 31st. He is also aware of the fact that the roads to Atikameg are much more passable in the winter than during the spring and summer. At present the temperature is above +32°F so that the work still unfinished on the out-buildings could have been completed.

G.S. Lapp,
Superintendent.
Atikameg Indian Day School,
Atikameg, Alberta,

Re: Atikameg Indian Day School.

Attached hereto please find our Voucher No. 99, covering the final accounting of the advances received from the Department to pay wages in connection with the construction of the Atikameg Indian Day School.

The total advances received from the Department to pay wages in connection with the building of the school amounted to $6500.00. In all, this office disbursed in cash for labor a total of $7027.14, thus leaving an overdraft of $527.14 in our Trust Account Ledger. It would be appreciated if a cheque could be forwarded at an early date in order this overdraft may be cleared from our ledgers.

There is a further amount of $455.02 which is outstanding covering income tax and unemployment insurance remittances. As we already have an overdraft of $527.14, it is felt advisable to have the Department forward an accountable advance of $455.02 in addition to the $527.14, therefore a total of $982.16 will be required. The $455.02 will be accounted for by receipts covering the tax and insurance payments.

It will be noted that Mr. J.A. Blouin, foreman, was overpaid in the amount of $22.00. We have written Mr. Blouin requesting him to remit this amount to this office which will be remitted to the Receiver General. Mr. Blouin has a further $33.00 owing him for recent work he had done at the school, therefore in the event he is unable to remit the $22.00 overpayment, collection maybe made from what is still owing him.

G.S. Lapp (Superintendent)

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Receipt is acknowledged of your letter 707-5,
dated October 29th, 1948.

(1) For the week ending July 10th: Attached please find receipts signed by the second, third and fourth persons whose names appear on the Return of Labor.

(2) Deductions for income tax and unemployment insurance are being accounted for on our voucher which is being attached hereto. The procedure followed in this office until Sept. 20th was to make deductions from wages for income tax and unemployment insurance but deductions were not forwarded to the Income Tax Branch nor to the Unemployment Insurance Office. The plan was to forward the deductions, in one sum, to offices concerned, when the school was completed. Since the school was presumably very near completion on September 20th, it was thought best to continue that procedure. The receipt from the Unemployment Office is attached. The receipt from the Income Tax Branch is not attached as it has not yet been received here but it is hoped that the cheque number will be acceptable to the Treasury Branch.

(3) With regard to the week ending July 17th: It is not understood why the Return of Labor with cheque number and signatures of recipients is not acceptable to The Treasury Branch. Perhaps the difficulty is that the recipients have placed their signatures in the "Witness Column" rather than in the "Received
payment" column. It will be impossible to obtain receipts covering payments for labor for the week ending July 17th before May 1st as the Indians who worked at the Atikameg Day School are for the most part trappers and some will not receive their mail before April 15th.

Attached hereto is our Credit Voucher No. 262(131) dated March 3rd, accounting for $7482.16, the total advances received from the Department for wages building the school. I might point out that you will not find all the labor sheets attached hereto as a number of them are attached to our voucher number 619, dated July 19th, 1948, and voucher No. 99, dated January 19, 1949. These labor sheets are no doubt on file in your office.

(Sgd.)
G.S. Lapp,
Superintendent.

Re: Atikameg Day School.

Attached please find a copy of a letter from the Rev. Sr. Superior, Atikameg Day School. As is indicated by the letter there is considerable work yet to be done at the school before the building will be completed. Could authorization be obtained to secure the services of a competent worker who would finish the work at the school? The expense would be covered by return of labor. I have not been able to visit the school since early in January and so it is difficult to estimate the cost of the work but I believe that the labor involved would amount to no more than $100.00. The materials including paint, varnish, and some furnace pipes would probably cost approximately $25.00.

G.S. Lapp,

Mr. G.S. Lapp, Superintendent,
High Prairie, Alberta.

Dear Sir:

Thank you for sending me the blank forms for the requisition of drugs.

I am sending you my list completed.

May I recall to your mind that the gutters are still in the shed, and so are the pipes for the cistern. It will be wasteful to pack the dirt around the house and have the water from the roof ruining the work done.

It seems to me also that the floor or the classroom would need a coat of varnish, and so would the desks.

I am sorry to have to ask for so many things, but to be kept in good condition, a house needs constant care.

I remain, dear Sir, much obliged,

Sr. Alfred de la Trinite, f.d.l.s.,

P.S. The storm windows would need to be painted also.

Mr. Bernard Neary,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Booth Bldg., Spark St.
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I just met His Excellency Right Rev. H. Routhier, O.M.I., and he advised me the intention of the Indian Department to build a school for the Indians at Whitefish Lake, Atikameg, P.O.

He asked me to give you some information about the conditions of the country.

To get the lumber, we have to come to Grouard; the manager of a sawmill offers to us a special price; he will let us have the rough lumber at Grouard, 65 miles from Whitefish L. for thirty dollars, a thousand feet; it seems they can be obtained there quite cheap. No sawmill has been established on the Metis colony, as it was thought.

The freighting may be done quite easily from Grouard to Whitefish Lake in winter; but the road is so bad in summer that it is very expensive to carry some goods in summer.

So to build the school next spring or summer, it is very important that the freight be done before April at least.

With my thanks and my Best Greetings of the Season,

I am,

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

y. M. Flori, O.M.I.

Re: Atikameg Indian Day School.

I acknowledge receipt of your letters of December 3rd and 15th, file 131-22-1 (W.T.) having reference to the construction of the above noted school.

I have recently interviewed Right Reverend Bishop Routhier and I am advised that he has found a suitable man to act as foreman for this construction. I know the man personally. He has erected several buildings in this district and has always shown himself most reliable and efficient. I am confident that with him acting as foreman we would have no trouble with the school building at that point.

As I understand a good deal of local lumber such as spruce will be required in this construction. This lumber, as noted by Father Floch's letter to you, is available in the vicinity of Grouard which is approximately 48 miles from Atikameg. The price that he quotes however at $30.00 per thousand is for rough lumber. As you are no doubt aware the biggest part of this lumber will have to be planed and would therefore cost an estimated additional $6.00 per thousand. The transportation of that lumber imposes a problem and as noted by Father Floch it is hardly feasible after March. The roads to that point are now in the better condition than it is expected that they will be in the course of the winter. I would very much appreciate if all freighting to be taken to that point were done by Indians. The standard of living of the Indians of the Whitefish Lake Reserve (Atikameg) is very low. Most of them have horses and sleighs and would very much appreciate whatever freighting we would give them. I am not yet certain of the exact cost of freighting lumber from Grouard to Atikameg but I would estimate that it will be in the neighborhood of $20.00 per thousand.

If it is your intention that I place an order with local lumber mills and take charge of the freighting of lumber it would be appreciated if I were notified at your earliest opportunity. It would also be appreciated if I were furnished with the quantity and type of lumber that will be needed. On receipt of same it will receive my prompt attention.

Indian Affairs Branch,

A. Lavery
Indian agent.

Re: Atikameg Day School

I wish to refer to your letter of December 27th, file 131-22-1 (W.T.), having reference to the building of the above mentioned school.

Receipt is also acknowledged of the following documents:

(a) One blueprint of our standard one-room Indian Day School with attached teacher's residence,

(b) One set of specifications for the above school,

(c) Three copies of the bill of materials required to construct the above school.

Since receiving these documents I have attached great importance and priority to this matter. I have succeeded in locating an experienced and reliable builder to act as foreman. The party is Alfred Blouin, whose address is Jussard, Alberta. This man is 56 years of age and well reputed as a very good carpenter and builder. So far he has built 4 military barracks at Grande Prairie, 1 church at Jussard, 1 ware-house at Peace River, 1 residence at Fairview and 3 residences at Peace River. He gives as reference Mr. Charles Turner, Contractor, Grande Prairie, Alta., and also Ray Lahey, Contractor, Peace River, Alberta.

I know this man personally and I have seen some of the work that he has done. I am of the opinion that he is fully qualified to undertake the building of our school there. In view of the remoteness of the area however, he is demanding $1.80 per hour. Considering the wages paid for common labour and for skilled labour I do not think that Mr. Blouin is over estimating himself by demanding these wages.

In your letter of December 18th in which you quote part of a letter from Father Floch of Atikameg, I wish to report as follows: When Father Floch approached the Grouard saw-mill which is operated by the Bassarab Brothers, it would appear that the firm really quoted him $30.00 per thousand for rough lumber. They were under the impression however that the lumber was required for the church authorities and in that respect they always make it a point to sell lumber at times even lower than cost price.
When I interviewed the Basarab Brothers they would not consider anything less than $42.00 per thousand for rough lumber and an additional $6.00 per thousand for plain lumber. Furthermore they will not undertake to prepare this lumber for me before June. Since it would be impossible to freight that lumber into Whitefish Lake in the spring it is obvious that we cannot consider purchasing our lumber from them.

I have also approached a second small firm, Walker and Sons, who operate a portable saw-mill within 35 miles of Atikameg. They are willing to fill my order at $48.00 per thousand feet for lumber dressed on three sides and the same price for lumber dressed on four sides. The transportation of this lumber from the mill to Atikameg could be done by Indians and I do not think that the cost would be more than $20.00 per thousand feet.

It is to be noted however that your requisition calls for all lumber to be yard seasoned and dry. In that respect I can only say that it is absolutely impossible to cut in such lumber in this district and in fact I am absolutely unaware as to where it could be obtained. There are numerous constructions going on in this district and all native lumber that is used is lumber sawn in winter, allowed to dry for approximately four months and then used in the buildings. Due to the shortage of lumber there is no alternative. While it does not make the best of buildings it would appear to be satisfactory and this system has always been followed in the district.

Studying the matter more fully I find another angle that we possibly could undertake. Last spring a portable saw-mill was purchased from Welfare and sent to me at Driftpile, where I intended to use it mainly for the bands of Driftpile and Sucker Creek. This mill is now set up in Driftpile and is powered by the band tractor. It works very nicely and does a very nice job. I have just returned from Atikameg after going through the spruce timber available on the reserve there. I find that while this timber is quite scattered there would be enough logs available within four miles of the school site to fill our requirements of native lumber. A good sawyer is available and under his leadership most of the work in this connection could be done by Indians. A small portable planer would have to be rented and moved on the premises. The tractor could be rented from the Driftpile Band and brought there as a means of power.

After consulting experienced saw-mill operators, I am told that in spite of the cost of wages we could safely fulfill our requirements for an estimated maximum of $60.00 per thousand feet right on the premises.

A copy of this report is being forwarded to Supervisor Gooderham for any recommendations that he may wish to make as there is no doubt that Mr. Gooderham as well as myself, would like to see this saw-mill operated. If the saw-mill is brought there I also intend to apply to Welfare for sufficient funds to saw additional lumber to be used for the building and the improvement of Indian homes of the Whitefish Lake Reserve.

A further point has also entered my mind. No provisions seems to have been made for a shed to store the material at Atikameg. There is no storage available
Indian Affairs Branch

therefor the material. It would therefore appear that we have no alternative but to build one. This shed could be built with one ply of lumber with a suitable roof. I would recommend the size to be 20 X 40 feet. This would require an additional 9000 feet of lumber. When the building of the school is completed I would recommend that this shed be taken apart and the lumber used for the building and improvement of Indian homes.

A. Landry,
Indian Agent.

Re: Atikameg Day School

In previous correspondence, in regards to the above noted school, no mention is made as to its exact location at Atikameg. Am I correct therefore in assuming that it is to be built on the property recently purchased from A.R. Morden by Right Reverend Bishop Henri Routhier?

As you are no doubt aware this property is adjoining the Whitefish Lake Indian Reserve and at the spot where the Indians are mostly located. There is a nice elevation on that property approximately 300 yards from the small Whitefish Lake.

I also note that no provision is made for the water supply. In that respect I can only say that there are no wells at Atikameg. The population of that area use the lake for their water supply. While that water appears to be good I have been informed by the Post Manager of the Hudson's Bay Company that the analysis of the water revealed that it should be chlorinated.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

Atikameg Indian Day School.

The sum of $11,000.00 has been included in our 1948-49 estimates for the construction of a standard one-room school and attached teacher's residence at Atikameg, an Indian reserve situated on Whitefish Lake in the Lesser Slave Lake Agency.

This is an isolated reserve and the Departmental Purchasing Agent is now buying building materials which can be shipped in via The Northern Alberta Railway Company and Indian teamsters to the proposed site. It will not be possible to interest a contractor in the construction of this school, therefore, we requested Mr. Indian Agent Landry to try to locate a suitable building foreman. He has done so and has now reported as follows:

"I have succeeded in locating an experienced and reliable builder to act as foreman. The party is Alfred Blouin, whose address is Jeussard, Alberta. This man is 36 years of age and well reputed as a very good carpenter and builder. So far he has built 4 military barracks at Grande Prairie, 1 church at Jeussard, 1 ware-house at Peace River, 1 residence at Fairview and 3 residences at Peace River. He gives as reference Mr. Charles Turner, Contractor, Grande Prairie, Alberta, and also Mr. Ray Lahey, Contractor, Peace River, Alberta. I know this man personally and I have seen some of work that he has done. I am of the opinion that he is fully qualified to undertake the building of our school there. In view of the remoteness of the
area, however, he is demanding $1.50 per hour. Considering the wages paid for common labour and for skilled labour, I do not think that Mr. Blouin is over estimating himself by demanding these wages".

Your approval is requested for the hiring of Mr. Blouin at the rate of $1.50 per hour to supervise the construction of this school by Indian labour.

Director.

BFN/HM.
Ottawa, January 27, 1948.

Mr. A. Landry, Indian Agent, High Prairie, Alberta.

Atikameg Indian Day School.

We are now able to report progress from here with regard to the construction of this school:

(a) The requisitions are now in the hands of the Departmental Purchasing Agent and it is hoped that Purchase Orders can be issued in the near future. I understand that Father Beuglet would do everything possible through his business contacts in Edmonton to obtain scarce items of building materials. We are now buying similar building materials for two schools in the Norway House Agency and have experienced great difficulty in buying millwork and some hardware items. If firms in Edmonton cannot promise delivery of certain scarce items, then we will write you immediately requesting you to contact Father Beuglet in an attempt to have him expedite such delivery.

(b) Your recommendation concerning Mr. Blouin is now at the Minister's office with a request that approval be given for hiring him at the rate of $1.50 per hour.

(c) Approval is given to your recommendation concerning the building of a storage shed near the site of the school. We will try to get authority for you to buy the lumber necessary by local purchase.

(d) The matter of the site of the school was discussed at some length with Father Beuglet. The Indian Act requires that day schools be situated on an Indian reserve. We would be prepared to accept your recommendation with regard to the location of the school but it should be
located on property owned by the Department. If necessary we could consider the purchase of a small plot of land from Bishop Routhier. We will expect to hear further from you with regard to this matter.

(e) We have asked in our estimates for the sum of $14,000.00 for the construction of this school. A lot depends on the cost of materials, freighting, etc., and as to what provision can be made for water and other extras. Therefore, we are not in a position to give you a definite answer insofar as these items are concerned, until we know how great an expenditure has been made for other necessary supplies, etc. In any event, we can not exceed $14,000.00.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

BFN/HM.

Reference your 131-22-5 (E) of February 13.

I note from the above noted letter that the purchase of the cement required has already been made. The same would apply to all other material required for the construction of this school. The road to Atikameg in the summer time is practically impassable with loads.

A. Landry, Esq.,

High Prairie, Alberta.

With reference to your Credit Voucher No. 446, I have to advise you that you have been credited with $2,480.06 on the basis of this account. The sum of $10.00 was deducted from this, since you advanced J. Miller $10.00 on freighting as per receipt #59313 which was not accounted for by details in the same way as the other advances.

I have also to advise you that you have had advances re this school to the extent of $4000.00 - $1200.00 as per Cheque No. 96664, dated Mar. 13th and Cheque No. 99380 amounting to $2500.00 so that you still have to account for $1529.94.

It is noted that you have several other balances outstanding as follows:

- Trust Funds = $9047.59
- Vote 511 = $600.00 (Firewood)
- Annuities = $1890.00
- Vote 515 = $1700.00 (500.00-Freighting) (1200.00-Bldg. homes)

It is not known in Treasury if these are in process of being passed for payment by the Department but it is definitely not understood why these advances have not been adjusted by Credit Vouchers or refunds before this. The end of the Government Fiscal Year is March 31st, and since none of this money can be expended after that date, certainly sufficient time has elapsed to have these advances completely cleaned up.

An impression seems to have developed that these accountable advances do not have to be accounted for until the end of the year. This is definitely not the case. Accountable Advances should be liquidated by Credit Voucher or refund of unexpended balances immediately after the money has been spent.

Will you please give this matter your immediate attention.

N/W

W. Leachlan
Chief Treasury Officer.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

It will be noted that the Trust A/c here has an overdraft of $990.06 in the Freight A/c, Whitefish Lake. It would be appreciated if the Department would forward in Trust to this office a cheque covering this overdraft.

A. Landry,
Superintendent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Attention: Mr. B.F. Neary

Re: Atikameg Indian Day School.

The foreman and three carpenters have now proceeded to Atikameg with a view of building the above mentioned school. While there it is anticipated that a good number of Indians will also be employed as the foreman, Mr. Blouin, is very eager to see that this building is completed as soon as possible.

It is not known here exactly how much money will be required for the total labour of this construction. Meanwhile however, it would be appreciated that a temporary advance of $4,000.00 could be sent to the Indian Agency Trust Account, where it will be accounted for in the usual manner.

I have reasons to believe that in all likelihood you will require a progress report as the construction goes on. In that respect it would be appreciated if I could be in receipt of the required forms for this report if they exist. It would also be appreciated if I could be instructed of the work progress in that matter.

A. Landry,
Superintendent.
July 9, 1948.

Mr. A. Landry, Superintendent,
High Prairie, Alberta.

With reference to your letter of June 26th, we are arranging to forward you an accountable advance for $1,000.00 for labour in connection with the erection of the Atikameg Indian Day School. As soon as this cheque is expended you should account for it in the proper manner and apply for a further advance.

While the construction of the building is in progress you should visit it weekly, if possible, and let us have a letter stating the progress that is being made.

PP/MGD

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Attention: Mr. Neary.

Re: Atikameg Indian Day School:

I have just returned from the Atikameg Reserve and have thoroughly inspected the above noted school building.

The building is progressing very satisfactorily; I regret however, that the cost will exceed considerably the $14,000.00 allotted. The freighting to that point by Indian teams constitutes a major item.

The rough part of the building is now completed. That is to say, the walls and floor, ceiling and roofing and all partitions are completed. The chimney is also nearly finished. All excavation is completed. The outside finish of the cement wall is also completed. Work is also progressing nicely on the interior finish of the basement floor and walls. One out-house is completed.

The hauling of rocks, gravel and sand proved costly. These were only available at a considerable distance from the building site and a road had to be built to get there.

The $1000.00 advance already received for labor has now been used up. A remaining $2435.00 in wages is unpaid as of July 31st. It would therefore be appreciated if an accountable advance of $3000.00 were received here to pay such wages.

Due to.........
Due to the difficulty in obtaining skilled labor to work at such a remote point it is somewhat hard to estimate how much longer it will be before the building is completed. Mr. J.A. Blouin, the foreman, expects to have it completed by September 1st.

A. Landry,
Superintendent.

Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

Re: Atikameg Indian Day School,
Lesser Slave Lake Agency.

Under cover of our file 131-11-15, today's date, you will find an accounting to cover disbursements for labor to construct the above school. At the present time there is a debit balance of some $1300.00 in the Atikameg Day School account at Lesser Slave Lake; in addition to this there are work sheets on hand covering labor already performed but yet to be paid for, in the amount of some $750.00.

The carpenters are at present on location presumably putting the finishing touches on this building. The Superintendent, Mr. Lapp has been trying to obtain the services of a plasterer but it is not known whether he has been successful as yet. I understand that there is still some plumbing to be done - I gathered that the plumbing had been roughed in but that there was some finishing to do. These additional expenditures may amount to some $750.00 to $1000.00.

In order to clear the debit balance in this account and to provide the addition funds required to pay outstanding wages, and to complete the school, an accountable advance of at least $2500.00 should be provided as soon as possible.

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Reverend Father Floc'h of Saint Benoit Mission, Atikameg Alberta, wishes me to call your attention to the present conditions in regard to the new school building which the Department is erecting at Atikameg, as well as the other matters pertaining to the school itself.

He states that:

1: The building is not yet completed.
2: The heating plant, the toilets for the children and the double windows still have to be finished or installed. This is made difficult because the workmen here left and will not return.
3: Some of the desks are still at Grouard.
4: The kitchen stove, which was ordered C.O.D. from Simpson, is at Enilda and the Agent says that he has no money to have it freighted to the Mission.
5: The Agent would like us to open the school on November 22nd, but as stated above, only part of the desks are in the school and moreover there are no chairs and tables or bedding for the sisters who will be in charge of the school.
6: Apparently the school books and other school material have not yet been shipped or are delayed somewhere in transit.
7: The cocoa milk and sugar have arrived, but there are no biscuits.

The above report, as stated, was forwarded to me by the Reverend Father Floc'h who is in charge of this Mission and should in my estimation be inquired into.

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.
November 30, 1948.

AIR MAIL

Mr. G.S. Lapp,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
High Prairie, Alta.

The Department is anxious to have a report from you as soon as possible regarding the progress of the work at the Atikameg School and we would like to know the approximate date on which you consider it can be opened.

We have been advised that there is considerable work that has to be done and that the workmen have left.

We have also been told that some of the desks are still at Grouard and that the kitchen stove is at Enilda. Possibly you have already arranged for delivery of these articles to the school.

Have the furnishings for the residential portion of the building arrived yet?

We are ordering vitaminized biscuits from Paulin Chambers in Winnipeg and it is hoped that these will reach you in the near future.

When replying you should also let us have an idea of the approximate cost of finishing the building. Funds are provided in the current year's appropriation for this building and we want to have it completed so that we will not have to provide funds in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1949-50.

Bernard F. Neary

December 4, 1948.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Re: Atikameg Day School

Receipt is acknowledged of your letter of November 30, 1948,
file 707-5 (E.I.) regarding the Atikameg Day School.

I visited this school on November 22nd, and found that all
work which could be done with the material available had been fin-
ished. The floor registers had not been installed owing to the
fact that registers are not available. We put in a telephone call
to Edmonton in an endeavour to secure registers but none were av-
ailable of the size desired. We also communicated with a plumbing
supply firm in Peace River with similar results. At present we
have an order for registers with a High Prairie welding firm but
there has been a delay owing to lack of material. The only substi-
tute available is mink wire which Mr. J. A. Bluin, the carpenter,
will put on when he goes to Atikameg on December 6th.

The kitchen sink had not been installed because a pipe thread-
er was not available. Mr. Bluin will endeavour to borrow such a
tool and install the sink.

Some of the hot air pipes that connect the living quarters
with the furnace were not available. We have attempted to get
these pipes in High Prairie but they are not in stock here. Mr.
Bluin will take measurements and we will have them made as soon
as possible.

The windows had not been put in the toilet as they too were
not shipped from Edmonton. The air vents and urinal were not put
in but Mr. Bluin has promised to do this work during the week of
December 6th.

All except three or four of the desks were at the school on
November 22nd. A few of the desks had been damaged in transit.
but I believe that Father Floc'h will arrange for repairs.

The storm windows had not been put on the building as they had not yet arrived in Atikameg.

On December 1st, we arranged with a truck driver to have the storm windows taken to the school. The remaining desks were to be taken in at that time also.

I believe that all the furnishings for the residential part of the building will have arrived at Atikameg at this date. On Nov. 22nd, the kitchen stove had not yet arrived owing to the fact that it was shipped C.O.D. to Enilda. The station agent at Enilda wrote to Simpson's of Regina and asked to have the stove released but that was not done. We sent a telegram from this office and asked that the stove be released but no answer arrived. Rev. Father Tessier of Grouard secured the stove by giving a personal cheque. It has now gone to Atikameg but is much too small for preparation of a noon meal for school children.

Mr. Bluin estimates that it will cost approximately $200.00 to finish the school. I believe that amount will be sufficient although the cost of floor registers will be high.

In a telephone conversation today Rev. Father Beuglet of McNamara told me that the Atikameg Day School was to open on Monday, November 29th. I might add that the delay seems to have been mainly the result of shortage of building materials.

G. S. Lapp

St. Benedict's Mission Atikameg, Alberta December the 14th 1948.

Mr. Philip Phelan, Superintendent,
Welfare Branch,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Let allow me to wish you a "Very Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year. I ask God to Bless you and to assist you in your work. Will you also offer my Wishes to Mr. Neary, who is doing so much for our school at Whitefish Lake, Atikameg.

Indeed we are grateful to the Department of Indian Affairs for the nice school built at Atikameg for our Indian children.

However I feel it is not true what is the most advisable in a place like ours; most of the people lead a nomadic life and cannot afford to stay around to have their children go to school. It happens that some have sent back the children to Grouard and it may partly be the reason why some Catholic children have been put at the Anglican school. Besides others have come from the district of Athabasca or Prairie Lake and stay here; the inconvenience is that far away from their traditions they can hardly maintain their families; in fact they have build some kind of houses to shelter themselves, but they are so poor that they cannot afford to have a floor. I take the liberty to mention it that it can be understood the condition of life in our district. It is very different as it is around Edmonton and Calgary; the Indians have a chance to farm, here it is entirely a wild country, with bush, swamps, etc.

You may be interested to know how the school building stand; it is not completed; the heating system is not finished, lack of material requisitioned; there is no register fixed on the floor. The sink is not fixed; the men who came did not have the tools to fix it. There are some storm windows not brought in yet and none is set up, and some other things, which are finished. It has taken quite a time to have the school built; the carpenters were away twice for about a month every time. They are supposed to come back at any time, but I am afraid that we may have to wait quite a while.

The teacher, Sister Véline will appreciate very much, if the school furnitures, requisitioned to the Department, can be shipped in the nearest future; for till now she has to go on what was begged or borrowed here and there, and she is short of everything useful to make the school go; it is known the attention always by the Department to supply everything needed. She did not receive any school register nor any form for monthly or quarterly returns.

Will not be advisable too to have the "national Flag supplied and some Fire Extinguishers".
It will be appreciated also, if different things for games can be supplied as footballs, baseball sets, etc.; our children are very fond of sports and it is a way to have them busy at recess time or after school.

Surely you will excuse me to be such a begger; but I do so thinking it necessary for the welfare of our Indian children.

With my Wishes of the Season and my sincere Thanks,

I am Yours very truly.

Y. M. Flock. O.M.C.

Re: Atikameg Day School.

Receipt is acknowledged of your letter of January 5th, file 707-5 (El).

Contrary to the statement in my letter of December 4th, Mr. Bluin, the carpenter, did not go to Atikameg on December 6th. The weather became very severe at that time so that Mr. Bluin did not make the trip.

On January 5th Mr. Bluin went to Atikameg by truck to continue work on the school. He was accompanied by Brother Bossé, a tinsmith and carpenter from the Grouard Mission. I went to Atikameg at that time also in the Agency car.

The following information was given to me today by Brother Bossé:

Mr. Bluin and Brother Bossé installed the floor registers and fitted the storm windows. They attempted to complete connections to the sink but some of the fittings were missing. The hot air connections to the living quarters are not complete but the living quarters are sufficiently warm even in sub-zero temperatures. One hot air elbow leading to the classroom was of very light material and is damaged beyond repair. A substitute elbow may be found at Grouard and sent to Atikameg. The air vents and urinal have not been installed in the toilets.

The attached letter lists some work which should be done on the school building. All the improvements which are requested by the Reverend Mother Superior are necessary and I recommend that the work be done as soon as possible. At present there is no storage space in the class-
If shelves with sliding doors were built under the large windows the storage problem would be partially solved. The warehouse to which Reverend Mother Superior refers is the building in which the cement and other building materials were stored. The cement was piled on one side with the result that the floor joists are broken. At present snow blows through the broken floor so the building is not suitable for storage.

All the furniture for the school has arrived at Atikameg. Included in the shipment were two couches (chesterfields) and two buffets. One of each is sufficient in the small quarters. Reverend Mother Superior is waiting for instructions as to the disposition of the extra couch and buffet for which there is insufficient storage space. Some parts of the broken desks are in the office here. When a capable workman is found the desks will be repaired and returned to Atikameg. At present there are sufficient desks for the pupils enrolled.

Mr. Bluin left Atikameg on the afternoon of January 8th. He plans not to return before May although he is aware, I believe, that the building should be completed by March 31st. He is also aware of the fact that the roads to Atikameg are much more passable in the winter than during the spring and summer. At present the temperature is above +32° F so that the work still unfinished on the out-buildings could have been completed.

G.S. Lapp,
Superintendent.

Attached hereto please find our Voucher No. 99, covering the final accounting of the advances received from the Department to pay wages in connection with the construction of the Atikameg Indian Day School.

The total advances received from the Department to pay wages in connection with the building of the school amounted to $6500.00. In all, this office disbursed in cash for labor a total of $7027.14, thus leaving an overdraft of $527.14 in our Trust Account Ledger. It would be appreciated if a cheque could be forwarded at an early date in order this overdraft may be cleared from our ledgers.

There is a further amount of $455.02 which is outstanding covering income tax and unemployment insurance remittances. We have written Mr. Blouin requesting him to remit this amount to this office which will be remitted to the Receiver General. Mr. Blouin has a further $33.00 owing him for recent work he had done at the school, therefore in the event he is unable to remit the $22.00 overpayment, collection maybe made from what is still owing him.

(1) For the week ending July 10th: Attached please find receipts signed by the second, third and fourth persons whose names appear on the Return of Labor.

(2) Deductions for income tax and unemployment insurance are being accounted for on our voucher which is being attached hereto. The procedure followed in this office until Sept. 20th was to make deductions from wages for income tax and unemployment insurance but deductions were not forwarded to the Income Tax Branch nor to the Unemployment Insurance Office. The plan was to forward the deductions, in one sum, to offices concerned, when the school was completed. Since the school was presumably very near completion on September 20th, it was thought best to continue that procedure. The receipt from the Unemployment Office is attached. The receipt from the Income Tax Branch is not attached as it has not yet been received here but it is hoped that the cheque number will be acceptable to the Treasury Branch.

(3) With regard to the week ending July 17th: It is not understood why the Return of Labor with cheque number and signatures of recipients is not acceptable to The Treasury Branch. Perhaps the difficulty is that the recipients have placed their signatures in the "Witness Column" rather than in the "Received..."
payment" column. It will be impossible to obtain receipts covering payments for labor for the week ending July 17th before May 1st as the Indians who worked at the Atikameg Day School are for the most part trappers and some will not receive their mail before April 15th.

Attached hereto is our Credit Voucher No. 262(131) dated March 3rd, accounting for $7482.16, the total advances received from the Department for wages building the school. I might point out that you will not find all the labor sheets attached hereto as a number of them are attached to our voucher number 619, dated July 19th, 1948, and voucher No. 99, dated January 19, 1949. These labor sheets are no doubt on file in your office.

Ottawa, November 22nd, 1909.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a report from Mr. Inspector Markle on the Good Fish Lake Day School. In this report Mr. Markle says that the attendance here has not been what might be expected. He states that the teacher intends to provide a mid-day meal with a hope of improving conditions in this respect.

The Department will be glad to give Mrs. Waters assistance to do this, and I have to ask you to be good enough to communicate with her and furnish her with the necessary utensils of a serviceable nature, and to supplement the supply of biscuits with a reasonable allowance of rice, salt, tea, soup meat, flour, beans and bacon. The meat may be purchased and the other articles issued from the Agency storehouse, but your voucher should show the amounts of each given to the school.

Mr. Markle also refers to certain articles of stationery needed, and you will be good enough to have the teacher make a requisition on the forms provided for the purpose and forward it to the Department, when it will receive consideration.

Your obedient servant,

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 28th ultimo in reference to your appointment as teacher of the Goodfish Lake day school.

In reply I beg to say that the objection to your remaining in charge of this school was taken by the Department based upon information contained in a letter written by you to the Rev. Mr. Perrier on November 3rd, last, in which you state "my home is only six miles from the school so it is quite handy for me". The Department was not aware that you were boarding upon the reserve. Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter which reached me yesterday in reply to a letter I wrote some weeks ago to the Indian Department concerning some misunderstanding between the Dept and the Mission. But as I had been granted the school for a year I determined to write to him again and also to the Dept. Rev. Sir,

I beg to refer to official letter of March 2nd, last, in reference to the appointment of Mrs. Alldritt as teacher of the Goodfish Lake day school.

As you were informed on February 10th the Department consented to Mrs. Webber's remaining in charge until June 30th, next, provided the reports as to her work were satisfactory. Nothing further was heard in this matter until the Department was indirectly advised of the appointment of Mrs. Alldritt. It was presumed by the Department that when the change of teachers was made mutually satisfactory arrangements had been made, but in a letter dated the 27th ultimo just received from Mrs. Webber she claims that she has not been fairly dealt with.
