Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith a report, on a form, of an inspection made of the Good Fish mid-day meal day school. This school was recently re-opened as the Department knows and changed from a regular day to a mid-day meal, and the transportation of the pupils to and from school.

My impression is that it would be prudent to decide as to the kinds of food to be furnished to the children and not to leave this to the teacher, or the supervisor, to decide. When so left they are liable to be making requisitions on the agent for various supplies, according to notions and fancies of individual teachers, and the agent is at a loss to know just what to give and what to refuse. The Indians at Good Fish lake have cows and I see no reason why they should not send in a little milk daily if it is their wish that the children get milk, or cream, in their tea. Indians, as a rule, do not use milk in tea and I fail to see why canned cream should be purchased and sent in at considerable expense unless it is that the Department and the teacher desires to educate them to live more expensively than do their parents at home. Poor people, too, very frequently are obliged to use tea without sugar. It's largely habit and my notion is that these pupils might as well form the habit in their mouth to use tea without sugar. I did.

Mr. Scott,

With reference to Rev. Mr. Ferrier's statement that Mrs. Howard of Goodfish Lake, Alta., is desirous of having a school built with the idea of accommodating the children from Whitefish Lake and arrangements made for having the children from there driven to her school I beg to say that Mr. Inspector Markle, who visited the Goodfish Lake School last month, says that the school is kept in an old log building, which is used for the mid-day meal as well as the class-room and is not suitable for the work.

The Indians agreed a year or more ago to erect the walls for a new class-room and kitchen, provided the Department completed the same. This was agreed to by the Department and the log wall of the class-room building is now up, but Mr. Markle states he is informed by Mrs. Howard and the Indians claim it will be too small and should be enlarged. This could be done at an outlay of about $650.00.

The enrolment at the Goodfish Lake School for the last quarter was 30, with an average attendance of 17.
The Whitefish Lake School was closed for lack of attendance in June, 1910.

Mr. Markle, with his report, has sent in a sketch showing the location of the homes of the Indian children and giving the numbers of school age on the locations as shown. This shows that there would be approximately 40 children who could attend from the vicinity of Whitefish Lake and Goodfish Lake, but it would entail a drive of at least ten miles to bring in five children who live at the north end of Whitefish Lake. If these five children were sent to Red Deer the drive for the others would be shortened by about four miles. At the lower end of Whitefish Lake Mr. Markle says there are seven children of school age. This would give the total number of children of school age around Whitefish Lake as twelve. The other children all live within walking distance of the Goodfish Lake School. If the children around Whitefish Lake were sent to Red Deer there would be no need of making a semi-boarding school of the Goodfish Lake School, which would seem to be the wish of Mrs. Howard.

Mr. Markle thinks that the first requirement is to complete the new building and not crowd the old one with more pupils. He says that Mr. and Mrs. Howard seemed to be impressed
impressed with the idea that they are doing a wonderful work. He states that they are probably holding the children and parents in check to some degree, but there is still room for advancement in more than one direction.

It seems to me that the Howards have all that they can attend to at the Goodfish Lake School without taking in the children from around Whitefish Lake.

Mr. Markle, in his report on the Saddle Lake School, which he visited last month, says that if a day school is to be maintained on this reserve he thinks that a new building is required. He says that it is a question, however, whether a married woman with a family and house of her own to care for is in a position to devote her whole time to the work. has not been in operation long enough to show whether the Indians really want a school or not. School is held in the parlour of the parsonage, which is too small and not otherwise suited. I am sending you Mr. Markle's report herewith.

I observed that this school was not in operation for about 4 months last year - between June 25th and October 25th. The reason given is that the new building was not completed until about the end of October. The old building in which school has been held for years was available. I refer to this because I fail to be satisfied that Indian children can make progress at studies in a foreign language unless they are kept pretty steady at the work before them. They forget too quickly and after such a long term of idleness makes it about necessary to start where they first begun.

The new school building is now open for use the entire 12 months of the year and the reason advanced last year will not suffice for this season.

Dear Sir,

Being, more or less, known to the Dept. of Indian Affairs' officials, as one who is interested in the welfare of our Indian people, I make bold to write you regarding a matter closely connected with, and affecting the development of, the Indians in this Reserve. I refer to the Day-School here.

Mrs. Howard came to this Reserve in
The year 1913, I take up the work of the Day school; she was then Mrs. Butler.

After three years of her administration at the Day school, and judging by the results of her work, alone, I feel constrained to say that her being there — or anywhere else, for that matter — as teacher of the school, is a farce. By giving a hot noon-day meal, by giving them clothing etc., she secures a very good attendance; but not any better, really, than has been attained without these things; for the three months immediately preceding her arrival, the average daily attendance was 17.8%.

However, these things are good in themselves, and, as a means to an end, are excellent, but when they become the sum and substance of the whole matter, the school becomes a farce. Such is the condition prevailing at this school.
Mrs. Howard is a motherly woman and a very nice person. Personally, I have nothing whatever against her. But I feel that all parties concerned in the efficiency of the school are being imposed upon, because she is not competent to teach school subjects. The children are fed, lodged (partly), and amused. If genuine teaching, there is none.

You wonder why I write to you, what it is the church which is responsible for her being there. I write to you as a last resort, to see if you dept. cannot have her removed. I approached the church on this subject a year ago, but was informed that Mrs. Howard should have the school as long as she wanted it. I can do nothing in that direction. Mrs. Howard's brother has risen in the ranks of the Methodist Ministry, and holds a responsible position in this Province. I would point out to you, however, that
This does not qualify her to teach school. I beg of you, if she cannot be got rid of in any other way, to close the school. It can easily be opened again when a suitable teacher is obtained.

Please do not let it be known to my Church that I have written you in this strain: a man in my position has enough to contend with without having all his 'betters' down on him.

If you care at all for the welfare and progress of our Indians, act immediately.

I have no doubt but that Charles Hughes, the Indian Agent at Saddle Lake, and Mr. Muckle, Inspector of Indian Schools, will substantiate my statements, should you apply to them.

I have the honour to be, Yours truly,

Under present conditions, I do not think that any teacher "even if fully qualified and competent to teach all school subjects" could make a success of teaching in the Day schools at this agency.

My candid opinion is, that the operation of the Day schools here is a farce. Since the opening of the Day schools, it has been a very hard matter to secure pupils for the Industrial schools as the attendance of the children at the Day schools furnishes the parents with a good excuse in refusing to send their children to an Industrial school.

In regard to securing a good attendance by giving the children a hot mid-day meal and clothing, I might say that I believe it to be quite true.

It appears to me that in some cases, the children attend school fairly regular, not so much for the purpose of learning as from a desire to eat, and I would therefore respectfully recommend that the furnishing of the mid-day meals be discontinued.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.
As requested in your letter of the 12th ultimo No. 116959/1, I have the honour to submit herewith, a report regarding school matters in connection with the Goodfish Lake Day School.

I have just returned from a trip to Whitefish Lake reserve and while there I made a special examination of this school and I regret very much to have to report that very slow progress is being made by the pupils.

In regard to Mrs. Howard's qualifications as a teacher, I might say that she has no certificate and while she may not be competent to teach school subjects, I am under the impression that even if she were, the results would be much the same.

The attendance at the Day schools is very irregular owing to the fact that whenever the Indians go hunting or visiting, they usually take the whole family along and they sometimes keep their children away from school for a considerable length of time.

As the children spend the greater part of their time at home, they hear very little English spoken outside of the school room, and as the Indians do not appear to have any great desire to have their children learn the English language, it is obvious that their home life is a detriment to their learning.

Goodfish Lake Indian Day School

The reference to the re-opening of the above school has been noted in your latest quarterly report. There was formerly a day school in operation at this point. It was closed in 1925, upon the recommendation of Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, the then Indian Agent, and the teacher of the school.

The attendance at this school for the six years from 1918 to 1924 had been unsatisfactory. Mr. Ostrander's letter recommending the closing of this school reads as follows:

"It is my opinion that the children who have been attending this day school could be recruited for the residential schools. The result would be favourable, both financially and educationally, in that the attendance at day schools is seldom very regular on account of the irregular habits of the parents."

There were at that time four day schools in operation in the Edmonton, Hobbsma and Saddle Lake Agencies,-

(a) Paul's, (b) Samson's, (c) Goodfish Lake,
(d) Saddle Lake.

It would be appreciated if you would draw the above to the attention of Mr. Laurie. We are quite prepared, however, to have you investigate further the possibility of re-opening this school on a temporary basis.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Colonel Neary:

Proposed school at GOODFISH LAKE
Saddle Lake Agency:

With Mr. Supt. Taylor I looked over possible sites on the reserve on the 10th inst. We had discussions with Councillor Thomas Jackson (father of ten) and a senior Indian, Peter Shirt, who is the local medicine dispenser.

Mr. Taylor is going to ask the heads of families on July 2nd to vote on two sites.

The top photo shows the more likely site. Mr. Taylor is shown at one corner of the United Church, looking across the road to a field used by an Indian, Charlie Hunter, who lives close by. The road curves around the fence beside the lake which is no more than thirty yards away. A shallow well seems possible.

Charlie Hunter, two of whose children are at school in Edmonton, professed his willingness to let the land be used for school purposes.

This site would serve more families more conveniently than the site shown in the lower pictures.

The site shown in this photo is about three-quarters of a mile north-west of the one above. It is on much higher ground, distant from the lake, and a deep well would likely be necessary. Its chief supporter is Mr. Peter Shirt who has no young children. The buildings shown are a granary and an implement shed. The projected farm instructor's house may be erected near here.

In the bottom photo the camera is pointed back toward the first site which is nearly a third of a mile to the left of the Catholic Church which appears in the background.

I did not see any gravel deposits nearby, but gravel is said to be available at reasonable cost.

There are several competent contractors and builders in St. Paul and neighbouring towns. Unskilled Indian labourers could be obtained.

There is a minister's house not far from the United Church, but the missionary lives in Saddle Lake. The teacher will definitely be isolated. There is a post-office (Goodfish Lake) off the reserve about two miles west, but communications are not good.

Goodfish Lake Indian Day School

We have now received Major Clark's report concerning educational facilities required on the Goodfish Lake Indian Reserve. We understand from his report that a vote will be held on July 2 to determine the site for the school.

Here again, we would make similar recommendations with regard to the construction of this school as for Alexander. It is noted from our official's report that there are several competent contractors and builders in St. Paul and other neighbouring towns. It is possible that Mr. Superintendent Taylor might interest one of them in the construction of this school. The normal rate which we pay for foremen-carpenters is $1.50 per hour. The blue-prints and specifications are very clear and we have had success with this mode of construction elsewhere. The Department would buy all materials and labour would be that provided locally or by using Indians. The other alternative again is that of interesting contractors in submitting a labour tender for the building. The Department would be responsible for the provision of all material. I might add for your information that similar labour tenders for this standard school have been obtained in Saskatchewan and Manitoba in amounts varying from $4,200.00 to $4,990.00, depending upon location.

I would suggest that you send two copies of the blue-prints and specifications for the standard school to Mr. Taylor so that he can discuss the matter with local builders.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

November 30, 1949.

Superintendent of Education:
Goodfish Lake Indian Day School:

With Mr. Field Agent Battle and Mr. Asst. Taylor I consulted the Bishop of St. Paul last night. The Reverend Principal of Blue Quills participated in the discussion.

The school is so situated that children of two religious denominations will find it convenient to attend. Some of these children are already at Blue Quills and Edmonton Residential schools. In some cases their parents may want them to attend the day school which will probably be ready to receive them after the Christmas vacation.

All aspects of the situation were surveyed and discussed, and agreement was reached on the following points:

As the majority of the band adhere to the United Church of Canada, the teacher must be (i) acceptable to that denomination, and not of a sect likely to be offensive to the Roman Catholic Church.

Only children in the first four grades are to attend this term. Grades above Grade Four will "carry on" at residential schools until further notice.

Children requiring residential facilities (in the judgment of the Department) will continue to be directed to residential schools regardless of school grade.

Roman Catholic parents living within the radius of the school may elect to which type of school their children shall go (if in the first four grades.) The Church authorities will not impose sanctions on those who patronize the day school.

The school will be conducted in the manner usual for provincial public schools, i.e., with time allowed for religious instruction by interested religious denominations.

The United Church missionary and the Chief (Ruben Bull) have been assured that the school will be conducted as above and in accordance with the Indian Act.

C.W. Clark

Progress made by the contractor erecting Goodfish Lake School indicates that the building may be ready to open in January. Major Clark's report of November 30th indicates the denomination of the teacher to be employed at this school. I have had the pleasure of meeting Mrs. A. C. Hughes, Welfare Teacher, who is at present supplying at the Morley Residential School until the United Church has secured the services of a teacher or until she is required as teacher in the Sioux Lookout Indian Hospital. I casually said to her that it was my hope that we would have more of her calibre as teachers in this province and on the strength of that she has written to say that she would like to remain in Alberta if there was a vacancy in a departmental day school. She states that even if she is required to go East, that she firmly intends to return to the West.

I understand that Mrs. Hughes is a Presbyterian and it is my belief that she should therefore be acceptable for the new Goodfish School, Saddle Lake Indian Agency, which should be opened in January. I do not know whether she would be interested in taking this school.

Would you kindly advise whether you would be prepared to accept an application from her, and if so, at what grade and salary. I will not answer her letter until I have heard from you.

Reference your 205/6-10 of December 6

I agree that Mrs. Hughes would be a good teacher at the Goodfish Lake School.

However, I am somewhat confused as to the religious denomination which is in the majority on this reserve. Our records show that there was formerly a Methodist school on this reserve. However, I understand from Major Clark's report of November 30 that 26 children are R.C. and 16 are U.C. Yet, in his report attached to these statistics, he states that the majority of the band adhere to the United Church of Canada. I presume from this that the R.C. parents have more children than the others.

I understand that Mr. Battle was present at the meeting with the Bishop of St. Paul and that they will permit their children to attend this school if the teacher is not of a sect likely to be offensive to them.

From your letter I would assume that Mrs. Hughes would fit this category and that she should be acceptable to everyone at Goodfish Lake. I also assume that this would be a welfare position and that Mrs. Hughes would consider transferring to this school. I agree that you should discuss this transfer with her and I am quite certain that approval can be obtained for her appointment to this school.

Goodfish Lake Indian Day School

Dear Bishop Baudaux:

I have received a report concerning the situation which exists with regard to the appointment of a teacher at this school. I believe that I can interest a teacher in a transfer and that she would be quite acceptable to all. This teacher is Mrs. A.C. Hughes, aged 56 years with a First Class Quebec Teaching Certificate. She was Principal of the Joliette Secondary School and taught History and Latin at the Verdun High School. She is a Protestant and has been teaching for us in the Miller Bay Hospital School at Prince Rupert, B.C. At that time we were unable to get a Catholic teacher and she was sent in and has done a good job.

She is a very energetic woman and will work hard with the children. She is genuinely interested in Indians and is presently filling in pending the completion of the Sioux Lookout Hospital School. However, she likes the west and I believe we could persuade her to take the Goodfish Lake School.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Sir:

I have the honour to state that we have not yet received from the Indian Department a cheque for the salary of the teacher at Goodfish Lake, Alberta, for the September quarter, 1913. I wrote to the teacher, Mrs. Florence Watters, in regard to the matter, and have received a reply from her to the effect that she sent forward the returns early in October through the Agent. She states that the school is never opened at that place early in September on account of the absence of the people and their having; that she has not taken any legal holidays since school opened and fully expects therefore to be able to make up the regular number of days for the year, which will entitle her to the full salary allowance.

I shall esteem it a favour if you will be good enough to look into the matter and let me know the reason we have not received the usual cheque for that quarter.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your Obedient Servant,

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo with reference to the salary of the teacher of the Goodfish Lake Day School for the September quarter, 1913.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to inform you that I am in receipt of a communication from Miss E.F. Ryckman, former teacher of the Goodfish Lake Indian Day school, in regard to payment of bonus. Miss Ryckman states that she has not received bonus for the months of April, May and June 1925 and wishes to know if this is to be paid her.

I might state that Miss Ryckman's address is "Mannville," Alberta.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.,
Ottawa, October 14, 1925.

SIR,-

In reply to your letter of the 2nd instant, regarding payment of bonus to Miss E. B. Ryckman, former teacher of the Goodfish Lake Indian Day School, for the quarter ended June 30th, last, I beg to say that payment of bonus was discontinued from March 31st, last.

Miss Ryckman's salary, however, was increased by $150.00 from April first which increase made her salary at the rate of $90.00 for each teaching month. A cheque for $270.00 in payment of the June quarter was sent to the treasurer of the Methodist Missionary Society, Toronto, and he will, no doubt, forward to Miss Ryckman the amount due her.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Russell T. Ferrier,
Gupt. of Indian Education.

J. P. B. Ostrander, Esq.,

Sept. 15th 1913

Dear Mr. Hughes,

You know something of the condition of the school teacher's house at Goodfish Lake. You know that one woman was carried out dying of consumption and another died there last year of consumption. The windows are all gone. The place is nothing to piece. Sam Bull used it to store his grain last winter (with my permission). The place should be pulled down and used for firewood.

Mr. Walter, the new teacher, and two little girls arrived on Saturday with the intention of going into that house. I would not allow an animal of mine to stay there.

Matthew Horle has a new log house partly built about 200 yards from the school. He will sell him for $95. It will cost about $150 to finish it up. It could easily be hauled up to the school lot.

Will you please telegraph the Dept.
and ask them if they will put $300 into a new house for the teacher. It will cost that by the time it is moved and finished.

Very sincerely yours,

L. Denier.

Hope Mrs. Hughes arrived home safe and sound. We enjoyed her visit very much.
heartly built that he would move up here & ready for occupation for $500.00. We could have it ready for use in two weeks time. It is a log building 18' x 29' & he should finish it off with shingle roof, two floors, doors & windows plaster & whitewash for above figure. Would you not telegraph the Dept. the state of affairs here & ask for permission for this plan to be rushed through. The house here is unsanitary & unsafe to live in. Mr. Queen is writing you & believe I giving

the view of the matter I intend to open school on Wednesday or will camp at Zooskish until we hear from the Dept.

I will need biscuits for the school. I believe the Dept. intends to provide a hot midday meal for the children & so they will notify you as to what they wish sent for it.

Yours sincerely,

Mrs Florence Walters

Sept. 15th, 1913.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

Mrs. Watters and family arrived on Saturday. I had no idea she had a family and thought she would be able to stay with us. The school teacher's house at Goodfish Lake is unfit for anyone to live in. I would not use it for a stable.

One of the Indians started to build a new log house last year but never finished it. He would sell it for $95.00. It would cost about $200 more to move it and finish it. It would be a good thing to buy this and move it up for the school teacher to live in.......

Mrs. Aldritt died of consumption in the old house. Mrs. Perrion was carried out dying of consumption. The windows are all gone and the place is rotting to pieces. It should be burned. Mrs. Watters is going to try to live in one room until she hears what is going to be done. I want her to stay here but she feels that it is too far from the school. It is too far for her to walk and her nerves will not allow her to drive, so there is nothing else to be done.

Please let me hear from you soon. Kind regards to you all.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd) L. Dineen
Whitefish Lake, Alta.,
Sept. 15th., 1913.

Dear Mr. Perrier,

We arrived at Goodfish Lake after an eight days' drive and found the house in a dreadful condition. We are practically outdoors. There is not a single window pane in the house and scarcely a frame. The house is unsanitary and unsafe to live in. I have moved into an out kitchen after disinfecting it, but cannot unpack until some arrangements are made for a home. I have written Mrs. Hughes asking him to telegraph the Department the state of affairs here and ask permission for the following plan to be carried out:

Matthew Houle, an Indian near by, has a log house partly built, 18 by 19, and he would move in on to the land here and fit it up comfortable and complete for $200, with shingle roof, two floors, windows, door, etc., plaster and whitewash. This seems reasonable, as material has to be teamed from Vegreville, a distance of 50 miles. He could have the house ready in about two weeks and this seems the only plan that could be carried out without delay.

There is every prospect of a good attendance and I feel sure if we can be settled comfortably that the work will prosper. I intend to open school on the 17th. as soon as I can have it cleaned and ready. I hope the matter will be attended to without delay for you cannot imagine the condition of things here and the weather is already becoming chilly.

I will let you know how we progress. I feel sure all will be well.

Kind regards to all,

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd.) (Mrs. F. Watters)

Dept. of Indian Affairs

Dear sir,

I wish to explain how the amount granted in the Dept. The $300.00 sent in of the house finished by the Indians only meant a house with single floors, no ceiling partitions, inside finish, cellar or closet. It was simply a log house mudded & whitemudded with 2 single floors, shingle roof & windows & one door. This would have answered for a time in the case of emergency but would have needed finishing off later on. The house as it stood with sheathing on the roof & one floor & windows cut out cost $93.50 & was purchased for that amount; the moving cost $30.00 which was very reasonable. I do not know the exact cost of the material for finishing inside & out but the house, moving, material & freight must already exceed the grant. The house intended to be cottoned, burlapped & papered this will make a durable finish. The building when completed will be very comfortable. The school is proving very successful & I do not feel that the Dept. will mind the extra outlay toward finishing the house. The labor is being done very reasonable. We spent in the first estimate of the building $600 an explanation to the Dept. but I feel sure you will see the building is being completed as reasonably possible considering how far everything has been freighted &c.

Yours sincerely,
Florence Watters

Sirs:

I have the honour to enclose herewith a report on a form of the inspection of the Good Fish mid-day meal day school.

There is no well in connection with this school or with the teacher's new residence. Mrs. Waters stated that one was required and may have so informed the Department direct. If it is decided to get a well sunk I respectfully suggest that the well be carried up about 20' or 24' above the grade and the required water elevated with a rope and a bucket. If a pump is supplied it is likely to be out of repair about half the time and the agent called upon frequently to supply repairs and keep it in order—almost an impossible task with so many operators of the pump.

I was shown the plan of the proposed new school plan calling for a building 28' x 36' and a lean-to 20' x 40'. The Indians claim that logs sufficiently long cannot be obtained for such a building, not easily, anyway. Moreover, the saw carriage is limited to about 24'. The roof of the lean-to has very little fall.

Yours obediently,

J.A. Markle,
Insp.

Sir:

I have written through Sir Hughes, asking if the Dept is willing to supply grass seed for our school grounds at Whitefish Lake. We had the grounds all prepared for seed last fall. There is about an acre to seed.

The seed catalogue calls for 100 lbs per acre, according to this we will need 100 lbs of seed to make a good lawn. At present there is not any good place for the children to play & they track the mud in dreadfully in wet weather. It is impossible to keep either the children or school clean. Hoping to receive a reply as soon as possible.

Sir,

Mrs. H. H. Howard, teacher of the Goodfish Lake school, states that there is not any good place for the children to play and that they track in mud in wet weather.

Kindly let the Department have an estimate of the cost of filling in the grounds with sand or gravel and also state whether you consider this would improve the conditions complained of.

O. E. Hughes, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Saddle Lake, Alta.
Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 15th ultimo, No. 116959/1, regarding cost of filling in the grounds with sand and gravel at Goodfish Lake school, I have the honour to inform you that I do not think that filling in the grounds as suggested would improve the conditions complained of.

I am of the opinion that if the land broken around the school buildings was seeded down to grass it would prove more satisfactory than the filling in as the grounds thereabout are fairly level and any levelling which the grounds would require could be done with a drag. I do not consider that the school grounds require filling in with sand and gravel.

The cost of levelling the grounds with a drag and seeding down to grass would be about $12.00.

The children tracking the mud into the school is almost unavoidable as the road passes in front of the school and that is where they spend most of their playtime. The teacher could prevent this to a certain extent by having the children clean their shoes on a door mat before allowing them to enter the school.

I have the honour to be

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Mr. Sinclair's marginal notation dated the 29th ultimo on Mr. Hoey's memorandum to you of July 27th last, asks for a report on the above school, for which a tender of $17,985.00 had been received by Indian Affairs from the Alberta Construction Company of Edmonton.

It is a typical one roomed school, with combined teacher's accommodation without water supply inside toilet or electrical facilities, the latter being services usually supplied by Indian Affairs, apart from the contract.

The Indian Affairs Branch, on Departmental authority, have been carrying out construction of one and two roomed schools, for the past two years, from drawings and specifications furnished by our architectural section, on their own responsibility; relying on advice and guidance from this Division, but handling the securing of tenders, awards of contracts and financing, themselves.

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1948-49 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to construct a combined one-room Indian day school and teacher's residence on the Alexander's Indian Reserve, Edmonton Indian Agency, Province of Alberta;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Alexander's Indian Reserve and living quarters for one Indian day school teacher;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C., 1927, provides, in part as follows:

PRECIS FOR THE CLERK OF THE PRIVY COUNCIL:

Memorandum:

- DEPUTY MINISTER -

Alexander Indian Day School.

Included in our Main Estimates for 1948-49 is the sum for the construction of a one-room Indian Day School and attached teacher's residence on the Alexander's Indian Reserve, Edmonton Indian Agency.

Mr. Indian Superintendent Robertson and Mr. Regional Supervisor Gooderham made several attempts to interest contractors in the erection of this building. Finally on July 14th a tender was received from the Alberta Construction Company Limited of Edmonton, Alberta offering to erect a school for the sum of $17,985.00.

This tender was submitted to our Lands and Development Services Branch for consideration and their reply read in part as follows:

"While of course the urgency for the need of particular buildings, must determine whether or not a tender is accepted by the Indian Affairs Branch, when only one tender can be obtained we do not consider a recommendation in excess of $14,000.00 for a school of this type is justified for the proposed Alexander Day School, and recommend Mr. Hoey be so advised."

Mr. Gooderham was advised of the Chief Engineer. Shortly after this, we received word from the Principal of the Youville Residential School they would be unable to accept Indian pupils as they, in future, to serve as an old peoples home. Fortunately foreseen this and had erected two Indian Day Schools Michel and Stony Plain Reserves to provide educational facilities for the children who formerly attended the Residential School.
However, as indicated above, we have not been able to obtain a satisfactory tender for the erection of the third school required, namely that on the Alexander's Reserve. Therefore, we again had Mr. Indian Superintendent Robertson approach contractors in the vicinity of Edmonton. He approached four companies, namely, The Alberta Construction Company, Poole Construction Company, (who had previously built the Stony Plain and Michel Day Schools for us on a cost plus ten percent basis) Bennett & White Construction Company and Kingsway Construction Company. We have today received an air mail letter from Mr. Regional Supervisor Gooderham in which he reports as follows on Mr. Superintendent Robertson's attempts to interest contractors:

"Superintendent Robertson has submitted two tenders for the construction of this school on the basis of estimated costs plus fee of 10%, they are attached as follows:

Alberta Construction Co. $15,495.00 plus fee of 10%
Poole Construction Co. Estimated cost $20,000.00

Mr. Robertson reports that the Poole Construction Co. only submitted a tender after some persuasion and that two other firms, Bennett & White Construction Co. and Kingsway Construction, refused to bid.

It is hoped that the department will now be in a position to proceed with the construction of this school, Mr. Robertson should be advised by "Air Mail" direct with copy to this office".

Please find attached the two tenders submitted as indicated above. I have also had prepared a Submission to Council recommending the acceptance of the tender of the Alberta Construction Company for the following two reasons:

(a) This company's tender is the lower
(b) Because this company has done satisfactory work for the Agency Division at the Hobbema Agency
The urgency of this situation can best be illustrated by the following comments from Mr. Gooderham:

"However, it is a serious matter for those from the Alexander Band; there are a number of children from this Band who would attend and their parents want them in school.

I suggest that the day school on this reserve be erected as quickly as possible. In order to accomplish this, it may be necessary to accept an offer to build it at a figure much higher than originally estimated or if need be, to accept an offer on a cost plus basis. You will no doubt have found it impossible to keep within your estimate for schools and still carry out your program owing to the steadily mounting costs. In this province up to the moment no contracts have been placed so far as I am aware and it is not because our superintendents have not tried to get bids".

Acting Director.

It is understood and agreed, however, that the Contractor shall notify His Majesty immediately upon placing each order for material to be used in connection with the work upon which a cash discount will accrue, for the purpose of enabling His Majesty to take advantage of such cash discount, if His Majesty deems it advisable, by advancing funds to the Contractor to cover such above-mentioned orders or by paying for such orders out of funds set aside by His Majesty for that purpose, and upon His Majesty advancing such funds to the Contractor to cover such above-mentioned orders, the Contractor shall apply them so that the cash discounts thereon will be obtained. 2. SUCCESSORS AND ASSIGNS.

This contract shall endure to the benefit of all and shall be binding upon the heirs, executors, administrators or successors and assigns (subject as hereinafter provided) of the Contractor and the successors of His Majesty; provided that the Contractor shall not be entitled to assign or sublet this contract or any of the work except as herein expressly provided.

3. QUALITY OF WORK.

The work shall be performed by the Contractor using the best materials and finished in the best and most workmanlike manner, and in strict conformity with the contract, and to the complete satisfaction of the Indian Agent and the Minister, and at such places as the Indian Agent shall, from time to time, direct.

4. TIME.

Time shall be deemed to be material and of the essence of this contract.

5. CHANGES IN THE WORK.

The Minister may, through the Indian Agent from time to time, by written instruction or drawings issued to the Contractor, make changes in the work, issue additional instructions, require additional work or direct the omission of work previously ordered, and the provisions of the contract shall apply to all such changes, modifications and additions with the same effect as if they were embodied in the contract plans, drawings and specifications.

Instructions shall be deemed to have been duly given to the Contractor if given to the Superintendent or to a foreman of the Contractor on the work, or if given to the Contractor personally or, if the Contractor is a firm or corporation, to a member of such firm or officer of such corporation.

If there is any change in the work, the Minister shall decide if there has been such a material increase or decrease in the scope of the work so that an adjustment should be made in the Contractor's fee and the Minister's decision on the adjustment to be made shall be final.
6. INDIAN AGENT SOLE JUDGE OF WORK AND MATERIALS.

The Indian Agent shall be the sole judge of the work and materials, in respect of both quality and quantity, and his decision on all questions in dispute with regard thereto, or as to the meaning or intentions of the contract or as to the meaning or interpretation of the plans, drawings and specifications shall be final, and no work under the contract shall be deemed to have been performed, nor materials or things provided, so as to entitle the Contractor to payment therefor unless and until the Indian Agent is satisfied therewith, as evidenced by his certificate in writing, which certificate shall be a condition precedent to the right of the contractor to be paid therefor; provided that any such decision may be altered or cancelled by the Minister.

7. WORK SUBJECT TO CONTROL OF INDIAN AGENT.

The work shall, in every particular, be under and subject to the control and supervision of the Indian Agent.

8. FOREMAN OF WORKS.

A competent foreman shall be kept on the ground by the Contractor during working hours, to receive the orders of the Indian Agent. Such foreman shall be considered as the lawful representative of the Contractor and shall carry out all requisitions and instructions of the Indian Agent.

9. DEFECTIVE WORK OR MATERIAL.

Should the Contractor use or employ or intend to use or employ, any material, plant, tools equipment, articles or things, which, in the opinion of the Indian Agent, are not in accordance with the provisions of the contract or are in any way unsuitable for the work, or any part thereof, or should the Indian Agent consider that any work is for any reason, improperly, defectively, or insufficiently executed or performed, the Indian Agent may order the Contractor to remove the same, or to use and employ other material, plant, tools, equipment, articles and things or to properly re-execute and perform such work, as the case may be, and thereupon the Contractor shall immediately comply with such orders and if the Contractor fails to comply with such orders within twenty-four hours the Indian Agent may, at any time thereafter, execute or cause to be executed the orders so given.

10. CONSUMABLE TOOLS, MATERIALS AND SUPPLIES.

All usable tools (other than tools customarily provided by tradesmen) and all consumable materials and supplies left over after the completion of the work shall, if the Minister so desires, be taken over and be paid for by the Contractor at a fair and reasonable price to be determined by the Minister.

11. WORK NOT COMPRISED IN CONTRACT.

His Majesty may, at any time, without payment therefor, send and employ on, in and about the work other contractors and workmen, with such horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things as the Indian Agent may deem necessary to do any work not comprised in the contract, and the Contractor shall afford them all reasonable facilities, to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent, for doing such work, the work of the Contractor being interfered with as little as the Indian Agent may deem practicable.
The taking of possession of the whole or any part of the work of the Contractor for such purpose shall not be deemed in accordance by or on behalf of His Majesty of the whole or any portion of the work comprised in this contract.

with respect thereto in or under this contract, or should the Contractor become insolvent or abandon the work or make an assignment of this contract without the consent required or otherwise fail to observe and perform any of the provisions of the contract, then and in any of such cases, the Minister, for and on behalf of His Majesty, and without any further authorization, may take all the work out of the Contractor's hands and may employ such means as he may see fit to complete the work, and in such cases the Contractor shall have no claim for any further payment on account of the fee stipulated to be payable to the Contractor for the respect of work performed, but shall be chargeable with, and shall remain liable for all loss and damage which may be suffered by His Majesty by reason of such default, or delay, or the non-completion by the Contractor of the work, and all horses, machinery, tools, plant and equipment, and all rights proprietary or otherwise, licences, powers of the contract may be used, exercised and enjoyed by His Majesty, for the purpose of carrying out the work as fully to all intents and purposes as they might theretofore have been used, exercised and enjoyed by the Contractor.

(a) All items comprised in any Government issue supplied to the Contractor for the purposes of the contract shall always be and remain the property of His Majesty and shall be used by the Contractor solely for the purposes of the contract and the Contractor shall account fully to the Minister for such Government issue in such manner as the Minister may require.

The Contractor shall take special precautions to prevent fire occurring in or about the work, and shall observe and comply with all laws and regulations in force respecting fires, and with all regulations and instructions made and given from time to time during construction, by the Indian Agent with respect to fires and the prevention and extinguishing of fires.

The Contractor shall not assign or sublet the contract without the written consent of the Minister first obtained; provided however, that (unless, in any case, the Minister objects thereto and subject also as herein provided) the Contractor may sublet such portions of the work herein contracted for as is customary and usual in the construction of such work, but His Majesty shall not in any way be held liable for the payment of any moneys due to any subcontractor, and the Contractor shall be held responsible for the proper performance of every portion of the work herein contracted for.

17. SUB-CONTRACTORS

The Contractor shall, before entering into any sub-contracts for work or materials, notify the Indian Agent in writing of the names of all such proposed sub-contractors and the terms and conditions of such sub-contracts and shall not enter into any such sub-contracts without obtaining the approval of the Indian Agent thereto.

The Indian Agent may, on request, furnish to any sub-contractor wherever practicable, evidence of the amounts certified to on his account.

The Contractor agrees to bind every sub-contractor by the terms of the General Conditions, Drawings and Specifications, as far as applicable to his work.

No member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of the contract, or to any benefit to arise therefrom.

19. ACCOUNTS

The Contractor shall keep proper accounts and records in such form and detail as shall be satisfactory to the Minister of the cost to the Contractor of the work and the invoices, receipts and vouchers relating thereto, and such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers shall at all times be open to audit and inspection by the Minister or his authorized representatives (who may make copies thereof and take extracts therefrom) and the Contractor shall afford all proper facilities for such audits and inspections and shall furnish the Minister and his authorized representative with all such information as he or they may from time to time require with reference to such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers. If any part of the work is performed by an allied firm (as defined herein) the Contractor shall cause such allied firm to keep similar accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers with respect to the cost of the work performed by such allied firm and to permit the same to be inspected and audited by the authorized representatives of the Minister. The Contractor shall cause all such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers as aforesaid to be preserved and kept available for audit and inspection at any time and from time to time until the expiration of five (5) years from the date of the termination of the work.

20. WORK TO BE FREE FROM ALL ENCUMBERANCES

Before making any payment on any progress or final estimate the Minister may require the Contractor to furnish evidence that all work performed, and material supplied and all structures built for which payment is being made are free and clear from all lawful claims or liens under any law for labour, workmanship, materials or otherwise; the Contractor shall indemnify and hold harmless His Majesty from and against any and all kinds of claims or liens accruing from labour and services performed and material furnished or otherwise, and any of the same in or about the works.

(a) His Majesty shall indemnify the Contractor against all actions, claims or proceedings for infringement of any patent or industrial design rights or of any alleged patent or industrial design rights (hereinafter referred to as "patent rights") in carrying out his contract, and for royalties or other payments which may be payable in connection with any such patent rights (including any amounts properly payable by the Contractor to any of its subcontractors pursuant to any similar covenant of indemnity given by the Contractor to any sub-contractor), in respect of anything the model, plan or design of which shall have been provided by or on behalf of His Majesty, but this indemnity shall apply to this contract only.

(b) Save and except as set forth in sub-section (a) of this section, the Contractor shall indemnify His Majesty against all actions, claims or proceedings for infringement of any patent rights and for royalties or other payments which may be payable in connection with any such patent rights in carrying out this contract.

(d) If and when the Minister shall so direct, the Contractor shall make no payment by way of royalties or otherwise with respect to any patent rights referred to in any statement furnished by the Contractor as provided in sub-section (c) of this section, except with the consent of the Minister and subject to such conditions as the Minister may impose and from and after the giving of any such direction by the Minister, His Majesty shall indemnify the Contractor against any action, claim or proceeding for infringement of the patent rights covered by such direction or for non-payment of royalties or other payments in respect thereof.

The Contractor shall comply with, and the work shall be carried on subject to all regulations made by any lawful authority and applicable to said work, and all orders given by the Indian Agent with respect to sanitation or preservation of health on the work. The Contractor shall protect, and shall not remove or destroy, or permit to be removed or destroyed, the stakes, buoys and other marks placed on or about the said work by the Indian Agent or his assistants, and shall furnish the necessary assistance to correct or replace any stake, buoy or mark which through any cause may have been removed or destroyed.

24. NOTICES

Any notice, order, direction or other communication given to the Contractor under any of the provisions of this contract shall be sufficiently given if delivered to the Contractor personally, or to his foreman, or left at the Contractor's office, or mailed at any post office to the Contractor or foreman addressed to the address mentioned in the contract, or to the Contractor's last known place of business or residence.

25. PROGRESS MEASUREMENTS AND CERTIFICATES NOT BINDING

The progress measurements and progress certificates shall not in any respect be taken as binding upon the Indian Agent or as final measurements or as fixing final amounts; they are to be subject to the revision of the Indian Agent in making up his final certificate, and they shall not in any respect be taken as an acceptance of the work or as a release of the Contractor from responsibility in respect thereof.
26. PROTECTION OF WORK

The Contract and all information issued in connection therewith are confidential and their use must be strictly confined to the work and to the purpose of the contract; and particulars contained therein; and other matter issued in connection therewith, must not be disclosed to unauthorized persons.

The Contractor shall at all times take and cause to be taken all reasonable measures, for the protection of the work against espionage and sabotage, and on the order of the Minister shall dispense with the services of any person employed in, about or upon the work or cause the same to be dispensed with. The Minister shall at all times through such agency as he may see fit be entitled to maintain on or about the premises where the work or any part thereof is being carried on such police or other protective force as in the opinion of the Minister may be advisable.

To the full extent that the same are procurable, only Canadian labour, parts and materials (unless otherwise agreed by the Minister) shall be used in connection with the work.

In engaging labour for the work contemplated by this contract, either from the National Employment Service or from Trade Unions with which the contractor has collective agreements, the contractor shall specify that preference shall be given to competent and available ex-service men.

The contractor shall maintain and keep available for inspection by the Minister a record of the names and addresses of ex-service men employed, together with a record of the steps taken to implement this requirement.

28. SALARIES

The salaries payable to engineers, superintendents, draftsmen and foremen shall only be such as shall be approved by the Minister.

(a) Notwithstanding anything in this contract contained the Minister may, by giving notice to the Contractor, terminate the contract (save and except the provisions of this section and of Section 19 of these general conditions) as regards all or any part or parts of the work or works not theretofore completed. (b) All work completed by the Contractor under or pursuant to the provisions of the contract before or after the giving of any notice, subject to acceptance by His Majesty in accordance with the provisions of the contract, shall be paid for on the basis provided in the agreement (the Contractor being allowed such fraction of his
stipulated fee as shall be proportionate to the amount of the work theretofore completed) and the Contractor shall be entitled to be reimbursed the actual cost to the contractor of work not completed under or pursuant to the provisions of this contract and/or any notice given pursuant thereto plus a fair and reasonable profit in respect of work done thereon, provided that no reimbursement shall be made for materials which have been or may be rejected after inspection as not complying with the terms and conditions of this contract and the specifications.

(d) The said fee referred to in subsections (b) and (c) hereof shall be deemed to cover the entire profits of the Contractor and the necessary services of all executive officers of the Contractor and also all overhead expenses of the Contractor at its normal offices and at any regularly established branch office, including but without limiting the generality of the foregoing the services of the purchasing, accounting, estimating and contract departments at such general offices or regularly established branch office.

It is understood and agreed, however, that the Contractor shall notify His Majesty immediately upon placing each order for material to be used in connection with the work upon which a cash discount will accrue, for the purpose of enabling His Majesty to take advantage of such cash discount, if His Majesty deems advisable, by advancing funds to the Contractor to cover such above-mentioned orders or by paying for such orders out of funds set aside by His Majesty for that purpose, and upon His Majesty advancing such funds to the Contractor to cover such above-mentioned orders, the Contractor shall agree that such cash discounts thereon will be obtained. Provided always, however, that if His Majesty fails to provide funds to the Contractor to cover such orders or fails to pay for same as provided for above, the Contractor shall be entitled to the benefit of all such discounts in respect of purchases made by it with its own funds of materials required for the carrying out of this contract. It is understood that His Majesty may supply the Contractor with materials or may make available to the Contractor funds with which to purchase materials required for the purposes of this contract and any and all materials or funds so supplied or made available shall be used by the Contractor solely for the purposes of this contract.

LISTS OF MATERIALS AND EQUIPMENT SUPPLIERS.

(d) "Specifications" means any and all specifications, plans and/or drawings at any time furnished for the carrying out of this contract, including the specifications, plans and/or drawings (if any) referred to in the agreement.

(g) "Work" means the work done or required to be done by the Contractor, and when the context permits, includes labour and materials shown or described in the specifications;

(i) "Government Issue" means all materials, machinery, tools and/or equipment (if any) which may be supplied by His Majesty to the Contractor for the purposes of the work and includes also any specifications supplied to the Contractor for the said purposes, provided however, that the Contractor shall not be entitled to be supplied with any Government issue except as and to the extent (if any) specifically provided in the agreement;

(j) "other contractor" means any person, firm or corporation employed by, or having a contract directly or indirectly with, the Minister otherwise than through the Contractor;
