2. SUCCESSORS AND ASSIGNS.

This contract shall endure to the benefit of all and shall be binding upon the heirs, executors, administrators or successors and assigns (subject as hereinafter provided) of the Contractor and the successors of His Majesty; provided that the Contractor shall not be entitled to assign or sublet this contract or any of the work except as herein expressly provided.

3. QUALITY OF WORK.

The work shall be performed by the Contractor using the best materials and finished in the best and most workmanlike manner, and in strict conformity with the contract, and to the complete satisfaction of the Indian Agent and the Minister, and at such places as the Indian Agent shall, from time to time, direct.

4. TIME.

Time shall be deemed to be material and of the essence of this contract.

5. CHANGES IN THE WORK.

The Minister may, through the Indian Agent from time to time, by written instruction or drawings issued to the Contractor, make changes in the work, issue additional instructions, require additional work or direct the omission of work previously ordered, and the provisions of the contract shall apply to all such changes, modifications and additions with the same effect as if they were embodied in the contract plans, drawings and specifications.

Instructions shall be deemed to have been duly given to the Contractor if given to the Superintendent or to a foreman of the Contractor on the work, or if given to the Contractor personally or, if the Contractor is a firm or corporation, to a member of such firm or officer of such corporation.

If there is any change in the work, the Minister shall decide if there has been such a material increase or decrease in the scope of the work so that an adjustment should be made in the Contractor's fee and the Minister's decision on the adjustment to be made shall be final.
6. INDIAN AGENT SOLE JUDGE OF WORK AND MATERIALS.

The Indian Agent shall be the sole judge of the work and material, in respect of both quality and quantity, and his decision on all questions in dispute with regard thereto, or as to the meaning or interpretation of the contract and as to the meaning or interpretation of the plans, drawings and specifications shall be final, and no work under the contract shall be deemed to have been performed, nor materials or things provided, so as to entitle the Contractor to payment therefor unless and until the Indian Agent is satisfied therewith, as evidenced by his certificate in writing, which certificate shall be a condition precedent to the right of the contractor to be paid therefor; provided that any such decision may be altered or cancelled by the Minister.

7. WORK SUBJECT TO CONTROL OF INDIAN AGENT.

The work shall, in every particular, be under and subject to the control and supervision of the Indian Agent.

8. FOREMAN OF WORKS.

A competent foreman shall be kept on the ground by the Contractor during working hours, to receive the orders of the Indian Agent. Such foreman shall be considered as the lawful representative of the Contractor and shall carry out all requisitions and instructions of the Indian Agent.

9. DEFECTIVE WORK OR MATERIAL.

Should the Contractor use or employ or intend to use or employ, any material, plant, tools equipment, articles or things, which, in the opinion of the Indian Agent, are not in accordance with the provisions of the contract or are in any way unsuitable for the work, or any part thereof, or should the Indian Agent consider that any work is for any reason, improperly, defectively, or insufficiently executed or performed, the Indian Agent may order the Contractor to remove the same, and to use and employ proper material, plant, tools, equipment, articles and things or to properly re-execute and perform such work, as the case may be, and thereupon the Contractor shall immediately comply with such orders and if the Contractor fails to comply with such orders within twenty-four hours the Indian Agent may, at any time thereafter, execute or cause to be executed the orders so given.

10. CONSUMABLE TOOLS, MATERIALS AND SUPPLIES.

All usable tools (other than tools customarily provided by tradesmen) and all consumable materials and supplies left over after the completion of the work shall, if the Minister so desires, be taken over and be paid for by the Contractor at a fair and reasonable price to be determined by the Minister.

11. WORK NOT COMPRISED IN CONTRACT.

His Majesty may, at any time, without payment therefor, send and employ on, in and about the work other contractors, and workmen, with such horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things as the Indian Agent may deem necessary to do any work not comprised in the contract, and the Contractor shall afford them all reasonable facilities, to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent, for doing such work, the work of the Contractor being interfered with as little as the Indian Agent may deem practicable.
The taking of possession of the whole or any part of the work of the Contractor for such purpose shall not be deemed in acceptance by or on behalf of His Majesty of the whole or any portion of the work comprised in this contract.

12. POWER TO TAKE WORK FROM CONTRACTOR.

In case the Contractor shall make default or delay in commencing, or in diligently executing any of the work or portions thereof to be performed, or that may be ordered under the contract, to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent, the Indian Agent may give a general notice to the Contractor requiring him to put an end to such default or delay, and should such default or delay continue for seven days after such notice shall have been given by the Indian Agent to the Contractor, or should the Contractor make default in completion of the work or any portion thereof, within the time limited with respect thereto in this contract, or should the Contractor become insolvent or abandon the work or make an assignment of this contract without the consent required or otherwise fail to observe and perform any of the provisions of the contract, then and in any of such cases, the Minister, for and on behalf of His Majesty, and without any further authorization, may take all the work out of the Contractor's hands and may employ such means as he may see fit to complete the work, and in such cases the Contractor shall have no claim for any further payment on account of the fee stipulated to be payable to the Contractor or in respect of work performed, but shall be chargeable with, and shall remain liable for all loss and damage which may be suffered by His Majesty by reason of such default, or delay, or the non-completion by the Contractor of the work, and all horizons, machinery, tools, plant and equipment, and all rights proprietary or otherwise, licences, powers and privileges, whether relating to or affecting real estate or personal property, acquired, possessed or provided by the Contractor for the purposes of the work, or by the Indian agent under the provision of the contract may be used, exercised and enjoyed by His Majesty, for the purpose of carrying out the work as fully to all intents and purposes as they might theretofore have been used, exercised and enjoyed by the Contractor.

13. INSURANCE.

(a) The Contractor, unless otherwise instructed by the Minister shall insure all materials, equipment and the Contractor's plant during transit and at all times during the construction and until the final acceptance of the work and shall keep the same and all buildings and structures being constructed and/or erected insured against loss by fire, in such insurance company or companies and in such amount or amounts as may be approved of by the Indian Agent and the policies of such insurance shall be made payable as the interests of the Contractor and His Majesty, as respectively, appear, and the original policies together with certified copies thereof shall be forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch provided that such buildings or structures need not be insured by the Contractor from and after the date of the occupation thereof by His Majesty.

(b) The Contractor shall maintain such insurance as will protect him from claims under the Workmen's Compensation Acts and from any other claims for damages for personal injury, including death, which may arise from his operations under the Contract. Certificates of such insurance shall be forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch.
and shall be subject to their approval as to adequacy of protection; and the Contractor shall indemnify and save harmless His Majesty from and against all claims and demands, loss, costs, damages, actions quits or other proceedings by whomsoever made, brought or prosecuted in any manner based upon, occasioned by, or attributable to any such death, or injury, or any damage to, or infringement of, any property or right.

14. GOVERNMENT ISSUE

(a) All items comprised in any Government issue supplied to the Contractor for the purposes of the contract shall always be and remain the property of His Majesty and shall be used by the Contractor solely for the purposes of the contract and the Contractor shall account fully to the Minister for such Government issue in such manner as the Minister may require.

(b) The Contractor shall be responsible for and shall indemnify His Majesty for all loss or damage of or to any and all such Government issue while on the premises of or in the care or subject to the control of the Contractor and shall at its own expense replace, repair or restore to the complete satisfaction of the Minister any and all such Government issue which may be so lost or damaged; provided that the Contractor shall not be obligated to make good damage caused by reasonable wear and tear or due to causes beyond his control.

15. PRECAUTIONS AGAINST FIRE

The Contractor shall take special precautions to prevent fire occurring in or about the work, and shall observe and comply with all laws and regulations in force respecting fires, and with all regulations and instructions made and given from time to time during construction, by the Indian Agent with respect to fires and the prevention and extinguishing of fires.

16. ASSIGNMENTS

The Contractor shall not assign or sublet the contract without the written consent of the Minister first obtained; provided however, that (unless, in any case, the Minister objects thereto and subject also as herein provided) the Contractor may sublet any portions of the work herein contracted for as is customary and usual in the construction of such work, but His Majesty shall not in any way be held liable for the payment of any moneys due to any subcontractor, and the Contractor shall be held responsible for the proper performance of every portion of the work herein contracted for.

17. SUB-CONTRACTORS

The Contractor shall, before entering into any sub-contracts for work or materials, notify the Indian Agent in writing of the names of all such proposed sub-contractors and the terms and conditions of such sub-contracts and shall not enter into any such sub-contracts without obtaining the approval of the Indian Agent thereto.

The Indian Agent may, on request, furnish to any sub-contractor wherever practicable, evidence of the amounts certified to on his account.

The Contractor agrees to bind every sub-contractor by the terms of the General Conditions, Drawings and Specifications, as far as applicable to his work.
18. MEMBER OF H. OF C. NOT TO BENEFIT

No member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of the contract, or to any benefit to arise therefrom.

19. ACCOUNTS

The Contractor shall keep proper accounts and records in such form and detail as shall be satisfactory to the Minister of the cost to the Contractor of the work and the invoices, receipts and vouchers relating thereto, and such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers shall at all times be open to audit and inspection by the Minister and his authorized representatives (who may make copies thereof and take extracts therefrom) and the Contractor shall afford all proper facilities for such audits and inspections and shall furnish the Minister and his authorized representative with all such information as he or they may from time to time require with reference to such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers. If any part of the work is performed by an allied firm (as defined herein) the Contractor shall also cause such allied firm to keep similar accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers with respect to the cost of the work performed by such allied firm, and to permit the same to be inspected and audited by the authorized representatives of the Minister. The Contractor shall cause all such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers as aforesaid to be preserved and kept available for audit and inspection at any time and from time to time until the expiration of five (5) years from the date of the termination of the work.

20. WORK TO BE FREE FROM ALL ENCUMBRANCES

Before making any payment on any progress or final estimate the Minister may require the Contractor to furnish evidence that all work performed, and material supplied and all structures built for which payment is being made are free and clear from all lawful claims or liens under any law for labour, workmanship, materials or otherwise; the Contractor shall indemnify and hold harmless His Majesty from and against any and all kinds of claims or liens accruing from labour and services performed and material furnished or otherwise, and any of the same in or about the works.

21. PATENT CLAIMS AND ROYALTIES

(a) His Majesty shall indemnify the Contractor against all actions, claims or proceedings for infringement of any patent or industrial design rights or of any alleged patent or industrial design rights (hereinafter referred to as "patent rights") in carrying out his contract and for royalties or other payments which may be payable in connection with any such patent rights (including any amounts properly payable by the Contractor to any of its sub-contractors pursuant to any similar covenant of indemnity given by the Contractor to any sub-contractor) in respect of anything the model, plan or design of which shall have been provided by or on behalf of His Majesty, but this indemnity shall apply to this contract only.

(b) Save and except as set forth in sub-section (a) of this section, the Contractor shall indemnify His Majesty against all actions, claims or proceedings for infringement of any patent rights and for royalties or other payments which may be payable in connection with any such patent rights in carrying out this contract.
(c) Before making any payments with respect to any patent rights, the Contractor shall supply to the Minister a statement showing all payments and claims for payment by way of royalties or otherwise which the Contractor or any of its subcontractors will or may be obligated to make or proposes to make to the owner or holder of any patent rights in connection with this contract, and the basis thereof and the parties to whom the same are payable, and shall from time to time promptly advise the Minister of any and all claims or arrangements made or proposed, which would or might result in further or different payments being made by the Contractor or any of its subcontractors by way of royalties or otherwise as aforesaid.

(d) If and when the Minister shall so direct, the Contractor shall make no payment by way of royalties or otherwise with respect to any patent rights referred to in any statement furnished by the Contractor as provided in sub-section (c) of this section, except with the consent of the Minister and subject to such conditions as the Minister may impose and from and after the giving of any such direction by the Minister, His Majesty shall indemnify the Contractor against any action, claim or proceeding for infringement of the patent rights covered by such direction or for non-payment of royalties or other payments in respect thereof.

22. SANITATION

The Contractor shall comply with, and the work shall be carried on subject to all regulations made by any lawful authority and applicable to said work, and all orders given by the Indian Agent with respect to sanitation or preservation of health on the work. The Contractor shall make adequate arrangements, to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent, for the medical and sanitary supervision of all his employees.

23. INDIAN AGENT'S MARKS

The Contractor shall protect, and shall not remove or destroy, or permit to be removed or destroyed, the stakes, buoys and other marks placed on or about the said work by the Indian Agent or his assistants, and shall furnish the necessary assistance to correct or replace any stake, buoy or mark which through any cause may have been removed or destroyed.

24. NOTICES

Any notice, order, direction or other communication given to the Contractor under any of the provisions of this contract shall be sufficiently given if delivered to the Contractor personally, or to his foreman, or left at the Contractor's office, or mailed at any post office to the Contractor or foreman addressed to the address mentioned in the contract, or to the Contractor's last known place of business or residence.

25. PROGRESS MEASUREMENTS AND CERTIFICATES NOT BINDING

The progress measurements and progress certificates shall not in any respect be taken as binding upon the Indian Agent or as final measurements or as fixing final amounts; they are to be subject to the revision of the Indian agent in making up his final certificate, and they shall not in any respect be taken as an acceptance of the work or as a release of the Contractor from responsibility in respect thereof.
26. PROTECTION OF WORK

The Contract and all information issued in connection therewith are confidential and their use must be strictly confined to the work and to the purpose of the contract; and particulars contained therein; and other matter issued in connection therewith, must not be disclosed to unauthorized persons.

The Contractor shall at all times take and cause to be taken all reasonable measures, for the protection of the work against espionage and sabotage, and on the order of the Minister shall dispense with the services of any person employed in or about or upon the work or cause the same to be dispensed with. The Minister shall at all times through such agency as he may see fit be entitled to maintain on or about the premises where the work or any part thereof is being carried on such police or other protective force as in the opinion of the Minister may be advisable.

27. CANADIAN WORK AND MATERIALS

To the full extent that the same are procurable, only Canadian labour, parts and materials (unless otherwise agreed by the Minister) shall be used in connection with the work.

27a. EMPLOYMENT OF EX-SERVICE MEN

In engaging labour for the work contemplated by this contract, either from the National Employment Service or from Trade Unions with which the contractor has collective agreements, the contractor shall specify that preference shall be given to competent and available ex-service men.

The contractor shall maintain and keep available for inspection by the Minister a record of the names and addresses of ex-service men employed, together with a record of the steps taken to implement this requirement.

28. SALARIES

The salaries payable to engineers, superintendents, draftsmen and foremen shall only be such as shall be approved by the Minister.

29. TERMINATION

(a) Notwithstanding anything in this contract contained the Minister may, by giving notice to the Contractor, terminate the contract (save and except the provisions of this section and of Section 19 of these general conditions) as regards all or any part or parts of the work or works not theretofore completed. Upon such notice being given, the Contractor shall cease work (including the procuring of materials for the fulfilment of the contract) in accordance with and to the extent specified in such notice but shall proceed with all reasonable speed to complete such part or parts (if any) of the work or works as are by the terms of such notice to be completed and shall also proceed with all reasonable speed to complete up to such time and/or stage as may be specified in the notice any part or parts of the work or works as required by such notice. The Minister may, at any time, or from time to time give one or more additional notices with respect to any or all parts of the work which remain to be completed after the giving of any previous notice or notices.

(b) All work completed by the Contractor under or pursuant to the provisions of the contract before or after the giving of any notice, subject to acceptance by His Majesty in accordance with the provisions of the contract, shall be paid for on the basis provided in the agreement (the Contractor being allowed such fraction of his
stipulated fee as shall be proportionate to the amount of the work thereafter completed) and the Contractor shall be entitled to be reimbursed the actual cost to the contractor of work not completed under or pursuant to the provisions of this contract and/or any notice given pursuant thereto plus a fair and reasonable profit in respect of work done thereon, provided that no reimbursement shall be made for materials which have been or may be rejected after inspection as not complying with the terms and conditions of this contract and the specifications.

(c) In the event that the Contractor and the Minister are unable to agree upon the amount in respect of which the Contractor is entitled to be reimbursed as aforesaid, the matter shall be referred to the Exchequer Court.

(d) Whenever practicable the Contractor shall procure materials required for the performance of the contract on terms that will enable it to terminate any contracts entered into by the Contractor upon conditions and terms similar in effect to those herein provided for in respect of termination by the Minister and the giving of a notice or notices as aforesaid; and generally the Contractor shall co-operate with His Majesty and the Minister and do everything reasonably within its power at all times to minimize and reduce the amount of His Majesty's obligations under the provisions of this section.

(e) Upon reimbursement being made to the Contractor as herein provided, title to the materials and/or work in progress in respect of which such reimbursement is made shall pass to and vest in His Majesty (the Contractor hereby agreeing to execute and deliver all requisite instruments by way of further assurance) and such materials and/or work in progress shall be delivered to the order of the Minister, but the materials thus taken over will in no case be in excess of what would have been required for performing the contract in full if no notice had been given under the provisions hereof.

(f) If it is established to the satisfaction of the Minister by the Contractor that by reason of any action taken by the Minister under the provisions of this section exceptional hardship has resulted to the Contractor then the Minister may, notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, in his absolute discretion grant such allowance (not to include in any case, however, any allowance or compensation for loss of profit) to the Contractor as, in the opinion of the Minister is warranted by the circumstances.

(g) Any action, decision or determination by the Minister under the provisions of this section shall be final and binding upon the Contractor.

(h) The Contractor shall have no claim for damages, compensation loss of profit, allowance or otherwise by reason of or directly or indirectly arising out of any action taken or notice given by the Minister under or pursuant to the provisions of this section except as and to the extent in this section expressly provided.

(i) The right of termination and of giving notice hereinbefore provided shall be in addition to and not in substitution for any other right possessed by His Majesty and/or the Minister.

30. LABOUR CONDITIONS

The Contractor shall comply with and be subject to all the terms and conditions of the Labour Conditions (if any) referred to in the agreement and to all variations and modifications thereof that may at any time be enacted or brought into force during the continuance of the contract.

Section (a) The total amount actually and properly payable to sub-contractors in connection with the work;

Reference to your letter of November 23rd, in connection with construction of Alexander's Indian Day School.

In regard to the furnishings for the school teachers' age, I have corrected the list enclosed with your letter inserting the Western Division catalogue numbers and prices and have made up requisition to cover, which is forwarded to you herewith.

I do not think that there is any possibility of this school being completed before the first of April at the earliest and I would suggest that the requisition for the furnishings be held up until about the first of February as they would be liable to be damaged if they were stored in the school building before it is completed.

You will note that I have not requisitioned for any linoleum rugs. The scale shows three rugs from Eatons and two from Robert Simpson Co., and five rugs were furnished for each, at Michel and Stony Plain Schools. The teachers and I were only able to find where three rugs were required and the extra four rugs are stored at the Agency and will fill the needs at Alexander's School.

(Sgd) E. A. Robertson,
Superintendent.

Reference to your letter of Nov. 23rd. in connection with construction of Alexander's Indian Day School.

I was at this school site yesterday with Mr. Gooderham. The construction is coming along very well considering that it is winter construction. The workmen were putting on the rafters yesterday and expect to have the building closed in, in a day or two.

In regard to desks, there are sufficient suitable desks to furnish this school remaining from those we took over from Youville Residential school. We will, however, require a teacher's desk and chair.

In regard to the furnishings for the school teaching, I have corrected the list enclosed with your letter inserting the Western Division catalogue numbers and prices and have made up requisition to cover which is forwarded to you herewith.

I do not think that there is any possibility of this school being completed before the first of April at the earliest and I would suggest that the requisition for the furnishings be held up until about the first of February as they would be liable to be damaged if they were stored in the school building before it is completed.

p.t.o.
You will note that I have not requisitioned for any linoleum rugs. The scale shows three rugs from Eatons and two from Robert Simpson Co., and five rugs were furnished for each, at Michel and Stony Plain Schools. The teachers and I were only able to find where three rugs were required and the extra four rugs are stored at the Agency and will fill the needs at Alexander's School.

In regard to advertising for a teacher I would suggest that it be left until the completion date of the school is a little more definite. Frankly I have considerable doubt of our chances of securing a suitable teacher in the midst of a contract year. In view of the large shortage of teachers in Alberta any suitable teacher will be tied up until the end of the June term.

E.A. Robertson,
Superintendent.

Encs.

PROGRESS CLAIM #1 - $10,195.69

The audit of Progress Claim #1 has been completed at the Contractor's office in Edmonton and the report thereon follows:

MATERIALS: $3,289.94

All invoices for materials have been checked for calculations and compared with purchase orders or delivery slips when available. These accounts have been approved by Mr. E.A. Robertson, Superintendent of the Indian Agency, acting as Department Engineer.

Materials taken from the contractor's stock have been checked to original invoices for prices and found in order.

In accordance with Section 4 of the Agreement, the Contractor has taken advantage of cash discounts and has assumed the benefits since the purchases had been made with Company funds.

SMALL TOOLS:

An inventory of small tools and non-consumable items has been set up, although not segregated from the charges for materials in this claim.

PAYROLLS & PAYROLL CHARGES - $3,381.32

Although a schedule of wage rates has not been issued or included with the contract, the rates that have been paid by the Contractor compares closely with the prevailing scale of wages in this district and have been approved by Mr. E.A. Robertson.

The following rates were paid on the basis of an 8 hour day, 40 hour week with time and a half for overtime:

Foreman - $1.60 per hour plus $1.50 @ day board
Carpenters - 1.40 " " " board
Carpenter's helper - 1.25 " " " "
Rough carpenter - 1.25 " " " "
Laborers (including) 80¢ - $1.00 per hour plus board.

The job foreman maintains a weekly time record showing the number of hours worked each day by each man. The payrolls are compiled from these time records. All calculations and extensions have been checked with one error noted on Inv. 37 - Payroll #6 for Nov. 11-17, where Fred White received payment of $28.75 instead of
$30.00. The Contractor has agreed to make an adjustment to the employee and include same in the next claim.

BOARD - $154.94

The value of board received by employees, with the exception of A.E. Elstvedt, the foreman, has not been included in the earnings as required by Income Tax regulations. This has been brought to the Contractor's attention and a further check will be made to ascertain that the amounts involved are properly set up and reported with the employees' earnings.

An error in extension resulting in an overcharge of $6.70 has been noted on Inv. # 41 where 29 meals @ 67¢ served to E. Dickson have been calculated as $26.13 instead of $19.43. The contractor has taken steps to obtain the necessary credit which will be reflected in the next claim.

VACATION PAY - $60.28

All employees on this project have received Holiday Pay at the rate of 2% in accordance with the length of their service and on the basis of their gross earnings, exclusive of board paid on their behalf.

UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE - $25.24

The provisions of the Unemployment Insurance Act have been complied with and the amount of contributions paid by the Contractor on behalf of the employees listed appears correct although the Contributions' books have not yet been examined for proof of payment.

WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION - $128.86

The Contractor has been assessed at the rate of 4% for the current year by Alberta Workmen's Compensation Board. The above charge has been calculated on the gross payroll and includes value of free board and Vacation Pay.

PUBLIC LIABILITY & PROPERTY DAMAGE - $5.49

The Contractor carries insurance against the above risks at a cost of .170% of the gross payrolls. The values of free and Vacation Pay have also been included in the calculations of the above charge.

BUILDERS' RISK INSURANCE - $187.00

The building while in the course of construction and is unoccupied has been insured for one year by the Contractor. The above charge represents the premium on a British General Insurance Co. Ltd. Policy # 93799 for $17,000 which is effective from November 8, 1948. The Department of Mines & Resources have been registered as co-beneficiaries with the Contractor.

EQUIPMENT RENTAL - $245.00

A Company-owned ½ Ton Mercury Pick-up truck has been used to transport men and materials to and from the project. The above charge covers the rental from October 14 to December 1st, at the rate of $1.00 per hour without operator. This rate has been approved by Mr. E.A. Robertson.

The above charge has been included in the "cost of work" in error and included in the calculations of the fee. The Contractor has agreed to adjust the overcharge which has resulted on the next Progress Claim.
SUB-CONTRACTS

1. EXCAVATION AND CONCRETE WORKS - $1,777.50

The Adby Construction Co., Ltd., has carried out excavation and back filling work at $1.50 per cu. yd., and also supplied and poured concrete @ $20.00 per cu. yd. The Contractor, with the concurrence of the Superintendent of the Agency, has had this work completed at rates which the sub-contractor normally charges.

2. PLUMBING - $219.89

The firm of Jamison & Lofts has, at the Contractor's request, supplied and installed at current market prices the plumbing material and fixtures required. The above charge includes $48.00 for labour and $6.00 for truck expenses.

TRUCKING - $165.16

The services of W. Crawford of Edmonton have been retained by the Contractor to have materials as required from Edmonton to the Indian School, a distance of some 22 miles, at the rate of 25¢ per cwt. This rate is somewhat lower than that currently charged by the larger cartage firms in Edmonton.

The hauling accounts have been compared with the materials invoices. The accounts were found in order and further served to establish proof of delivery of materials to the site.

An account paid to A. Boddes in the amount of $21.00 for cartage of stone at $3.50 per yd. has been found reasonable and in order.

CONTRACTOR'S FEE - $926.88

In accordance with the Agreement which the Contractor has signed and returned to the Department for final ratification, a fee of 10% of the "cost of work" completed has been claimed in this application.

The inclusion of equipment rental, noted above, has resulted in an overcharge of $24.80 in fee for which the Contractor has agreed to adjust on the next Progress Claim.

GENERAL

A copy of the Agreement signed by the Contractor and the Department has not been returned to the Company and was therefore not available for examination. According to a draft of the Agreement which has been received, the above charges, excluding the discrepancies noted, appear fair and reasonable.

The Contractor's records, in spite of the discrepancies disclosed, have been found generally well kept and handled by an efficient staff who have given me all the information and assistance required to carry out my audit.

An examination of "paid" cheques has not been undertaken but will be carried out before the second Progress Claim is passed for payment.

In accordance with the above report, and subject to the adjustments mentioned, Progress Claim #1 has been certified.

PROGRESS CLAIM # 1 - $10,195.69

The audit of Progress Claim # 1 has been completed at the Contractor's office in Edmonton and the report thereon follows:

MATERIALS: $3,289.94

All invoices for materials have been checked for calculations and compared with purchase orders or delivery slips when available. These accounts have been approved by Mr. E.A. Robertson, Superintendent of the Indian Agency, acting as Department Engineer.

Materials taken from the contractor's stock have been checked to original invoices for prices and found in order.

In accordance with Section 4 of the Agreement, the Contractor has taken advantage of cash discounts and has assumed the benefits since the purchases had been made with Company funds.

SMALL TOOLS:

An inventory of small tools and non-consumable items has been set up, although not segregated from the charges for materials in this claim.

PAYROLLS & PAYROLL CHARGES - $3,381.32

Although a schedule of wage rates has not been issued or included with the contract, the rates that have been paid by the Contractor compares closely with the prevailing scale of wages in this district and have been approved by Mr. E.A. Robertson.

The following rates were paid on the basis of an 8 hour day, 40 hour week with time and a half for overtime:

Foremen - $1.60 per hour plus $1.50 @ day board
Carpenters - 1.40 " " " board
Carpenter's helper - 1.25 " " " "
Rough carpenter - 1.25 " " " "
Laborers (Indians) 80¢ - $1.00 per hour plus board.

The job foreman maintains a weekly time record showing the number of hours worked each day by each man. The payrolls are compiled from these time records. All calculations and extensions have been checked with one error noted on Inv. 37 - Payroll # 6 for Nov. 11-17, where Fred White received payment of $28.75 instead of
The Contractor has agreed to make an adjustment to the employee and include same in the next claim.

**BOARD - $154.94**

The value of board received by employees, with the exception of A.F. Elfstedt, the foreman, has not been included in the earnings as required by Income Tax regulations. This has been brought to the Contractor's attention and a further check will be made to ascertain that the amounts involved are properly set up and reported with the employees' earnings.

An error in extension resulting in an overcharge of $6.70 has been noted on Inv. #41 where 29 meals @ 67¢ served to E. Dickson have been calculated as $26.13 instead of $19.43. The contractor has taken steps to obtain the necessary credit which will be reflected in the next claim.

**VACATION PAY - $60.28**

All employees on this project have received Holiday Pay at the rate of 2% in accordance with the length of their service and on the basis of their gross earnings, exclusive of board paid on their behalf.

**UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE - $25.24**

The provisions of the Unemployment Insurance Act have been complied with and the amount of contributions paid by the Contractor on behalf of the employees listed appears correct although the Contributions' books have not yet been examined for proof of payment.

**WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION - $128.86**

The Contractor has been assessed at the rate of 4% for the current year by Alberta Workmen's Compensation Board. The above charge has been calculated on the gross payroll and includes value of free board and Vacation Pay.

**PUBLIC LIABILITY & PROPERTY DAMAGE - $5.49**

The Contractor carries insurance against the above risks at a cost of .170% of the gross payrolls. The value of free board and Vacation Pay have also been included in the calculations of the above charge.

**BUILDERS RISK INSURANCE - $127.00**

The building while in the course of construction and is unoccupied has been insured for one year by the Contractor. The above charge represents the premium on a British General Insurance Co. Ltd. Policy #95799 for $17,000 which is effective from November 8, 1943. The Department of Mines & Resources have been registered as co-beneficiaries with the Contractor.

**EQUIPMENT RENTAL - $248.00**

A Company-owned ½ Ton Mercury Pick-up truck has been used to transport men and materials to and from the project. The above charge covers the rental from October 14 to December 1st. at the rate of $1.00 per hour without operator. This rate has been approved by Mr. E.A. Robertson.

The above charge has been included in the "cost of work" in error and included in the calculations of the fee. The Contractor has agreed to adjust the overcharge which has resulted on the next Progress Claim.
SUB - CONTRACTS

1. EXCAVATION AND CONCRETE WORKS - $1,777.50

The Adby Construction Co. Ltd. has carried out excavation and back filling work at $1.50 per cu. yd., and also supplied and poured concrete @ $20.00 per cu. yd. The Contractor, with the concurrence of the Superintendent of the Agency, has had this work completed at rates which the sub-contractor normally charges.

2. PLUMBING - $219.89

The firm of Jamison & Lofts has, at the Contractor's request, supplied and installed at current market prices the plumbing material and fixtures required. The above charge includes $48.00 for labour and $6.00 for truck expenses.

TRUCKING - $165.16

The services of W. Crawford of Edmonton have been retained by the Contractor to have materials as required from Edmonton to the Indian School, a distance of some 38 miles, at the rate of 25¢ per cwt. This rate is somewhat lower than that currently charged by the larger cartage firms in Edmonton.

The hauling accounts have been compared with the materials invoices. The accounts were found in order and further served to establish proof of delivery of materials to the site.

An account paid to A. Boddez in the amount of $21.00 for cartage of stone at $3.50 per yd. has been found reasonable and in order.

CONTRACTOR'S FEE - $926.88

In accordance with the Agreement which the Contractor has signed and returned to the Department for final ratification, a fee of 10% of the "cost of work" completed has been claimed in this application.

The inclusion of equipment rental, noted above, has resulted in an overcharge of $24.20 in fee which the Contractor has agreed to adjust on the next Progress Claim.

GENERAL

A copy of the Agreement signed by the Contractor and the Department has not been returned to the Company and was therefore not available for examination. According to a draft of the Agreement which has been received, the above charges, excluding the discrepancies noted, appear fair and reasonable.

The Contractor's records, in spite of the discrepancies disclosed, have been found generally well kept and handled by an efficient staff who have given me all the information and assistance required to carry out my audit.

An examination of "paid" cheques has not been undertaken but will be carried out before the second Progress Claim is passed for payment.

In accordance with the above report, and subject to the adjustments mentioned, Progress Claim #1 has been certified.
J. L. VILLENUEVE,
Treasury Auditor.

PROGRESS CLAIM #2 - $4,105.66

The audit of Progress Claim #2 has been completed by the undersigned at the Contractor's office in Edmonton and the report thereon follows:

Payrolls and Payroll Charges - $1,062.76

A schedule of minimum wage rates to be observed on contract has not been received. The rates paid in the present claim are the same as in claim #1. Since December 29, E. McLean has taken over the duties of foreman from A. Elfstedt and has been paid at the same rate of $1.50 per hour plus $1.50 @ day board which he received on his former job.

Weekly time records maintained and signed by the foreman have been checked in detail to the payrolls and found correctly transcribed and computed.

An underpayment of $1.25 noted in Claim #1 on Payroll #6 for Nov. 11-17 has been adjusted and paid to Fred White on Payroll #10 for Dec. 16-22.

Board - $66.53

The value of board paid by the Contractor on behalf of several employees has not been included on the payrolls for Income Tax deductions owing to the fact that the board accounts are not available at the time the payrolls are compiled. The amounts involved are, however, posted to the employees' individual records of earnings and are reported to the Income Tax Branch in due course.

The over charge of $6.70 reported in Claim #1, resulting from an apparent error in calculation on Inv. #61, upon inquiries by the Contractor, has been found to be an error in the account submitted by J.D. Morin who charged 89 meals to E. Dickson whereas the number should have been 89 which is in agreement with the payment received by the claimant.
Vacation Pay - $18.64

All employees have been paid at the rate of 2% in accordance with their length of employment, and Holiday Pay Books have been stamped to date. The value of board has been taken into account in the calculation.

Unemployment Insurance - $7.48

This represents the Contractor's portion of contributions paid under the U.I. Act. Contribution books have been examined and found in order.

Workmen's Compensation - $40.55

This amount represents 4% of the total of wages, board and Vacation Pay charged in the present claim.

On completion of final returns to the Alberta Workmen's Compensation Board, the contractor's records will be reviewed to adjust any rebates that may accrue in connection with employees whose earnings exceeded $2,375.00 in 1948.

F.H.S. & F.D. - $1.62

This charge, representing an assessment of .170¢ on the gross payroll, including board, is reasonably accurate although an undercharge of 10 cents has been noted in connection with Payroll #10 for December 22nd.

Materials - $1,062.76

Invoices for materials have been test checked for calculations and extensions. Delivery and receipt of materials has been reasonably established by comparing invoices to items listed on trucking accounts and also by the signature of the foreman appearing on delivery slips and purchase orders.

Materials supplied from the contractor's stock have been fairly priced in line with actual cost laid down.

Equipment Rental - $87.00

This amount represents the Contractor's charge for the rental of a Company-owned ½ ton Mercury Pick-up truck at the rate of $1.00 per hour without operator. The number of hours charged corresponds with the number of hours the foreman has been on the job.

In accordance with Schedule "A" (Sec. j) of the contract, these charges have been deleted from the "cost of the work" in computing the Contractor's fee or commission.

- Sub-Contracts -

1 - Millwork - W.R. Seidler Ltd. - $1,098.50

With the concurrence of the Indian Superintendent, Mr. E.A. Robertson, the Contractor has accepted the above firm's estimate of $2,500.00 for millwork as the lowest bid received. To date this sub-contractor has supplied millwork to the value of $1,098.50 in addition to other material not classed or listed as millwork.
Trucking charges in the present claim amount to $37.68 and have been calculated at the agreed rate of 25 cents per sq. The materials hauled corresponded accurately with supplier invoices and items charged out of the Contractor's stock.

Contractor's Fee - $349.61

The Contractor's fee has been calculated at the rate of 10% on the actual "cost of work" completed, as set out in Section 5 (b) of the contract, deleting charges for rental on Company-owned equipment. The overcharge of $24.60 in claim #1 has accordingly been deducted from the fee earned in the present claim, leaving a net fee of $345.61 to be paid.

General -

An examination of "paid" cheques has been performed in connection with payrolls and accounts included in Progress Claim #1, and proof of payment established. A list has been set-up for all cheques outstanding from the previous claim.

The Contractor has complied with all statutory requirements and, to the best of my knowledge, the accounts submitted herein represent goods and services that have been rendered at prices that appear fair and reasonable.

In accordance with the foregoing report, and subject to the adjustments mentioned, Progress Claim #2 has been certified.

Progress Claim #8 - $4,450.58

The audit of Progress Claim #8 has been completed by the undersigned at the Contractor's office in Edmonton, and the report thereon follows:

Payrolls and Payroll charges - $2,116.58

The payrolls submitted have been checked in detail to the weekly time records which are maintained and signed by the foreman, R. McLean.

The rates paid by the contractor comply with the Schedule of wages provided in the contract and are in line with current Union rates.

Board - $186.56

The Contractor has paid the board accounts as submitted herewith and added the amounts to the earnings of the employees concerned. The value of board has not been recorded on the payrolls owing to the fact that the amounts are not available at the time the payrolls are compiled.

Vacation Pay - $39.71

All employees have been paid in accordance with their length of employment and Holiday Pay Books have been stamped to date. The value of board has been taken into account in the case of each employee.

A minor error of .08 has been noted in the additions of Holiday Pay column on Payroll #14 for January 15, (1949) to 19th where the total is shown as $6.75 instead of $6.75. No adjustment has been requested.

Unemployment Insurance - $13.58

The Contractor has complied with the Unemployment Insurance Act and the above charge represents the employer's contributions.
Workmen's Compensation - $75.14

This amount represents 6% of the total of wages, board and Vacation Pay charged in this claim less a credit of $5.85 on account of a W.C.B. rebate applicable to 1946 wages charged to this contract. The credit which the Contractor has allowed has in the case of E. McLean been incorrectly calculated as $.34 whereas the correct amount should be $.04, a difference of $.34 which may be adjusted on a later claim if the Contractor so desires.

P.L.C. & P.D.C. - $5.56

The above charge has been calculated as 170% of the gross payrolls and board but does not include Vacation Pay. An undercharge of $.08 has resulted and no adjustment is contemplated unless requested by the Contractor.

Materials - $765.44

Invoices for materials have been checked in detail for calculations and extensions. Delivery and receipt of materials in all instances have been acknowledged by the foreman on the project.

Materials supplied from the contractor's stock have been properly recorded and priced in line with the actual cost laid down.

Equipment Rental - $151.50

The Contractor has charged the rental of a Company owned ½ ton Pick-up truck at $1.00 per hour without operation which is in compliance with the schedule of rates approved in the Contract.

In accordance with the provisions of the Contract, the contractor has been allowed to derive a fee of 10% on such rentals.

Sub-Contracts

1 - Millwork - W.R. Zeidler Ltd. - $515.00

In accordance with the above firm's accepted tender, millwork in the amount of $515.00 has been supplied and charged in this claim, bringing the amount supplied to date to $1505.50, which is within the approved estimate of $2525.00.

2 - Barry & Kemper - $250.00

This firm has been authorized to install the furnace and ducts at an estimated cost of $250.00. The above charge would cover a portion of the work that has been completed to date.
S - R.A. Sorensen - $84.50

With the consent of the Indian Superintendent, the Contractor has sub-contracted the erection of the chimney to the above party on a cost plus 10% basis. The account submitted is exclusive of materials and is somewhat lower than the cost at other Indian schools of the same specifications.

An error of 10¢ noted on the account can be overlooked as the contractor has now settled the account.

Trucking - W. Crawford - $35.00

This charge represents one account and covers materials hauled and delivery of which has been acknowledged by the job foreman.

Contractor's Fee - $435.07

This amount brings the total fee claimed to date to $1764.56 which represents 10% of the "cost of work", that has been established and claimed by the Contractor, and is in accordance with the terms of the contract.

General

The charges submitted by the Contractor to this stage exceed the expenditure of $12,000.00 authorized in the contract by $750.18. The completion of the school is estimated to cost a further $2,500.00. The Contractor has been advised to take immediate action along with the Indian Superintendent to secure the necessary approval from the Department for a further appropriation of funds.

An examination of "paid cheques", has been carried out in connection with payrolls and accounts included in the previous claims and proof of payment established with the exception of a few cheques outstanding.

In accordance with the foregoing report, and subject to the remarks therein, Progress Claim #8 has been certified.

Re: Indian Day School - Alexander Reserve
Alberta Construction Co. - Contractor.

Progress Claim #4 - $4060.02

The audit of Progress Claim No. 4 has been completed by the undersigned at the Contractor's office in Edmonton and the report thereon follows:

Payrolls

One hour travelling time per man has been charged from April 20th on, as the contractor was not able to find lodging and board for the men on the site. The extra hour has been charged at straight time and has been done with approval of the Provincial Board of Industrial Relations.

Builders' Risk Insurance -

The Contractor has insured the building by an additional $3000 which brings the amount carried to $20000. The extra premium amounted to $33.00.

Workmen's Compensation -

The amount of rebate credited on Claim No. 3 which has resulted in an undercharge of 34 cents has not been claimed by the contractor in view of the small amount involved.

A charge of $87.00 has been paid to Adby Construction on Invoice No. 92 for levelling and back filling. This work was performed with the knowledge and approval of the Indian Superintendent Mr. H.A. Robertson.

General

The cost of the school to the conclusion of this claim amounted to $22,810.20. There are other accounts to come up, such as painting, with the result that the final cost may approach $25000. The original estimate of $16000 has been exceeded considerably due to an appreciable increase in the price of lumber and building materials and also to the fact that the school was at a considerable distance from Edmonton, thus entailing travelling and subsistence expenses.
The Indian Superintendent, Mr. E.A. Robertson has been informed on the matter and is of the opinion that the contract has been carried out in good faith and as economically as can reasonably be expected.

In accordance with the foregoing remarks, Progress Claim No. 4 has been certified.

Re: Indian Day School - Alexander Reserve
Alberta Construction Co. - Contractor.

Progress Claim No. 5 - $3445.64 (Final)

The audit of Progress Claim No. 5 has been completed by the undersigned at the contractor's office in Edmonton and the report thereon follows:

Payrolls:

Rates of pay observed by the contractor conformed with the minimum rates set out in the schedule of wages appended to the contract and also with the prevailing rates in the district as mutually agreed upon by the respective trades and contractors' organization.

Board:

Where employees have been supplied with board or board allowance, the amount received has been recorded on the employees earnings cards and reported to the Income Tax Branch.

Income Tax:

Deductions that have been made have been remitted to the local Income Tax Office. Cheques covering these remittances have been examined and proof of payment has been established.

Vacation Pay:

The contractor has fully complied with these requirements as prescribed by the Alberta Board of Industrial Relations. Holiday Pay books have been examined from time to time and satisfactory evidence has been obtained that the correct rates and amounts have been paid to the employees.

Unemployment Insurance:

Contributions by employer and employees have been test checked by examining the employees books and purchases of stamps from the Commission. The charges claimed by the contractor have been found correctly computed and in order.

Workmen's Compensation:

The assessment rate prescribed by the Workmen's Compensation Board of Alberta has been observed by the contractor and payment thereof has been verified by examining cheques and relative records of the contractor. All rebates accruing have been taken into account for the year 1948. There will be no rebate for 1949 as all employees employed on the project are no longer with the contractor and have not earned the maximum assessable amount.
The necessary clearance from the W.C. Board has been appended to this claim.

Public Liability and Property Damages:

The contractor has maintained the necessary coverage against the above risks throughout the duration of the project and has re-
mitted the amounts charged in the form of premiums to the Insurance Company.

Materials and Expenses:

All invoices for materials have been checked for calcula-
tions and compared with purchase orders and delivery slips. Materials supplied from the contractor's stores were also checked as to prices and delivery.

Materials remaining at the conclusion of the project have been set up on Inventory Sheets and disposed of partly by purchase by the contractor at 50% of original price as approved by the Supervising Engineer and partly by remaining the property of the Indian Affairs Branch.

Insurance:

With the approval of the Indian Superintendent, Mr. E.A. Robertson, the contractor has cancelled the Fire Insurance Policy on the building and secured and credited the rebate against the present claim.

Subcontracts:

Barry & Kesper - Supply and Installation of Furnace:

In accordance with the estimate submitted and approved by the Indian Superintendent, the above firm has completed the Installa-
tion of the heating system at the quoted amount of $255.00.

H.R. Zeidler - Millwork:

With the concurrence of the Indian Superintendent, the above firm was awarded the subcontract of supplying millwork for the estimated amount of $2589.00. The actual amount supplied has been valued at $2462.40 only, owing to the fact that certain items had to be procured from other suppliers.

The above two subcontracts have been formally submitted to the department for ratification.

A number of other firms have also provided materials and services of a specialised nature but as these firms would only agree to provide these services at current prices rather than offer an estimate, no formal approval was sought. This also enabled the con-
tractor to shop around and take advantage of competitive prices.

Plant Rentals:

Alberta Construction - Mercury 1947, ½ ton Pickup truck:

The Company has claimed rentals on the above truck at the rate of $1.00 per hour. This rate was authorised by the Indian Super-
intendent and corresponds with the rate set out in the Schedule of rates appended to the contract. The contractor has claimed a total rental of $1343.50. The time charged represented the number of hours
the truck was out with the men and includes many hours during which it was not in actual operation. Application for approval of the rate charged has gone forward to the Department.

Wilkinson & McKean:

The rent of Engine and Generator was for the operation of a sanding machine. The rate charged is that submitted by the firm owning the equipment. Application for approval of the rate of $8.00 per day has also gone forward to the Department.

Fee:

In accordance with the provisions of the contract a fee of 10% on the total cost of the work has been claimed by the contractor. The amount claimed in the present application represents the balance of a total fee of $236.50 as calculated on the total cost of $23,669.14 for the completed project.

General:

An inspection of the school following its completion has been made by the writer in the company of the Indian Superintendent, Mr. K.A. Robertson who has issued the required certificate of completion.

The cost of the project has exceeded the original estimate of $18,000 by $8,256.04. There is, however, a reasonable comparison between the cost of this school and the two identical schools erected on the Michel and Winterburn Reserves. The trend in prices has been on the upward since the earlier schools were built and consequently the increased cost can be attributed to this factor.

The contractor has furnished evidence of all payments of wages and accounts. Cancelled cheques have been examined in every case with the exception of cheque no. 6566 in the amount of $10.26 payable to Paul Henry on Payroll for July 22-28, which was still outstanding at the time of the final audit.

All applicable credits have been deducted from this and previous claims.

In accordance with the provisions contained in Contract No. 4458 dated October 5, 1948, I have made an examination of the accounts and records of the contractor, insofar as they pertain to the above mentioned contract and I have received all the information and explanations I have required. I have reviewed the system of internal control and the accounting procedures of the contractor and, without making a detailed audit of the transactions, I have tested the accounting records of the contractor and other supporting evidence by methods and to the extent I have deemed necessary.

I report that, subject to the extent of my examination and in my opinion, the amount of $26,256.04 in the cost arrived at as shown in the accounts and records examined and in accordance with the information and explanations obtained, the said amount being in excess of the estimated cost of $18,000 as set out in the contract by $8,256.04.

Dear Sirs,

We, the Indians of the Alexander Reserve, are very proud of our Day School. It allows our children to receive a sound education. Our thanks and gratefulness goes to the Department of Mines and Resources.

A good health, we hold, is necessary to profit of the teaching and education given at school. For this reason, we built for our children a hockey rink (170 ft. x 70 ft.), which we are flooding with water from a one-mile lake. A slide for the younger boys and girls is being constructed also.

Having shown our interest and our good will, having done a good amount of the required work, having our own Band's Hockey Team to Equip with goalie's sticks, pads and protectors, we would greatly appreciate a help from the Department of Mines and Resources to equip our children with their own Hockey equipment.

They would be in need of the following hockey articles:

- 2 goalie's pads.
- 2 goalie's sticks.
- 2 goalie's, breast protectors.
- a few shovels.
- 4 "24 inch" scrapers.

A few sleighs for the girls would also be appreciated.

Inspection of Big Horn Reserve Area to Select Suitable Site for Proposed Indian Day School

The area which is to be used as a reserve lies some fifteen miles South Westerly from Nordegg, Alberta, and is entirely in Township 39, Range 16 west of the fifth meridian.

Mr. Smelser of this office, accompanied Mr. Clark of the Ottawa Indian Branch Office, and Mr. John E. Pugh, Superintendent, Stony Sarees Indian Agencies, on the inspection of the reserve area. The Nordegg detachment of the R.C.M.P. provided a Jeep and driver for the inspection carried out on May 20th.

The accompanying township map shows the area embraced in the reserve, the approximate location of the dwelling houses of the Indians, and the area or site selected as most suitable for the Agency and School buildings.

A site for the proposed school and agency buildings was selected in the S.W. quarter of Section 19, Township 39, Range 16 W being a parcel of land bounded northerly by the existing constructed section of the proposed David Thompson Highway and Southerly by the Big Horn River.

This site was selected as fulfilling more than any other site examined, the following requirements:

1. Accessibility. It is on the principal and only highway in this District, 15 miles from Nordegg.

2. Drainage. The site in general is a level gravel bench at an elevation of approximately 10 feet above high water line of the Big Horn River. Drainage is very satisfactory.

3. Water Supply. Both for domestic and fire fighting purposes is at all times adequate and accessible at a minimum of cost.

4. Surroundings are pleasant. The highway runs along the south side of rather high, up to 300 feet wooded hills. The river as it emerges from the Big Horn Canyon is crossed by the highway Bridge. See accompanying photographs.

5. Control. It is very desirable to have the agency buildings located at a site which will give the most ..........

MEMORANDUM

Col. B. F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education

Re: Bighorn Indian Day School

Further to your memorandum of June 16th I have examined with interest Mr. Mills' report and have noted the selection made for the school and administrative site on the Bighorn River. From the photographs and information it looks to be a very interesting and attractive site both from the viewpoint of the school and the administrative headquarters.

We have at the moment before Council a recommendation to create the 5,000-acre block into an Indian Reserve to be known as Bighorn Indian Reserve No. 144A and expect the Order in Council within the next day or two. As soon as the Order in Council is received, this Service is sending forward a recommendation to the Minister to set aside approximately fifty acres at the location marked by you as a school site and as a site for administrative buildings to serve the Reserve.

I discussed this with Mr. Hoey and we agreed that in setting aside the area for administrative purposes we should make it large enough so that we could control enough property to prevent Indian housing from encroaching too closely to the administrative buildings. We also made it large in order to ensure that we have control within the Branch of the exact building site ultimately selected.

As soon as this authorization is received from the Minister, we will forward you a copy for record purposes. In the meantime I am enclosing copy of the draft of the Minister's order which we propose to ask him for as soon as the Order in Council setting up the Reserve is received here.
We are returning herewith Mr. Mills' report with attachments and photographs, and appreciate having had the opportunity to look them over.

Encls.

D. J. Allan,
Superintendent,
Reserves & Trusts.

Enclosed herewith are sketches of the proposed log day school and log teacher's residence, together with construction detail as submitted by Superintendent J. H. Pugh.

You will recollect it was proposed to erect log buildings, and an accountable cheque of $2,000.00 was forwarded in 1948 to pay for logging and other preliminary work. The Indians have brought in all the necessary logs, a well is being drilled and what money is left out of this advance will be used to purchase cement.

I hope you are impressed with the construction as indicated in the sketches. I am impressed and believe that this type of building is most suitable for this reserve. The buildings will be erected along a scenic highway now under construction. There will be a community of log buildings, and I can visualize the day when this little Indian settlement will be an attraction for tourists, then the Indians can sell handicraft and operate other lines of business, which will be lucrative and make them more or less self-supporting.

Mr. Pugh has given this a great deal of thought and I can see no way to improve on his plans. Neither he nor I are in a position to give any close estimate of the total cost of the two buildings, but it is our belief that they may total close to $14,000.00. This would require a $12,000.00 expenditure during 1949/50.

If you approve the plan and the estimated expenditure, steps will immediately be taken to obtain the price of material, other than logs, as well as labour. The buildings should be erected in early summer to be ready for use in September at the latest.

After you have finished with these sketches, would you please return them to this office.

Ottawa,
Ontario:

Attention:- Col: Bernard F. Neary,
Supt: of Indian Education.

Re: Big Horn Indian Day School.

We desire to acknowledge the receipt of your file 710-5 (E), of the 26th ultimo, with reference to the erection of the above noted school, and we have today requested the Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, Calgary, Alta., to forward the copy of Radio message, herewith attached.

In this connection, we may say, that having just returned from Nordegg and the school site, where we checked the logs and well site etc., and interviewed Mr. Johnson, in regard to the work to be carried out, we were able to reply to your letter on our return with the information requested.

The wage schedule may appear about ten cents higher than would be the case in closer proximity to commercial centres, but as this site is so far removed from Rocky Mountain House, Nordegg being discounted being a purely Company mining town, we were confronted with the fact that the foreman and crew would have to set up their own living and boarding arrangements. Big Horn Reserve is situated 13 miles from Nordegg and as we have no transportation nearer than Rocky Mountain House (deep), we think that it would be fair to allow Mr. Johnson, if approved, to charge the nominal rate of 6 cents per mile for the use of his light delivery, if required in emergency. It will be also be noted that we have included a charge for the use of a gas power saw at a nominal rate of 10 cents per hour, and in this we feel that it will eliminate hand ripping, sawing etc., and is recommended. The use of the cement mixer is essential and the charge nominal, and will be based on 350 sacks of cement.

I requested Mr. Johnson to proceed out to the site with Mr. Thomas towards the end of the coming week, but will wire Mr. Thomas to delay this, until we have your signal to commence with Mr. Johnson.

We have made the necessary arrangements with Mr. C. Bruce of Rocky Mtn House to deliver the lumber to the site and as soon as possible, before rains, and the construction of roads which is proceeding between Rocky Mtn House and Nordegg. We checked over bridges between Nordegg and Big Horn, as there was some question as to their carrying capacity, but believe they are safe for normal loads.

Should the foregoing meet with your approval, may we be provided with an accountable cheque to pay wages, in the amount of $2000.00, which is tentative until we know the cost of material. The writer is basing his wage requirements at approximately 40% of the material cost.

Lumber reference above is made to Purchase Order No 41088, for forms etc. for this building.

John E. Pugh, Supt.

The nearest town to Big Horn school is Rocky Mountain House, 90 miles away. Here the demand for labour, expert and unskilled, is strong during the short intensive building season, and men can bargain for the best jobs. The Big Horn area offers little to attract workers. The nearest settlement, Nordegg, is a company town (coal) which has no facilities and no desire to accommodate transients. It must be made worthwhile for the men to stay on the job or the crew will evaporate. The foreman will have to boss the job and also set up and manage an oasis in the wilderness. He is, accordingly, going to be a valuable* and so an expensive man.

Re: Big Horn Day School, Morley, Alberta.

With reference to the marginally noted subject, it is advised that the writer has been in Morley this week, and this letter is being written at the Rocky Mountain House Agency.

We took Mr. Johnson the Foreman out to the site and laid out the ground plan for school and residence. Viewed the gravel pit, and arranged for the gravel hauling with the Indians of the Reserve, so they started on this work today.

Mr. Johnson is moving into the site on Monday next, and will take with him a Carpenter and Logmen (2), who will commence raising the logs and sawing work. Mr. Johnson will commence the excavation work, with Indian labour. In order to start the Indians off on the gravel it was necessary to purchase four gravel shovels and two picks, these we procure from the Beaver Colleries as there are no other than Company stores at Morley.

We have requested Mr. Bruce to move in his material for foundation work, at the beginning of the week. In checking the footings for these two buildings, and our bill of material for the concrete work, we notice that no re-inforcing rods were provided for, and bolts for tying the first round of logs to the concrete, and this material we have ordered through the retail store of the Marshall Wells Co. at Rocky Mountain House, and consist of 700 lineal feet of rod and 40 bolts & nuts, all of 5/8" size, the cost of the rods will approximate $100.00, and the bolts, approximately $4.50. Accounts will be rendered for the above material, and requisitions are attached herewith, which we would ask be approved by the Purchasing Agent for purchase locally from the above Company.

Requisitions for the gravel shovels and picks are also attached, and the same request to cover their purchase is made.

We also purchased for delivery to the site, some dimension material for gravel hauling as the Indians has no other means of hauling gravel, and the plank will be used for scaffold work after gravel hauling is finished. To Page 2.
Ottawa, May 27th, 1949.

CONTRACT AGREEMENT

THIS AGREEMENT made (in triplicate) the thirteenth day of May in the year Nineteen Hundred and forty-nine A.D.

BETWEEN

Mr. B.A. Johnson, Rocky Mountain House, Alberta, hereinafter called the Contractor, of the first part;

AND His Majesty the King, represented by the Minister of Mines and Resources of Canada, hereinafter called "The Minister", of the second part,

WHEREAS the party of the first part, for the consideration hereinafter mentioned, has agreed with the party of the second part, to do, perform the work, matters and things required to be done, and performed, in the manner hereinafter described, in connection with the work or works;

NOW THIS INDEED WITNESSETH that the said parties hereto, hereby covenant, promise and agree, each with the other as follows:

ARTICLE I: The covenants, clauses, provisos and conditions of the blueprints, plans and specifications already provided for the erection of the Big Horn Indian Day School and teacherage.

together with the drawings and such additional detail drawings, shop drawings and instructions, as may from time to time be furnished, shall be as fully part of this agreement as if attached hereto, or herein repeated, and should the Contractor or Minister fail to sign them, they shall nevertheless be binding on both parties.
ARTICLE II: The Contractor undertakes and agrees:

(a) to do, and perform, the works, matters and things required to be done, and performed, in connection with the following work or works namely,

(a) Erection of Big Horn Indian Day School,
(b) Erection of Big Horn teacherage

according to blueprints, plans and specifications and conditions outlined in Article I.

(b) to complete substantially, and to the satisfaction of the Minister, all the work, on or before the date or dates following, viz: the thirty-first day of August Nineteen Hundred and forty-nine A.D.

(c) Time shall be deemed to be material and of the essence of this contract.

ARTICLE III: The Minister undertakes and agrees, in consideration of the premises, and subject to the performance and observation on the part of the Contractor of all covenants, provisos and conditions in the specifications contained:

(a) To provide the materials required for the erection of the day school and teacherage.
(b) To pay the Contractor in current funds, for the performance of the contract at the rate of One Dollar and Seventy Cents per hour subject to additions and deductions as provided for in the Specifications governing the work.

Carpenters One Dollar and Fifty Cents per hour.
Carpenters' Helpers One Dollar and Twenty-Five Cents per hour.
Labourers Eighty Cents per hour.
Excavation Labourers (Indians) Seventy Cents per hour.
Gravel at site Two Dollars per load by Indians.

Re:-Big Horn Day School, Nordegg, Alberta.

With reference to the marginally noted School, now under construction, it is advised that this school was visited last week, and we found fairly good progress being made. Mr Johnson and Mr Thomas our Assistant at Rocky Mountain House, had procured two very good log men, and the following progress is reported upon.

Excavations well under way,
Concrete forms for school completed.
All gravel at site.
One half of the logs, stripped of inside peeling, and inside faces hewed on about half the logs, this work was being done in excellent shape, and the hewing of inside of the logs to even 10", will make the stripping of the inside walls when in place, a simplified matter.
Residence basement was being dug, and the pump had been set on the casing in this basement, this is being so constructed, that ready access can be had to the pump if required.
Mr Johnson was clearing the site of all excavation rock and dirt as this work proceeded, to which we agreed. He is using all Indian labour on the excavation and clearing of site.
They anticipated pouring the school foundations Tuesday last.
All material for the above foundation work had been delivered to the site by Mr C Bruce of Rocky Mountain House, including the cement which was obtained through the kindness of Mr Sturrock of the Brazeau Collieries at Nordegg, and Mr Bruce will clear their account.

Being in remote district, some organization was necessary to set up a camp, and this Mr Johnson undertook. He is boarding the crew and all in tents, and we allowed the use of flooring for the tents, which will be used to top the building to used for the school children's horses at the site.

over.
When requesting delivery from Mr Bruce of the foundation material, and after consultation with Mr Johnson, we asked that the cement flue blocks be delivered, so that this could be carried up through the two buildings on a cement foundation, and while we placed bricks and flue linings in the requisition sent forward for the completion of this building, these can be eliminated when taking delivery of that purchase order. We believe that as there is no furnace in either buildings that the cement block chimneys will be entirely satisfactory.

As the crew are now well on their way in this work, may we ask if the requisition sent forward for the balance of the material could be expedited, please. We would hesitate to lay off the crew for want of this material, hence our request to ask that this be treated urgently, through the office of the Purchasing Agent.

Might we also point out that should we have rain the roads to the site might also hold up the job, if the material is delayed. You no doubt noted that we requested prices at site, feeling that the Company who were awarded the tender, would be in a better position to truck this material, than us having to arrange same through remote control from this office.

May we be advised by Air Mail or Army Signal to Mr. G. H. Gooderham, what progress has been made towards the delivery of the above material.

John A. Pugh, Supt.
Stony - Sarcee Indian Agency.

Re:-Day School, Big Horn Indian Reserve, Nordegg, Alta.

It is advised that the writer has just returned from the above school project, and desire to report on the progress.

Main School Building:- Cement foundations complete, with all joists laid, and the first round of logs were being put in place. It is anticipated that the school logs will be in place by the end of this week. This appears to be a good job, with the cement foundation down on rock with a two foot base tapering to 12" as planned.

Residence:- The excavation was complete was the basement, and the crew were readying the forms for concrete pouring. This work proved somewhat expensive, due entirely to the formation we found below ground, this being old river bed, full of rock of all sizes, and a manual and team job from the beginning. Had the writer known that the entire underground was rock and shale as thought this would have not been undertaken, however it is now done, and actually is a requirement at this remote place.

Mr Johnson felt that he would have this basement finished by the end of this week, when the log men can move over to this building.

We have prepared a CREDIT VOUCHER covering labour costs up to the week ending June 11th last, which covers labour on the work up to this point, and includes all excavation work, gravel hauling, from river to site, making of forms and placing for the school, preparation of logs before erection, this consisting of cleaning logs of gum spots, tapering to desired width of 10", and some clearing work on site.

From the Credit voucher it will noted we have expended the sum of $1257.90, leaving a balance of $742.10 in this account, and it will be necessary to ask for a further accountable cheque for the framing work after the logs are in place, and it is desired to ask if this can be submitted at an early date, and the suggested amount is $2000.00.

(over)
The Assistant at Rocky Mountain House Agency who is completing the payrolls etc., has sufficient for approximately three weeks work, and we would appreciate receiving the requested further amount prior to that time.

We have not as yet received any indication as to whom has been awarded the tender for the framing material, and we trust that this will be expedited, in order to keep the crew at work, and they will be ready for roofing material about the end of the month.

The writer feels satisfied with the progress of the work on this project, and while under a certain amount of remote control, we think Mr. Johnson is doing a good job, under certain difficulties experienced in the excavations.

Stony - Sarcee Indian Agency.

G.H. Gooderham, Esq.,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
CALGARY,
Alberta.

Re:- Staining and Painting School & Residence.
Big Horn Indian Day School.

It is desired to submit herewith, prices obtained on materials for the above mentioned buildings by Mr M Macleod, acting in the writers absence on leave.

Quotations were obtained from two firms and are attached herewith. These are submitted with a view to having this work carried out as soon as the buildings are ready, and while we are not submitting a tender on the labour it is suggested that we use the services of Mr Johnson the Contractor, if we are able to come to terms with him on an upset price for the complete job.

Should the above suggestion be concurred in by the Branch, may we be advised Air Mail, and Mr Johnson will then be approached. We may say that it will be difficult to obtain the services of painters at this remote point, the nearest point that we might be able to obtain painters would be Rocky Mountain House and from observations, we believe that Mr Johnson could do the above work as well as work we have noted in Rocky Mountain House.

We would recommend that if the painting of these buildings is concurred in, that the materials be purchased at this time in readiness for the completion of the building work.

John S. Hugh, Supt.
Stony - Sarcee Indian Agency.
